# Blaze at Auckland supermarket contained, crews to stay overnight

[By 1News Reporters](https://www.1news.co.nz/reporter/1news-reporters/)

5:02pm

![Firefighters work to control the blaze at the New World at Victoria Park in Auckland. ](https://tvnz-1-news-prod.cdn.arcpublishing.com/resizer/v2/firefighters-work-to-control-the-blaze-at-the-new-world-at-v-QGEE7ONE75A3ZGF2ICRPVYFTQQ.jpg?auth=e5b3eba76a9cab88d408235f09a37aa9f4c49d3bd7a21b2ee65c3c2e577771e8&quality=70&width=767&height=431&focal=960%2C540)

Firefighters work to control the blaze at the New World at Victoria Park in Auckland. (Source: 1News)

A fire at an Auckland supermarket has now been contained but crews will remain on scene overnight to extinguish it.

Fire and Emergency NZ said crews were alerted to the fire at New World Victoria Park in Freemans Bay at 11.18am on Tuesday after a fire alarm was activated.

![](https://cf-images.ap-southeast-2.prod.boltdns.net/v1/static/963482464001/d293afc1-1f83-441a-aa69-3166fb325773/8d7f6f59-bc00-4048-bf90-2c189cfd0c14/1920x1080/match/image.jpg)

Smoke billows from fire at New World in Auckland CBD

The fire broke out at the supermarket in Freeman's Bay shortly after 11am.

Smoke billows from fire at New World in Auckland CBD0:32

The fire broke out at the supermarket in Freeman's Bay shortly after 11am. (Source: 1News)

By 2pm, 20 trucks and support vehicles from stations across the region were at the scene, with further resources still responding. Around 80 firefighters were responding at the height of the blaze.

Three aerial trucks from Auckland were working to bring the blaze under control, with a fourth on its way from Hamilton.

"All persons have been accounted for," FENZ said.

![Firefighters work to extinguish the blaze at a New World in central Auckland. ](https://tvnz-1-news-prod.cdn.arcpublishing.com/resizer/v2/firefighters-work-to-extinguish-the-blaze-at-a-new-world-in-2GHQWRDNRJE5LEEU4GYQI4OGT4.jpg?auth=c903a5dcdb5716f08d2ce587521d4b410566f48a4991e95242d7e8127f1e5b63&quality=70&width=767&height=431&focal=960%2C540)

Firefighters work to extinguish the blaze at a New World in central Auckland. (Source: 1News)

In an update at 4.50pm, Incident Controller Shaun Thornton said crews had been able to access the interior of the building.

Fifteen trucks and support vehicles remained on scene, with the Hamilton aerial now returning to its station.

The smoke had also considerably reduced and the emergency alert to stay inside had been lifted.

Thornton said progress had been made in removing cars from the carpark.

"If customers have a car in the New World carpark they are advised to see the Fire and Emergency New Zealand personnel at the cordon at the bottom end of Franklin Rd who are coordinating the retrieval of vehicles."

A Foodstuffs spokesperson said everyone who was on site at the time of the fire starting were safe and accounted for.

**Watch: Drone captures smoke billowing from supermarket -** [on TVNZ+](https://www.tvnz.co.nz/news/news-clips-str-2ybxbw3lvdni2s4f0hpunv6swim-1750121974158/drone-captures-smoke-billowing-from-auckland-supermarket-fire-in-depth)

The organisation thanked Fire and Emergency New Zealand who "responded quickly and are currently managing the situation on site".

![Firefighters make holes to ventilate the building. ](https://tvnz-1-news-prod.cdn.arcpublishing.com/resizer/v2/firefighters-make-holes-to-ventilate-the-building-CFIXR5NIF5D4BPXGYQHRAAJSK4.jpg?auth=9f2edaf1308a2092d32d64b5acd4cdd947da15ef39605de3bfcb95bdc7193212&quality=70&width=767&height=431&focal=647%2C486)

Firefighters make holes to ventilate the building. (Source: 1News)

"We’ve spoken with local owner-operator Steve Purton and our wider support teams, and together we’re focused on the next steps. Right now, our priority is the safety and wellbeing of everyone involved."

The public was advised to avoid the area.

Photos showed black smoke rising from the store. FENZ said smoke was drifting up into Ponsonby and towards Grey Lynn.

"Residents impacted by the smoke are advised to close their windows and doors and avoid going outside if possible."

![The fire seen from the top of ANZ tower. ](https://tvnz-1-news-prod.cdn.arcpublishing.com/resizer/v2/a-fire-seen-from-the-top-of-anz-tower-GO7HQKBILVESJMVURPLLQWGOQA.jpg?auth=5ab5c0c6d13a5c04230db0eed1c9405e3290263118b99a7c8496b87e067c2a6b&quality=70&width=767&height=431&focal=942%2C778)

The fire seen from the top of ANZ tower. (Source: Jeremy Mahony )

College Hill, Victoria St, Franklin Rd and Scotland St were all closed due to the fire.

"Avoid this area or expect delays with diversions in place affecting all traffic, including bus services," Auckland Transport said.

St John said it had been notified about the incident and that two rapid response vehicles were on standby if required.

Peter Stewart, who was doing his shopping when the fire started, said he was in the produce section when an alarm went off.

![Emergency services at the scene of the fire in central Auckland. ](https://tvnz-1-news-prod.cdn.arcpublishing.com/resizer/v2/emergency-services-at-the-scene-of-the-fire-in-central-auckl-NZRAUCGNXRGVVN3QA3PZAGAVEI.jpg?auth=21a3d5be11811b0b0d9f096612db5e4bb1cbf7a0b4871d7464d1025de68e310a&quality=70&width=767&height=431&focal=2016%2C1134)

Emergency services at the scene of the fire in central Auckland. (Source: 1News)

"There was a slight smell of smoke in the building, and then we very quickly moved out," he said.

Foodstuffs North Island CEO Chris Quin thanked customers for "staying calm and following the team’s direction”.

"We know it must have been a frightening and confusing experience, and we’re so grateful everyone is safe.”

He also praised the staff at the store.

![](https://cf-images.ap-southeast-2.prod.boltdns.net/v1/static/963482464001/5a75e2a4-b4fd-43f9-8019-504c7c170587/33c9d2a4-cb72-409e-88e2-3880adf424a5/1920x1080/match/image.jpg)

Watch: Drone footage shows smoke pouring from roof of Auckland supermarket0:30

Smoke and flames have been seen coming out of New World Victoria Park. (Source: 1News)

“The way our team responded – quickly, calmly, and with genuine care for the people around them – was exceptional. Getting everyone out of a busy supermarket safely and without panic is no small feat. I’m incredibly proud of how they handled it.”

Quin said that the extent of the damage was "not clear".

"Our teams are working hard to understand the impact and are assessing plans to get back to serving our valued customers."

He said the store's team was doing "all they can" to assist those whose vehicles remained on site.

[Persian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Persian_language "Persian language"): تهران, [romanized](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Romanization_of_Persian "Romanization of Persian"): _Tehrân_, pronounced[\[tʰehˈɹɒːn\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:IPA/Persian "Help:IPA/Persian")[Play audio](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/d/d6/Fa-ir-Tehran_%281%29.ogg/Fa-ir-Tehran_%281%29.ogg.mp3 "Play audio")[ⓘ](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Fa-ir-Tehran_(1).ogg "File:Fa-ir-Tehran (1).ogg")) is the capital[\[6\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-6) and largest city of [Iran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iran "Iran"). It is the capital of [Tehran province](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran_province "Tehran province"), and the administrative center for [Tehran County](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran_County "Tehran County") and its [Central District](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_District_(Tehran_County) "Central District (Tehran County)").[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-Tehran_Province_Structure-7) With a population of around 9.8 million in the city as of 2025,[\[8\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-8) and 16.8 million in the metropolitan area, Tehran is the [most populous city](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_largest_cities_of_Iran "List of largest cities of Iran") in Iran and Western Asia,[\[9\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-9) the [second-largest metropolitan area](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Largest_metropolitan_areas_of_the_Middle_East "Largest metropolitan areas of the Middle East") in the [Middle East](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Middle_East "Middle East") after [Cairo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cairo "Cairo"), and the 24th most populous metropolitan area in the world. [Greater Tehran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greater_Tehran "Greater Tehran") includes several municipalities, including, [Karaj](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karaj "Karaj"), [Eslamshahr](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eslamshahr "Eslamshahr"), [Shahriar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shahriar,_Tehran_province "Shahriar, Tehran province"), [Qods](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qods,_Iran "Qods, Iran"), [Malard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malard "Malard"), [Golestan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Golestan,_Tehran "Golestan, Tehran"), [Pakdasht](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pakdasht "Pakdasht"), [Qarchak](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qarchak "Qarchak"), [Nasimshahr](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nasimshahr "Nasimshahr"), [Parand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parand "Parand"), [Pardis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pardis "Pardis"), [Andisheh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andisheh "Andisheh") and [Fardis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fardis "Fardis"). In [classical antiquity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classical_antiquity "Classical antiquity"), part of the territory of present-day Tehran was occupied by Rhages (now [Ray](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ray,_Iran "Ray, Iran")), a prominent [Median](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medes "Medes") city[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-10) almost entirely destroyed in the medieval [Arab](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muslim_conquest_of_Persia "Muslim conquest of Persia"), [Turkic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oghuz_Turks "Oghuz Turks"), and [Mongol](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mongol_conquest_of_Khwarezmia "Mongol conquest of Khwarezmia") invasions. Modern Ray was absorbed into the metropolitan area of Greater Tehran. Tehran was first chosen as the capital of Iran by [Agha Mohammad Khan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agha_Mohammad_Khan_Qajar "Agha Mohammad Khan Qajar") of the [Qajar dynasty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qajar_dynasty "Qajar dynasty") in 1786, because of its proximity to Iran's territories in the [Caucasus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Caucasus "Caucasus"), then separated from Iran in the [Russo-Iranian Wars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russo-Persian_Wars "Russo-Persian Wars"), to avoid the vying factions of the previously ruling Iranian dynasties. The capital has been moved several times throughout history, and Tehran became the 32nd [capital of Iran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capitals_of_Iran "Capitals of Iran"). Large-scale construction works began in the 1920s, and Tehran became a destination for mass migrations from all over Iran in the 20th century.[\[11\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-11) Tehran is home to many historical sites, including the [World Heritage Site](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Heritage_Site "World Heritage Site") [Golestan Palace](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Golestan_Palace "Golestan Palace") of [Qajar dynasty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qajar_dynasty "Qajar dynasty") and [Sa'dabad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sa%27dabad_Complex "Sa'dabad Complex"), [Niavaran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Niavaran_Complex "Niavaran Complex") and [Marmar Palace](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marble_Palace_(Tehran) "Marble Palace (Tehran)") of [Pahlavi dynasty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pahlavi_dynasty "Pahlavi dynasty"). Tehran's landmarks include the [Azadi Tower](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Azadi_Tower "Azadi Tower"), a memorial built in 1971 to mark the [2,500th anniversary of the Persian Empire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2,500-year_celebration_of_the_Persian_Empire "2,500-year celebration of the Persian Empire"), the [Milad Tower](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milad_Tower "Milad Tower"), the world's [sixth-tallest self-supporting tower](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_tallest_towers "List of tallest towers"), completed in 2007, another famous landmark in Tehran is the [Tabiat Bridge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tabiat_Bridge "Tabiat Bridge"), completed in 2014.[\[12\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-archdaily-12) Most of the population are [Persian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Persian_people "Persian people"),[\[13\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-tabnak-13)[\[14\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-Mohammad-14) with roughly 99% of them speaking the [Persian language](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Persian_language "Persian language"), alongside [other ethnolinguistic groups](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethnicities_in_Iran "Ethnicities in Iran") in the city which became Persianised and assimilated.[\[15\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-15) Tehran has been described as a cultural "melting pot" and there are more [Azerbaijanis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iranian_Azerbaijanis "Iranian Azerbaijanis") in Tehran, than any other city in the world and the [Kurdish](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iranian_Kurds "Iranian Kurds") population in Tehran is more than 2 millions.[\[16\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-16)[\[17\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-17)[\[18\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-18)[\[19\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-19)[\[20\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-20)[\[21\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-21) Tehran is served by [Imam Khomeini International Airport](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran_Imam_Khomeini_International_Airport "Tehran Imam Khomeini International Airport"), alongside the domestic [Mehrabad Airport](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mehrabad_International_Airport "Mehrabad International Airport"), [a central railway station](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran_railway_station "Tehran railway station"), [Tehran Metro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran_Metro "Tehran Metro"), the [Tehran Bus Rapid Transit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran_Bus_Rapid_Transit "Tehran Bus Rapid Transit") system, [trolleybuses](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trolleybuses_in_Tehran "Trolleybuses in Tehran"), and [a large network of highways](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Expressways_in_Tehran "List of Expressways in Tehran"). Plans to relocate the capital from Tehran to another area due to [air pollution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Air_pollution "Air pollution") and earthquakes have not been approved so far. A 2016 survey of 230 cities across the globe by [Mercer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercer_(consulting_firm) "Mercer (consulting firm)") ranked Tehran 203rd for [quality of life](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quality_of_life "Quality of life").[\[22\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-22) According to the [Global Destinations Cities Index](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tourism#MasterCard_Global_Destination_Cities_Index "Tourism") in 2016, Tehran is among the top ten fastest [growing tourism destinations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tourism_in_Iran "Tourism in Iran").[\[23\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-23) In 2016, the Tehran City Council declared 6 October to be Tehran Day, celebrating the date in 1907 when the city officially became the capital of Iran.[\[24\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-24) ## Etymology \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tehran&action=edit§ion=1 "Edit section: Etymology")\] Various theories on the origin of the name Tehran have been put forward. Iranian linguist [Ahmad Kasravi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ahmad_Kasravi "Ahmad Kasravi"), in an article "Shemiran-Tehran", suggested that Tehran and Kehran mean "the warm place", and "Shemiran" means "the cool place". He listed cities with the same base and suffix and studied the components of the word in ancient [Iranian languages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iranian_languages "Iranian languages"), and came to the conclusion that Tehran and Kehran meant the same thing in different Iranian language families, as the constant "t" and "k" are close to each other in such languages. He also provided evidence that cities named "Shemiran" were colder than those named "Tehran" or "Kehran". He considered other theories not considering the ancient history of Iranian languages such as "Tirgan" theory and "Tahran" theory [folk etymology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Folk_etymology "Folk etymology").[\[25\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-25) Another theory is that "Tehran" derives from Tiran/Tirgan, "the abode of [Tir](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tir_(god) "Tir (god)")", the [Zoroastrian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zoroastrianism "Zoroastrianism") equivalent of [Hermes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hermes "Hermes"). The ancient [Parthian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parthian_Empire "Parthian Empire") town of Tiran had a neighbour, [Mehran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mehran_(district) "Mehran (district)") ("abode of Mehr/Mithra", the Zoroastrian sun/justice angel). Both of these were mere villages in the suburbs of the great city of Ray/Rhages. Mehran still exists as a residential district in Greater Tehran, as well as Ray, which forms the southern suburbs of Tehran. \[ _[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_\] The official City of Tehran website says that "Tehran" comes from the Persian words "Tah" meaning "end", or "bottom", and "Ran" meaning "\[mountain\] slope"—literally, the bottom of the mountain (ته کوه), referring to Tehran's position at the foot of the [Alborz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alborz "Alborz") mountains.[\[26\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-26) ### Spelling \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tehran&action=edit§ion=2 "Edit section: Spelling")\] In English, it is also spelt " **Teheran**",[\[27\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-27) with both variants being used in books since at least 1800, and "Teheran" being the dominant form from after WWII until shortly before the Islamic Revolution.[\[28\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-28) ## History \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tehran&action=edit§ion=3 "Edit section: History")\] For a chronological guide, see [Timeline of Tehran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_Tehran "Timeline of Tehran"). Archaeological remains from the ancient city of Ray suggest that settlement in Tehran dates back over 6,000 years.[\[29\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-29) ### Classical era \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tehran&action=edit§ion=4 "Edit section: Classical era")\] Tehran is in the historical [Media](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Media_(region) "Media (region)") region of ( [Old Persian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Old_Persian_language "Old Persian language"): 𐎶𐎠𐎭_Māda_) in northwestern Iran. By the time of the [Median Empire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medes "Medes"), part of present-day Tehran was a suburb of the prominent Median city of Rhages ( [Old Persian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Old_Persian_language "Old Persian language"): 𐎼𐎥𐎠_Ragā_). In the [Avesta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Avesta "Avesta")'s _[Videvdat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vendidad "Vendidad")_ (i, 15), Rhages is mentioned as the 12th sacred place created by [Ohrmazd](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ahura_Mazda "Ahura Mazda").[\[30\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-Minorsky-30) In [Old Persian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire "Achaemenid Empire") inscriptions, Rhages appears as a province ( [Bistun](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behistun_Inscription "Behistun Inscription") 2, 10–18). From Rhages, [Darius I](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Darius_I "Darius I") sent reinforcements to his father [Hystaspes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hystaspes_(father_of_Darius_I) "Hystaspes (father of Darius I)"), who was putting down a rebellion in [Parthia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parthia "Parthia") (Bistun 3, 1–10).[\[30\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-Minorsky-30) Some [Middle Persian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Middle_Persian "Middle Persian") texts give Rhages as the birthplace of [Zoroaster](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zoroaster "Zoroaster"),[\[31\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-31) although modern historians generally place the birth of Zoroaster in [Khorasan province](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Khorasan_province "Khorasan province"). [Mount Damavand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mount_Damavand "Mount Damavand"), the highest peak of Iran, which is located near Tehran, is an important location in [Ferdowsi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ferdowsi "Ferdowsi")'s _[Šāhnāme](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shahnameh "Shahnameh")_,[\[32\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-Tafazolli-32) an Iranian [epic poem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epic_poem "Epic poem") based on the [ancient legends of Iran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Persian_mythology "Persian mythology"). It appears in the epics as the homeland of the [protoplast](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Protoplast_(religion) "Protoplast (religion)") [Keyumars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Keyumars "Keyumars"), the birthplace of King [Manuchehr](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manuchehr "Manuchehr"), the place where King [Fereydun](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fereydun "Fereydun") bound the dragon fiend [Aždahāk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zahhak "Zahhak") (Bivarasp), and the place where [Arash](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arash "Arash") shot his arrow.[\[32\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-Tafazolli-32) ### Medieval period \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tehran&action=edit§ion=5 "Edit section: Medieval period")\] In 641, during the reign of the [Sasanian Empire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sasanian_Empire "Sasanian Empire"), [Yazdgerd III](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yazdegerd_III "Yazdegerd III") issued his last appeal to the nation from Rhages, before fleeing to Khorasan.[\[30\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-Minorsky-30) Rhages was dominated by the [Parthian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parthian_Empire "Parthian Empire") [House of Mihran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/House_of_Mihran "House of Mihran"), and [Siyavakhsh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Siyavakhsh "Siyavakhsh")—the son of [Mehran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mihran_Bahram-i_Chubin "Mihran Bahram-i Chubin"), the son of [Bahram Chobin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bahram_Chobin "Bahram Chobin")—who resisted the seventh-century [Muslim invasion of Iran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muslim_conquest_of_Persia "Muslim conquest of Persia").[\[30\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-Minorsky-30) Because of this resistance, when the Arabs captured Rhages, they ordered the town destroyed and rebuilt anew by traitor aristocrat [Farrukhzad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Farrukhzad "Farrukhzad").[\[30\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-Minorsky-30) In the ninth century, Tehran was a well-known village, but less so than the city of Rhages, flourishing nearby. Rhages was described in detail by tenth-century Muslim geographers.[\[30\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-Minorsky-30) Despite the interest that Arabian [Baghdad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baghdad "Baghdad") displayed in Rhages, the number of Arabs in the city remained insignificant and the population mainly consisted of Iranians of all classes.[\[30\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-Minorsky-30)[\[33\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-33) The [Oghuz Turks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oghuz_Turks "Oghuz Turks") invaded Rhages in 1035, and again in 1042, but the city was recovered under the [Seljuks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seljuk_Empire "Seljuk Empire") and the [Khwarezmians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Khwarazmian_dynasty "Khwarazmian dynasty").[\[30\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-Minorsky-30) Medieval writer [Najm od Din Razi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Najm_al-Din_Razi "Najm al-Din Razi") declared the population of Rhages about 500,000 before the [Mongol invasion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mongol_conquest_of_Khwarezmia "Mongol conquest of Khwarezmia"). In the 13th century, the [Mongols](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mongol_Empire "Mongol Empire") invaded Rhages, laid the city to ruins, and massacred many of its inhabitants.[\[30\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-Minorsky-30) Others escaped to Tehran. In July 1404, [Castilian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crown_of_Castile "Crown of Castile") ambassador [Ruy González de Clavijo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ruy_Gonz%C3%A1lez_de_Clavijo "Ruy González de Clavijo") visited Tehran on a journey to [Samarkand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Samarkand "Samarkand"), the capital of Turco-Mongol conqueror [Timur](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timur "Timur"), the ruler of Iran at the time. He described it in his diary as an unwalled region. ### Early modern era \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tehran&action=edit§ion=6 "Edit section: Early modern era")\] Italian traveler [Pietro della Valle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pietro_della_Valle "Pietro della Valle") passed through Tehran overnight in 1618, and in his memoirs called the city _Taheran_. English traveler [Thomas Herbert](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sir_Thomas_Herbert,_1st_Baronet "Sir Thomas Herbert, 1st Baronet") entered Tehran in 1627, and mentioned it as _Tyroan_. Herbert stated that the city had about 3,000 houses.[\[34\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-britannica1911-34) [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Agha_Mohammad_Khan_Qajar%2C_painting%2C_ca._1840.jpg/500px-Agha_Mohammad_Khan_Qajar%2C_painting%2C_ca._1840.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Agha_Mohammad_Khan_Qajar,_painting,_ca._1840.jpg) A portrait of the Shah of Iran [Agha Mohammad Khan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agha_Mohammad_Khan_Qajar "Agha Mohammad Khan Qajar"), at London's [V&A Museum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Victoria_and_Albert_Museum "Victoria and Albert Museum") In the early 18th century, [Karim Khan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karim_Khan_Zand "Karim Khan Zand") of the [Zand dynasty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zand_dynasty "Zand dynasty") ordered a palace and a government office built in Tehran, possibly to declare the city his capital; but he later moved his government to [Shiraz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shiraz "Shiraz"). Eventually, Qajar king [Agha Mohammad Khan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agha_Mohammad_Khan_Qajar "Agha Mohammad Khan Qajar") chose Tehran as the capital of Iran in 1786.[\[35\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-books.google.nl-35) Agha Mohammad Khan's choice of his capital was based on a similar concern for the control of both northern and southern Iran.[\[35\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-books.google.nl-35) He was aware of the loyalties of the inhabitants of former capitals [Isfahan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isfahan "Isfahan") and Shiraz to the [Safavid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Safavid_dynasty "Safavid dynasty") and Zand dynasties respectively, and was wary of the power of the local notables in these cities.[\[35\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-books.google.nl-35) Thus, he probably viewed Tehran's lack of a substantial urban structure as a blessing, because it minimized the chances of resistance to his rule by the notables and by the general public.[\[35\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-books.google.nl-35) He had to remain within close reach of [Azerbaijan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Azerbaijan_(Iran) "Azerbaijan (Iran)") and Iran's integral [northern](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_Caucasus "North Caucasus") and [southern](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Caucasus "South Caucasus") [Caucasian territories](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Caucasus "Caucasus")[\[35\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-books.google.nl-35)—at that time not yet irrevocably lost per the treaties of [Golestan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Treaty_of_Gulistan "Treaty of Gulistan") and [Turkmenchay](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Treaty_of_Turkmenchay "Treaty of Turkmenchay") to the neighboring [Russian Empire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russian_Empire "Russian Empire")—which would follow in the course of the 19th century.[\[36\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-36) [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Golestan_Palace_Album_No._132-31.jpg/250px-Golestan_Palace_Album_No._132-31.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Golestan_Palace_Album_No._132-31.jpg) A modern street in Tehran at the end of the 19th-century. Golestan Palace Collection After 50 years of Qajar rule, the city still barely had more than 80,000 inhabitants.[\[35\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-books.google.nl-35) Up until the 1870s, Tehran consisted of a walled citadel, a roofed [bazaar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bazaar "Bazaar"), and the three main neighborhoods of [Udlajan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oudlajan "Oudlajan"), Chale-Meydan, and Sangelaj, where the majority resided. During the long reign of [Naser al-Din Shah](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naser_al-Din_Shah_Qajar "Naser al-Din Shah Qajar") (1848-1896), Tehran witnessed Iran's first [institute of higher learning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dar_ul-Funun_(Persia) "Dar ul-Funun (Persia)"), [bank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imperial_Bank_of_Persia "Imperial Bank of Persia"), [railway line](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran%E2%80%93Rey_Railway "Tehran–Rey Railway") and museum.[\[37\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-37)[\[38\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-38)[\[39\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-39) The city expanded rapidly through multiple development plans[\[40\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-40) The first development plan of Tehran in 1855 emphasized traditional spatial structure. The second, under the supervision of [Dar ol Fonun](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dar_ul-Funun_(Persia) "Dar ul-Funun (Persia)") in 1878, included new city walls, in the form of a perfect octagon with an area of 19 square kilometers, mimicking the [Renaissance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Renaissance "Renaissance") cities of Europe.[\[41\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-Vahdat_Za-2011-41) Tehran was 19.79 square kilometers, and had expanded more than fourfold.[\[42\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-42) ### Late modern era \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tehran&action=edit§ion=7 "Edit section: Late modern era")\] [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Poster_of_Conquest_of_Tehran_in_July_1909_by_Bakhtiaris.jpg/250px-Poster_of_Conquest_of_Tehran_in_July_1909_by_Bakhtiaris.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Poster_of_Conquest_of_Tehran_in_July_1909_by_Bakhtiaris.jpg) The [Triumph of Tehran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triumph_of_Tehran "Triumph of Tehran"): [Sardar Asad II](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ali-Qoli_Khan_Bakhtiari "Ali-Qoli Khan Bakhtiari") and [Sepahsalar e Tonekaboni](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mohammad_Vali_Khan_Tonekaboni "Mohammad Vali Khan Tonekaboni") conquering Tehran in July 1909 Growing awareness of civil rights resulted in the [Constitutional Revolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Persian_Constitutional_Revolution "Persian Constitutional Revolution") and the [first constitution of Iran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Persian_Constitution_of_1906 "Persian Constitution of 1906") in 1906. On 2 June 1907, the parliament passed a law on local governance known as the _Baladie_ ( [municipal law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Municipal_law "Municipal law")), providing a detailed outline of issues such as the role of councils within the city, the members' qualifications, the election process, and the requirements to be entitled to vote. The then-Qajar monarch [Mohammad Ali Shah](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mohammad_Ali_Shah_Qajar "Mohammad Ali Shah Qajar") abolished the constitution and [bombarded the parliament](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1908_bombardment_of_the_Majlis "1908 bombardment of the Majlis") with the help of the Russian-controlled [Cossack Brigade](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Persian_Cossack_Brigade "Persian Cossack Brigade") on 23 June 1908. That was followed by the capture of the city by the revolutionary forces of [Ali-Qoli Khan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ali-Qoli_Khan_Bakhtiari "Ali-Qoli Khan Bakhtiari") (Sardar Asad II) and [Mohammad Vali Khan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mohammad_Vali_Khan_Tonekaboni "Mohammad Vali Khan Tonekaboni") (Sepahsalar e Tonekaboni) on 13 July 1909. As a result, the monarch was exiled and replaced by his son [Ahmad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ahmad_Shah_Qajar "Ahmad Shah Qajar"), and the parliament was re-established. #### World War I \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tehran&action=edit§ion=8 "Edit section: World War I")\] During the [Persian campaign](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Persian_campaign_(World_War_I) "Persian campaign (World War I)"), Russian forces that were occupying the northwest of Iran marched around [Qazvin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qazvin "Qazvin") and approached Tehran, caused a crisis and the dissolution of [parliament](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Consultative_Assembly "National Consultative Assembly"). [Ahmad Shah Qajar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ahmad_Shah_Qajar "Ahmad Shah Qajar") and his entourage decided to leave Tehran and move the capital to another place, sparking fears of rebellion in other cities.[\[43\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-Bahar-1992-43) During the [Battle of Robat Karim](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Robat_Karim "Battle of Robat Karim"), Iranian forces led by Heydar Latifiyan prevented the Russians from taking Tehran, despite the latter winning the battle.[\[44\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-44) This also allowed government functions to be moved to Qom and then to Isfahan, while the monarchy remained in Tehran.[\[43\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-Bahar-1992-43) #### Pahlavi rule \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tehran&action=edit§ion=9 "Edit section: Pahlavi rule")\] [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/ETH-BIB-Teheran_aus_400_m_H%C3%B6he-Persienflug_1924-1925-LBS_MH02-02-0085-AL-FL.tif/lossy-page1-500px-ETH-BIB-Teheran_aus_400_m_H%C3%B6he-Persienflug_1924-1925-LBS_MH02-02-0085-AL-FL.tif.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:ETH-BIB-Teheran_aus_400_m_H%C3%B6he-Persienflug_1924-1925-LBS_MH02-02-0085-AL-FL.tif) An aerial view of Tehran in 1925 After [World War I](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_I "World War I"), the [constituent assembly](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constituent_assembly "Constituent assembly") elected [Reza Shah](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reza_Shah "Reza Shah") of the [Pahlavi dynasty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pahlavi_dynasty "Pahlavi dynasty") as the new monarch, who immediately suspended the Baladie law of 1907, replacing the decentralized and autonomous city councils with centralist approaches to [governance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Governance "Governance") and planning.[\[41\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-Vahdat_Za-2011-41) From the 1920s to the 1930s, under the rule of Reza Shah, the city was essentially rebuilt from scratch. Several old buildings, including parts of the [Golestan Palace](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Golestan_Palace "Golestan Palace"), [Tekye Dowlat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tekyeh_Dowlat "Tekyeh Dowlat"), and [Tupkhane Square](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toopkhaneh "Toopkhaneh"), were replaced with modern buildings influenced by classical Iranian architecture, particularly the buildings of the [National Bank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_Melli_Iran "Bank Melli Iran"), the police headquarters, the telegraph office, and the military academy. Changes to the urban fabric began with the street-widening act of 1933, which served as a framework for changes in all other cities. The [Grand Bazaar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Bazaar,_Tehran "Grand Bazaar, Tehran") was divided in half and many historic buildings were demolished and replaced by wide straight avenues,[\[45\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-45) and the traditional texture of the city was replaced with intersecting cruciform streets that created large roundabouts in major public spaces such as the bazaar. As an attempt to create a network for easy transportation within the city, the old citadel and city walls were demolished in 1937, replaced by wide streets cutting through the urban fabric. The new city map of Tehran in 1937 was heavily influenced by modernist planning patterns of zoning and gridiron networks.[\[41\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-Vahdat_Za-2011-41) During [World War II](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"), Soviet and British troops entered the city. In 1943, Tehran was the site of the [Tehran Conference](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran_Conference "Tehran Conference"), attended by U.S. president [Franklin D. Roosevelt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt "Franklin D. Roosevelt"), Soviet premier [Joseph Stalin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Stalin "Joseph Stalin"), and British prime minister [Winston Churchill](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Winston_Churchill "Winston Churchill"). The establishment of the planning organization of Iran in 1948 resulted in the first socioeconomic development plan to cover from 1949 to 1955. These plans not only failed to slow the unbalanced growth of Tehran but with the 1962 land reforms that Reza Shah's son and successor [Mohammad Reza Shah](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mohammad_Reza_Pahlavi "Mohammad Reza Pahlavi") named the _[White Revolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/White_Revolution "White Revolution")_, Tehran's chaotic growth was further accentuated. In the 1960s and 1970s, Tehran developed rapidly under Mohammad Reza Shah. Modern buildings altered the face of Tehran and ambitious projects were planned for the following decades. To resolve the problem of [social exclusion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_exclusion "Social exclusion"), the first comprehensive plan was approved in 1968. The consortium of Iranian architect [Abd-ol-Aziz Farmanfarmaian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abdol-Aziz_Mirza_Farmanfarmaian "Abdol-Aziz Mirza Farmanfarmaian") and the American firm of [Victor Gruen Associates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Victor_Gruen "Victor Gruen") identified the main problems blighting the city as high-density suburbs, air and water pollution, inefficient infrastructure, unemployment, and rural-urban migration. Eventually, the whole plan was marginalized by the [1979 Revolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1979_Revolution "1979 Revolution") and the subsequent [Iran–Iraq War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93Iraq_War "Iran–Iraq War").[\[41\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-Vahdat_Za-2011-41) [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Tehran_IMG_20191219_122637099_%2849550671088%29.jpg/250px-Tehran_IMG_20191219_122637099_%2849550671088%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Tehran_IMG_20191219_122637099_(49550671088).jpg) The [Azadi Tower](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Azadi_Tower "Azadi Tower") was built in 1971 Tehran's most famous landmark, the Azadi Tower, was built by the order of the Shah in 1971. It was designed by [Hossein Amanat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hossein_Amanat "Hossein Amanat"), an architect whose design won a competition, combining elements of classical [Sassanian architecture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sasanian_architecture "Sasanian architecture") with post-classical Iranian architecture. Formerly known as the _Shahyad Tower_, it was built to commemorate the [2,500th anniversary of the Imperial State of Iran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2,500-year_celebration_of_the_Persian_Empire "2,500-year celebration of the Persian Empire"). ### Islamic Republic \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tehran&action=edit§ion=10 "Edit section: Islamic Republic")\] During the [Iran–Iraq War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93Iraq_War "Iran–Iraq War") in 1980 to 1988, Tehran was repeatedly targeted by airstrikes and [Scud](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scud "Scud") missile attacks. The 435-meter-high Milad Tower, one of the proposed development projects of pre-revolutionary Iran,[\[46\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-SadCity-46) was completed in 2007, and has become a famous landmark of Tehran. [Tabiat Bridge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tabiat_Bridge "Tabiat Bridge"), a 270-meter [pedestrian overpass](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Footbridge "Footbridge")[\[12\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-archdaily-12) that was designed by award-winning architect [Leila Araghian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leila_Araghian "Leila Araghian"), was completed in 2014. The city municipality started planting large number of imported palm trees replacing endemic plane trees.[\[47\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-47) ## Demographics \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tehran&action=edit§ion=11 "Edit section: Demographics")\] See also: [Demographics of Tehran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demographics_of_Tehran "Demographics of Tehran") Further information: [Ethnicities in Iran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethnicities_in_Iran "Ethnicities in Iran") [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Tehran_Population_%281956-2016%29.png/250px-Tehran_Population_%281956-2016%29.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Tehran_Population_(1956-2016).png) The population of households.[\[50\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-2016_Tehran_Province-50) ### Language and ethnicity \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tehran&action=edit§ion=13 "Edit section: Language and ethnicity")\] With its cosmopolitan atmosphere, Tehran is home to diverse ethnic and linguistic groups from all over the country. The present-day dominant language of Tehran is the [Tehrani variety](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehrani_accent "Tehrani accent") of the [Persian language](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Persian_language "Persian language"), and the majority of people in Tehran identify themselves as [Persians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Persian_people "Persian people").[\[14\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-Mohammad-14)[\[13\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-tabnak-13) Historically the native language of the Tehran–Ray region was not Persian, which is linguistically Southwest Iranian and originates in [Fars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fars_province "Fars province"), but a now extinct [Northwestern Iranian language](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_Iranian_languages "Western Iranian languages").[\[51\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-51) [Iranian Azeris](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iranian_Azerbaijanis "Iranian Azerbaijanis") are the second-largest ethnic group of the city, comprising about 10-15% [\[52\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-Iran-Azeris-52)[\[53\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-Country_Study_Guide-Azerbaijanis-53) of the population. Ethnic [Mazanderanis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mazanderani_people "Mazanderani people") are the third-largest, comprising about 5% of the population.[\[54\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-54) Tehran's other ethnic communities include [Kurds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kurds "Kurds"), [Armenians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iranian_Armenians "Iranian Armenians"), [Georgians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iranian_Georgians "Iranian Georgians"), [Bakhtyaris](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bakhtiari_people "Bakhtiari people"), [Talysh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talysh_people "Talysh people"), [Baloch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baloch_people "Baloch people"), [Assyrians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assyrians_in_Iran "Assyrians in Iran"), [Arabs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arabs "Arabs"), [Jews](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iranian_Jews "Iranian Jews"), and [Circassians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Circassians_in_Iran "Circassians in Iran"). In the 2010 census by the Sociology Department of the [University of Tehran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Tehran "University of Tehran"), in many districts of Tehran across various socio-economic classes in proportion to population sizes of each district and socio-economic class, 63% of the people were born in Tehran, 98% knew Persian, 75% identified themselves as ethnic Persian, and 13% had some degree of proficiency in a European language.[\[13\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-tabnak-13) Tehran saw a drastic change in its ethnic-social composition in the early 1980s. After the political, social, and economic consequences of the [1979 Revolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1979_Revolution "1979 Revolution") and the years that followed, a number of Iranian citizens, mostly Tehranis, left Iran. The majority of [Iranian emigrations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iranian_diaspora "Iranian diaspora") have left for the [United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iranian_Americans "Iranian Americans"), [Germany](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iranians_in_Germany "Iranians in Germany"), [Sweden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swedish_Iranians "Swedish Iranians"), and [Canada](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iranian_Canadians "Iranian Canadians"). With the start of the [Iran–Iraq War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93Iraq_War "Iran–Iraq War") (1980–1988), a second wave of inhabitants fled the city, especially during the Iraqi air offensives on Tehran. With most major powers backing Iraq at the time, economic isolation gave yet more reason for many inhabitants to leave Tehran and the country. Having left all they had and having struggled to adapt to a new country and build a life, most of them never came back when the war was over. During the war, Tehran also received a great number of migrants from the west and the southwest of Iran bordering [Iraq](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iraq "Iraq"). The unstable situation and the war in neighbouring [Afghanistan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Afghanistan "Afghanistan") and Iraq prompted a rush of refugees into Iran, who arrived in millions. Tehran was a magnet for many seeking work, who helped Tehran to recover from war wounds, working for a far lower pay than local construction workers. Many of these refugees are being repatriated with the assistance of the [UNHCR](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Nations_High_Commissioner_for_Refugees "United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees"), but there are still sizable groups of Afghan and Iraqi refugees in Tehran who are reluctant to leave, being pessimistic about the situation in their own countries. Afghan refugees are mostly [Dari](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dari_language "Dari language")-speaking [Tajik](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tajiks "Tajiks") and [Hazara](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hazara_people "Hazara people"), speaking a variety of Persian, and Iraqi refugees are mainly [Mesopotamian Arabic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mesopotamian_Arabic "Mesopotamian Arabic")-speakers who are often of Iranian and Persian ethnic heritage. ### Religion \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tehran&action=edit§ion=14 "Edit section: Religion")\] See also: [Religion in Iran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Religion_in_Iran "Religion in Iran") and [List of religious centers in Tehran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_religious_centers_in_Tehran "List of religious centers in Tehran") The majority of Tehranis are officially [Twelver Shia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twelver_Shia "Twelver Shia") [Muslims](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muslims "Muslims"), which has been the state religion since the 16th-century [Safavid conversion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Safavid_conversion_of_Iran_to_Shia_Islam "Safavid conversion of Iran to Shia Islam"). Other religious communities in Tehran include followers of the [Sunni](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sunni_Islam "Sunni Islam") and [Mystic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sufism "Sufism") branches of Islam, Christian denominations, Judaism, [Zoroastrianism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zoroastrianism "Zoroastrianism"), and the [Baháʼí Faith](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%CA%BC%C3%AD_Faith "Baháʼí Faith"). In the 2016 "Tehran Survey", when residents of Tehran were asked about the importance of religion in their life, 53.5% considered it to be "very important / important", 31.1% to be "rather important", 10.5% to be "not very important" and 4.8% to be "not at all important."[\[55\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-55) There are many religious centres scattered around Tehran, from old to newly built centres, including [mosques](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_religious_centers_in_Tehran#Mosques_and_madrasehs "List of religious centers in Tehran"), [churches](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_religious_centers_in_Tehran#Churches "List of religious centers in Tehran"), [synagogues](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_religious_centers_in_Tehran#Synagogues "List of religious centers in Tehran"), and [Zoroastrian fire temples](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_religious_centers_in_Tehran#Fire_temples "List of religious centers in Tehran"). Tehran has a very small third-generation Indian [Sikh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sikh "Sikh") community with a local [gurdwara](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gurdwara "Gurdwara") that was visited by the Indian Prime Minister, [Manmohan Singh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manmohan_Singh "Manmohan Singh") in 2012.[\[56\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-Indian_Prime_Minister_in_Tehran-56) ## Geography \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tehran&action=edit§ion=15 "Edit section: Geography")\] ### Location and subdivisions \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tehran&action=edit§ion=16 "Edit section: Location and subdivisions")\] [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Tehran_district_map_%28blank%29.svg/250px-Tehran_district_map_%28blank%29.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Tehran_district_map_(blank).svg) The districts of Tehran The metropolis of Tehran is divided into 22 municipal districts, each with its own administrative center. Of the 22 municipal districts, 20 are located in [Tehran County](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran_County "Tehran County")'s [Central District](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_District_(Tehran_County) "Central District (Tehran County)"), while districts [1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/District_1_(Tehran) "District 1 (Tehran)") and [20](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/District_20_(Tehran) "District 20 (Tehran)") are respectively located in the counties of [Shemiranat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shemiranat_County "Shemiranat County") and [Ray](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ray_County,_Iran "Ray County, Iran"). | showRegions and municipal districts of Tehran | | --- | | | | | | | | | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | | **North**:

government ministries and headquarters. Commercial centers are located further north. ### Climate \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tehran&action=edit§ion=17 "Edit section: Climate")\] [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Tehran_Profile%2C_Level_1%2C_2012.jpg/250px-Tehran_Profile%2C_Level_1%2C_2012.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Tehran_Profile,_Level_1,_2012.jpg) A 2012 urban sustainability analysis of the metropolitan area of Tehran, using the 'Circles of Sustainability' method of the [UN Global Compact](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Nations_Global_Compact "United Nations Global Compact") Cities Programme Most of Tehran has a cold [semi-arid climate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semi-arid_climate "Semi-arid climate"), _BSk_ within the [Köppen climate classification](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification "Köppen climate classification"). The climate is _BSh_ (hot semi-arid) around [Mehrabad International Airport](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mehrabad_International_Airport "Mehrabad International Airport") and cold semi-arid in higher areas, with a borderline [Mediterranean climate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mediterranean_climate#Hot-summer_Mediterranean_climate "Mediterranean climate") ( _Csa_) in the northern area of Tehran, with hot, dry summers and cool, rainy winters. Tehran's climate is largely defined by its geographic location, with the towering [Alborz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alborz "Alborz") mountains to its north and Iran's central desert to the south. As Tehran has a large area, with significant differences in elevation among various districts, the weather is often cooler in the hilly north than in the flat southern part of Tehran. For instance, the 17.3 km (10.7 mi) [Valiasr Street](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Valiasr_Street "Valiasr Street") runs from Tehran's railway station at 1,117 m (3,665 ft) elevation above sea level in Tehran's south, to [Tajrish Square](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tajrish_Square "Tajrish Square") at 1712.6 m (5612.3 ft) elevation above sea level in the north.[\[60\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-60) The elevation rises up to 2,000 m (6,600 ft) at the end of [Velenjak](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Velenjak "Velenjak") in northern Tehran. The sparse texture, the existence of old gardens, orchards, green spaces along the highways and the lack of industrial activities in the north of Tehran make the air in the northern areas 2 to 3 degrees Celsius cooler than the southern areas of Tehran.[\[61\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-Tehran_Geography-61) The main direction of the prevailing wind in Tehran is northwest to southeast.[\[62\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-hamshahrionline-62) Other air currents that blow in the area of Tehran are: 1. Tochal breeze: With the rapid cooling of the Alborz mountain range at night, a local high-pressure center is formed on Mount Tochal. This cold current flows down the mountain due to its weight and high pressure. Thus, a gentle breeze blows into the city from the north at night.[\[61\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-Tehran_Geography-61) 2. Southern and southeastern regional winds: these winds blow from the desert plains in the hot months of the year.[\[61\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-Tehran_Geography-61) 3. Western winds: These winds are among the planetary winds that affect Tehran throughout the year and can be called the prevailing wind.[\[61\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-Tehran_Geography-61) Air currents have a great effect on Tehran's weather. The prevailing wind blowing from the west causes the west of Tehran to always be exposed to fresh air. Although this wind brings smoke and pollution from the western industrial areas, its strong wind takes polluted air out of Tehran.[\[61\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-Tehran_Geography-61) In most years, winter provides half of Tehran's annual rainfall. March is the rainiest month of the year and about one-fifth of the annual rainfall occurs in it. Summer is the least rainy season. September is the driest month of the year in Tehran. The average annual rainfall of Tehran is sometimes very different in the north and south regions.[\[61\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-Tehran_Geography-61) There are between 205 and 213 days of clear to partly cloudy weather in Tehran.[\[63\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-atlas.tehran.ir-63) One of the most intense rains in Tehran happened on 21 April 1962, with 10 hours of rain. Meteorology determined that the amount of rainfall on that one day in Tehran was equivalent to six years.[\[64\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-64) Summer is hot and dry with little rain, and [relative humidity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Relative_humidity "Relative humidity") is generally low. Average high temperatures are between 31 °C (88 °F) and 38 °C (100 °F) during [summer months](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Summer "Summer"), and it can sometimes rise up to 40 °C (104 °F) during [heat waves](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heat_waves "Heat waves"). Average low temperatures in summer are between 18 °C (64 °F) and 25 °C (77 °F). It can occasionally drop to below 14 °C (57 °F)  in the mountainous north of the city at night. Winter is cold and occasionally snowy, with an average of 12.3 snow days annually in central Tehran and more than 23.7 snow days annually in northern Tehran. During the [winter months](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Winter "Winter"), average high temperatures are between 3 °C (37 °F) and 11 °C (52 °F). Average low temperatures are between −5 °C (23 °F) and 1 °C (34 °F), and it can occasionally drop to below −10 °C (14 °F)  during [cold waves](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cold_waves "Cold waves"). Most of the annual [precipitation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Precipitation_(meteorology) "Precipitation (meteorology)") occurs from late autumn to mid-spring. March is the wettest month with an average precipitation of 39.6 mm (1.56 in). The hottest month is July, with a mean minimum temperature of 24 °C (75 °F) and a mean maximum temperature of 36.7 °C (98.1 °F). The coldest is January, with a mean minimum temperature of −0.4 °C (31.3 °F) and a mean maximum temperature of 7.9 °C (46.2 °F).[\[65\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-IranTour-65) The highest recorded temperature was 43 °C (109 °F) on 3 July 1958.
