Snow depth was recorded as 15 cm (6 in) in the southern part of Tehran and 100 cm (39 in) in the northern part of Tehran. One newspaper reported that it had been the worst weather in 34 years. Ten thousand bulldozers and 13,000 municipal workers were deployed to keep the main roads open.[\[78\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-BBC-79)[\[79\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-chn-80) On 5 and 6 January 2008, a [wave of heavy snow and low temperatures](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Winter_storm "Winter storm") covered Tehran in a thick layer of snow and ice, forcing the Council of Ministers to declare a [state of emergency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_of_emergency "State of emergency") and close down the capital from 6 January to 7 January.[\[80\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-IRNA-81) On 3 February 2014, Tehran received heavy snowfall, specifically in the northern parts of the city, with a depth of 2 metres (6.6 ft). In one week of successive snowfalls, roads were made impassable in some areas, with the temperature ranging from −8 °C (18 °F)  to  −16 °C (3 °F).[\[81\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-BBC_News-82) On 3 June 2014, a severe thunderstorm with powerful [microbursts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microbursts "Microbursts") created a [haboob](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haboob "Haboob"), engulfing Tehran in sand and dust and causing five deaths, with more than 57 injured. This event knocked down numerous trees and power lines. It struck between 5:00 and 6:00 p.m., dropping temperatures from 33 °C (91 °F)  to 19 °C (66 °F)  within an hour. The dramatic temperature drop was accompanied by wind gusts reaching nearly 118 km/h (73 mph).[\[82\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-AccuWeather-83) ### Environmental issues \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tehran&action=edit§ion=18 "Edit section: Environmental issues")\] See also: [Environmental issues in Tehran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Environmental_issues_in_Tehran "Environmental issues in Tehran"), [Environmental issues in Iran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Environmental_issues_in_Iran "Environmental issues in Iran"), and [List of earthquakes in Iran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_earthquakes_in_Iran "List of earthquakes in Iran") [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Air_pollution_of_Tehran_-_5_January_2013_06.jpg/250px-Air_pollution_of_Tehran_-_5_January_2013_06.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Air_pollution_of_Tehran_-_5_January_2013_06.jpg) Heavy air pollution in Tehran A plan to move the capital has been discussed many times in prior years, due mainly to the environmental issues of the region. Tehran is one of the world's most polluted cities and is located near two major [fault lines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fault_lines "Fault lines"). Tehran suffers from severe air pollution, 80% of it due to cars.[\[83\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-84) The remaining 20% is due to [industrial pollution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrial_pollution "Industrial pollution"). Other estimates suggest that motorcycles account for 30% of air and 50% of [noise pollution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noise_pollution "Noise pollution") in Tehran.[\[84\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-85) Tehran is considered one of the strongest sources of greenhouse gas emissions in the Middle East. Enhanced concentration of carbon dioxide over Tehran, that likely originate from the anthropogenic urban sources in the city, is easily detectable from satellite observations throughout the year.[\[85\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-86) In 2010, the government announced that "for security and administrative reasons, the plan to move the capital from Tehran has been finalized."[\[86\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-Relocation-87) There are plans to relocate 163 state firms and several [universities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Iranian_Universities "List of Iranian Universities") from Tehran to avoid damages from a potential earthquake.[\[86\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-Relocation-87)[\[87\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-88) City officials are engaged in a battle to reduce air pollution. They have, for instance, encouraged taxis and buses to convert from petrol engines to [compressed natural gas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compressed_natural_gas "Compressed natural gas"). The government has set up a "Traffic Zone" covering the city centre during peak traffic hours. Entering and driving inside this zone is only allowed with a special permit. There are efforts to raise people's awareness of the hazards of pollution. Pollution Indicator Boards have been installed all around the city to monitor the level of [particulate matter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atmospheric_particulate_matter "Atmospheric particulate matter") (PM2.5/PM10), [nitrogen dioxide](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nitrogen_dioxide "Nitrogen dioxide") (NO2), ozone (O3), [sulfur dioxide](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sulfur_dioxide "Sulfur dioxide") (SO2), and [carbon monoxide](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carbon_monoxide "Carbon monoxide") (CO). ## Economy \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tehran&action=edit§ion=19 "Edit section: Economy")\] See also: [Economy of Tehran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy_of_Tehran "Economy of Tehran"), [Industry of Iran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industry_of_Iran "Industry of Iran"), and [Communications in Iran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communications_in_Iran "Communications in Iran") [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Tehran_Stock_Exchange_3513534.jpg/250px-Tehran_Stock_Exchange_3513534.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Tehran_Stock_Exchange_3513534.jpg) [Tehran Stock Exchange](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran_Stock_Exchange "Tehran Stock Exchange") Tehran is the economic centre of Iran.[\[88\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-89) About 30% of Iran's public-sector workforce and 45% of its large industrial firms are located in the city, and almost half of these workers are employed by the government.[\[89\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-90) Most of the remainder of workers are factory workers, shopkeepers, laborers, and transport workers. Few foreign companies operate in Tehran, due to the government's complex international relations. But prior to the [1979 Revolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1979_Revolution "1979 Revolution"), many foreign companies were active in Iran.[\[90\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-91) Tehran's present-day modern industries include the manufacturing of automobiles, electronics and electrical equipment, weaponry, textiles, sugar, cement, and chemical products. It is also a leading centre for the sale of carpets and furniture. The oil refining companies of [Pars Oil](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pars_Oil "Pars Oil"), [Speedy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sepahan_Oil_Company "Sepahan Oil Company"), and [Behran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behran_Oil_Company "Behran Oil Company") are based in Tehran. Tehran relies heavily on private cars, buses, motorcycles, and taxis, and is one of the most car-dependent cities in the world. The [Tehran Stock Exchange](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran_Stock_Exchange "Tehran Stock Exchange"), which is a full member of the [World Federation of Exchanges](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Federation_of_Exchanges "World Federation of Exchanges") (WFE) and a founding member of the [Federation of Euro-Asian Stock Exchanges](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federation_of_Euro-Asian_Stock_Exchanges "Federation of Euro-Asian Stock Exchanges"), has been one of the world's best-performing stock exchanges in recent years.[\[91\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-92) ### Fashion industry \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tehran&action=edit§ion=20 "Edit section: Fashion industry")\] Design, manufacturing, distribution, marketing, retail, advertising and other sectors of the [fashion industry in Tehran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fashion_in_Iran "Fashion in Iran") have been able to grow significantly according to the needs of the country. In particular, a large number of male and female models are working in Tehran's fashion advertising and promotion sections. Despite the lack of adequate laws to support models, payments to female models have been considered high. Also, modeling of children is usually prohibited in Tehran. Clothing manufacturers are closely related to other fashion sectors in Tehran. For example, the manufacturers of women's boots and bodysuits have strengthened their exports and branding in other countries by using this connection.[\[92\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-93) ### Shopping \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tehran&action=edit§ion=21 "Edit section: Shopping")\] See also: [List of shopping malls in Iran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_shopping_malls_in_Iran "List of shopping malls in Iran") Tehran has a wide range of shopping centers, and is home to over 60 modern shopping malls.[\[93\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-gulfn-94)[\[94\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-95) The city has a number of [commercial districts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commercial_district "Commercial district"), including those located at [Valiasr](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Valiasr_Street "Valiasr Street"), [Davudie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Davoodiyeh "Davoodiyeh"), and [Zaferanie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zafaraniyeh "Zafaraniyeh"). The largest old [bazaars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bazaar "Bazaar") of Tehran are the [Grand Bazaar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Bazaar,_Tehran "Grand Bazaar, Tehran") and the [Bazaar of Tajrish](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tajrish "Tajrish"). [Iran Mall](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iran_Mall "Iran Mall") is the largest mall in the world in area.[\[95\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-96) Most of the international branded stores and upper-class shops are in the northern and western parts of the city. Tehran's retail business is growing with several newly built malls and shopping centres.[\[93\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-gulfn-94) Tehran is a center for the production of women's clothing in Iran. Shoe (Mostly women's boots) manufacturing companies in Tehran can be reached in the malls.[\[96\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-97) ### Tourism \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tehran&action=edit§ion=22 "Edit section: Tourism")\] Main article: [Tourism in Tehran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tourism_in_Tehran "Tourism in Tehran") [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/%DA%A9%D8%A7%D8%AE_%DA%AF%D9%84%D8%B3%D8%AA%D8%A7%D9%86_6.jpg/250px-%DA%A9%D8%A7%D8%AE_%DA%AF%D9%84%D8%B3%D8%AA%D8%A7%D9%86_6.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:%DA%A9%D8%A7%D8%AE_%DA%AF%D9%84%D8%B3%D8%AA%D8%A7%D9%86_6.jpg) [Golestan Palace](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Golestan_Palace "Golestan Palace"), One of the oldest historic monuments in the city. [UNESCO World Heritage Site](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Heritage_Site "World Heritage Site") Tehran, as one of the main tourist destinations in Iran, has a wealth of cultural attractions. It is home to royal complexes of [Golestan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Golestan_Palace "Golestan Palace"), [Saadabad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sa%27dabad_Complex "Sa'dabad Complex") and [Niavaran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Niavaran_Complex "Niavaran Complex"), which were built under the reign of the country's last two monarchies. There are several historic, artistic, and scientific museums in Tehran, including the - [National Museum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Museum_of_Iran "National Museum of Iran") - [Malek Museum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malik_National_Museum_of_Iran "Malik National Museum of Iran") - Cinema Museum at [Ferdows Garden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ferdows_Garden "Ferdows Garden") - [Abgineh Museum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abgineh_Museum_of_Tehran "Abgineh Museum of Tehran") - [Museum of the Qasr Prison](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_of_the_Qasr_Prison "Museum of the Qasr Prison") - [Carpet Museum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Carpet_Museum_of_Iran "The Carpet Museum of Iran") - Reverse Glass Painting Museum (vitray art) - [Safir Office Machines Museum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Safir_Office_Machines_Museum "Safir Office Machines Museum") Also the [Museum of Contemporary Art](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran_Museum_of_Contemporary_Art "Tehran Museum of Contemporary Art"), which hosts works of famous artists such as [Van Gogh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Van_Gogh "Van Gogh"), [Pablo Picasso](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pablo_Picasso "Pablo Picasso"), and [Andy Warhol](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Warhol "Andy Warhol"). The [Iranian Imperial Crown Jewels](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iranian_Crown_Jewels "Iranian Crown Jewels"), one of the largest jewel collections in the world, are also on display at Tehran's National Jewelry Museum. A number of cultural and trade exhibitions take place in Tehran, which are mainly operated by the country's [International Exhibitions Company](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iran_International_Exhibitions_Company "Iran International Exhibitions Company"). Tehran's annual [International Book Fair](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran_International_Book_Fair "Tehran International Book Fair") is known to the international publishing world as one of the most important publishing events in Asia.[\[97\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-98) ## Infrastructure \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tehran&action=edit§ion=23 "Edit section: Infrastructure")\] ### Highways and streets \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tehran&action=edit§ion=24 "Edit section: Highways and streets")\] See also: [List of Expressways in Tehran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Expressways_in_Tehran "List of Expressways in Tehran") [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Fajr_Bridge_Tehran2.jpg/250px-Fajr_Bridge_Tehran2.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Fajr_Bridge_Tehran2.jpg) Fajr Bridge, [Hemmat Expressway](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hemmat_Expressway "Hemmat Expressway") Following the [Islamic Revolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iranian_Revolution "Iranian Revolution") in 1979, the political system changed from [constitutional monarchy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy "Constitutional monarchy") to [Islamic republic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Islamic_republic "Islamic republic"). Then the construction of political power in the country needed to change so that new spectrums of political power decision-making centers emerged in Iran. Motives, desires and actions of these new political power decision-making centers in Iran, made them rename streets and public places throughout the country, especially Tehran. For example Shahyad square changed to [Azadi square](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Azadi_Square "Azadi Square") and Pahlavi street changed to [Valiasr street](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Valiasr_Street "Valiasr Street").[\[98\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-99) The metropolis of Tehran is equipped with a large network of highways and interchanges. ### Cars \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tehran&action=edit§ion=25 "Edit section: Cars")\] See also: [Automotive industry in Iran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automotive_industry_in_Iran "Automotive industry in Iran") According to the head of Tehran Municipality's Environment and Sustainable Development Office, Tehran was designed to have a capacity of about 300,000 cars, but more than five million cars are on the roads.[\[99\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-100) The automotive industry has recently developed, but international sanctions influence the production processes periodically.[\[100\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-101) According to local media, Tehran has more than 200,000 taxis plying the roads daily,[\[101\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-102) with several types of taxi available in the city. Airport taxis have a higher cost per kilometer as opposed to regular green and yellow taxis in the city. ### Buses \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tehran&action=edit§ion=26 "Edit section: Buses")\] See also: [Trolleybuses in Tehran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trolleybuses_in_Tehran "Trolleybuses in Tehran") and [Tehran Bus Rapid Transit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran_Bus_Rapid_Transit "Tehran Bus Rapid Transit") [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/BRT_in_Tehran%2C_Iran_%28cropped%29.jpg/250px-BRT_in_Tehran%2C_Iran_%28cropped%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:BRT_in_Tehran,_Iran_(cropped).jpg) [Tehran's bus rapid transit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran_Bus_Rapid_Transit "Tehran Bus Rapid Transit") Buses have served the city since the 1920s. Tehran's transport system includes conventional buses, [trolleybuses](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trolleybus "Trolleybus"), and [bus rapid transit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bus_rapid_transit "Bus rapid transit") (BRT). The city's four major bus stations include the South Terminal, the East Terminal, the West Terminal, and the northcentral Beyhaghi Terminal. The trolleybus system was opened in 1992, using a fleet of 65 [articulated](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Articulated_bus "Articulated bus") trolleybuses built by [Czech Republic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Czech_Republic "Czech Republic")'s [Škoda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C5%A0koda_Works "Škoda Works").[\[102\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-Murray-103) This was the first trolleybus system in Iran.[\[102\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-Murray-103) In 2005, trolleybuses were operating on five routes, all starting at [Imam Hossein Square](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imam_Hossein_Square "Imam Hossein Square").[\[103\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-tm265-104) Two routes running northeastwards operated almost entirely in a segregated [busway](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bus_Rapid_Transit "Bus Rapid Transit") located in the middle of the wide [carriageway](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carriageway "Carriageway") along [Damavand Street](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Damavand_Street "Damavand Street"), stopping only at purpose-built stops located about every 500 metres along the routes, effectively making these routes trolleybus-BRT (but they were not called such). The other three trolleybus routes ran south and operated in mixed traffic. Both route sections were served by [limited-stop](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Limited-stop "Limited-stop") services and local (making all stops) services.[\[103\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-tm265-104) A 3.2-kilometer extension from Shoosh Square to Rah Ahan Square was opened in March 2010.[\[104\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-tm298-105) Visitors in 2014 found that the trolleybus system had closed, apparently sometime in 2013.[\[105\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-haseldine-106) However, it reopened in March 2016, operating on a single 1.8-km route between Meydan-e-Khorasan (Khorasan Square) and Bozorgrah-e-Be'sat.[\[106\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-tm328-107)[\[107\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-trolleymotion-2016july-108) Around 30 vehicles had been refurbished and returned to service.[\[106\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-tm328-107)[\[107\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-trolleymotion-2016july-108) Extensions were planned.[\[107\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-trolleymotion-2016july-108) [Tehran's bus rapid transit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran_Bus_Rapid_Transit "Tehran Bus Rapid Transit") (BRT) was officially inaugurated in 2008. It has 10 lines with some 215 stations in different areas of the city. As of 2011[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tehran&action=edit), the BRT system had a network of 100 kilometres (62 miles), transporting 1.8 million passengers on a daily basis. ### Railway and subway \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tehran&action=edit§ion=27 "Edit section: Railway and subway")\] See also: [Iranian Railways](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Islamic_Republic_of_Iran_Railways "Islamic Republic of Iran Railways") and [Tehran Metro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran_Metro "Tehran Metro") [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/02_Tehran_Metro_Line_3_4.jpg/250px-02_Tehran_Metro_Line_3_4.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:02_Tehran_Metro_Line_3_4.jpg) [Tehran Metro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran_Metro "Tehran Metro") is the largest metro system in the Middle East Tehran has a [central railway station](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran_Railway_Station "Tehran Railway Station") that connects services round the clock to various cities in the country, along with a Tehran–Europe train line also running. The feasibility study and conceptual planning of the construction of Tehran's subway system were started in the 1970s. Metro Lines ### Airport \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tehran&action=edit§ion=28 "Edit section: Airport")\] See also: [Airlines of Iran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Airlines_of_Iran "Airlines of Iran") Tehran is served by the international airports of [Mehrabad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mehrabad_International_Airport "Mehrabad International Airport") and [Imam Khomeini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imam_Khomeini_International_Airport "Imam Khomeini International Airport"). Mehrabad Airport, an old airport in western Tehran that doubles as a military base, is mainly used for domestic and charter flights. Imam Khomeini Airport, located 50 kilometres (31 miles) south of the city, handles the main international flights. ### Parks and green spaces \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tehran&action=edit§ion=29 "Edit section: Parks and green spaces")\] See also: [List of Tehran metropolis parks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Tehran_metropolis_parks "List of Tehran metropolis parks") There are over 2,100 parks within the metropolis of Tehran,[\[119\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-irnamokh-120) with one of the oldest being [Jamshidie Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamshidieh_Park "Jamshidieh Park"), which was first established as a private garden for Qajar prince Jamshid Davallu, and was then dedicated to the last empress of Iran, [Farah Pahlavi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Farah_Pahlavi "Farah Pahlavi"). The total green space within Tehran stretches over 12,600 hectares, covering over 20 percent of the city's area. The Parks and Green Spaces Organization of Tehran was established in 1960, and is responsible for the protection of the urban nature present in the city.[\[120\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-121) Tehran's Birds Garden is the largest bird park in Iran. There is also [a zoo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eram_Zoo "Eram Zoo") located on the Tehran–Karaj Expressway, housing over 290 species within an area of about five hectares.[\[121\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-122) In 2009, the [Ab-o-Atash Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ab-o-Atash_Park "Ab-o-Atash Park") ("Water and Fire park") was founded. Its main features are an open [water fountain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Water_fountain "Water fountain") area for cooling in the hot climate, [fire towers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fire_tower "Fire tower"), and an [amphitheatre](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amphitheatre "Amphitheatre").[\[122\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-123) ### Energy \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tehran&action=edit§ion=30 "Edit section: Energy")\] See also: [Energy in Iran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Energy_in_Iran "Energy in Iran") #### Water \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tehran&action=edit§ion=31 "Edit section: Water")\] Fresh water resources of Tehran province in 2017 1. [Groundwater](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Groundwater "Groundwater") (37%) 2. [Sewage treatment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sewage_treatment "Sewage treatment") (63%) See also: [Water supply and sanitation in Iran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Water_supply_and_sanitation_in_Iran "Water supply and sanitation in Iran") [Greater Tehran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greater_Tehran "Greater Tehran") with its population of more than 13 million is supplied by surface water from the [Lar dam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lar_Dam "Lar Dam") on the [Lar River](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lar_River "Lar River") in the Northeast of the city, the [Latyan dam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latyan_Dam "Latyan Dam") on the [Jajrood River](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jajrood_River "Jajrood River") in the North, the [Karaj River](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karaj_River "Karaj River") in the Northwest, as well as by groundwater in the vicinity of the city. The city experiences [stark water supply inequalities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran_water_shortage_inequality "Tehran water shortage inequality"): impoverished districts struggle with inadequate water provision and hazardous water quality, while affluent areas are largely exempt from these hardships.[\[123\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-124) #### Solar energy \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tehran&action=edit§ion=32 "Edit section: Solar energy")\] Solar panels have been installed in Tehran's [Pardisan Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pardisan_Park "Pardisan Park") for green electricity production, said [Masoumeh Ebtekar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Masoumeh_Ebtekar "Masoumeh Ebtekar"), head of the Department of Environment. According to the national energy roadmap, the government plans to promote green technology to increase the nominal capacity of power plants from 74 gigawatts to over 120 gigawatts by the end of 2025.[\[124\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-125) ## Education \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tehran&action=edit§ion=33 "Edit section: Education")\] See also: [Education in Iran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Education_in_Iran "Education in Iran"), [List of colleges and universities in Tehran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_colleges_and_universities_in_Tehran "List of colleges and universities in Tehran"), and [Science in Iran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Science_in_Iran "Science in Iran") [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/University_of_Tehran_at_night_2021_%281%29.jpg/960px-University_of_Tehran_at_night_2021_%281%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:University_of_Tehran_at_night_2021_(1).jpg) The [University of Tehran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Tehran "University of Tehran") is the oldest modern university of Iran Tehran is the largest and most important educational center in Iran. There are a total of nearly 50 major colleges and universities in Greater Tehran. Since the establishment of [Dar ol Fonun](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dar_ul-Funun_(Persia) "Dar ul-Funun (Persia)") by the order of [Amir Kabir](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amir_Kabir "Amir Kabir") in the mid-19th century, Tehran has amassed a large number of institutions of higher education. Some of these institutions have played crucial roles in the unfolding of Iranian political events. [Samuel M. Jordan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Samuel_M._Jordan "Samuel M. Jordan"), whom Jordan Avenue in Tehran was named after, was one of the founding pioneers of the [American College of Tehran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alborz_High_School "Alborz High School"), which was one of the first modern high schools in the Middle East. Among major educational institutions located in Tehran, [Amirkabir University of Technology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amirkabir_University_of_Technology "Amirkabir University of Technology") (Tehran Polytechnic), [University of Tehran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Tehran "University of Tehran"), [Sharif University of Technology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sharif_University_of_Technology "Sharif University of Technology"), and [Tehran University of Medical Sciences](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran_University_of_Medical_Sciences "Tehran University of Medical Sciences") are the most prestigious. Other major universities located in Tehran include [Tehran University of Art](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran_University_of_Art "Tehran University of Art"), [Allameh Tabatabaei University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allameh_Tabatabaei_University "Allameh Tabatabaei University"), [K. N. Toosi University of Technology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/K._N._Toosi_University_of_Technology "K. N. Toosi University of Technology"), [Shahid Beheshti University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shahid_Beheshti_University "Shahid Beheshti University") (Melli University), [Kharazmi University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kharazmi_University "Kharazmi University"), [Iran University of Medical Sciences](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iran_University_of_Medical_Sciences "Iran University of Medical Sciences"), [Islamic Azad University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Islamic_Azad_University "Islamic Azad University"), [International Institute of Earthquake Engineering and Seismology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Institute_of_Earthquake_Engineering_and_Seismology "International Institute of Earthquake Engineering and Seismology"), Iran's Polymer and Petrochemical Institute, [Shahed University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shahed_University "Shahed University"), and [Tarbiat Modarres University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tarbiat_Modarres_University "Tarbiat Modarres University"). [Sharif University of Technology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sharif_University_of_Technology "Sharif University of Technology"), [Amirkabir University of Technology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amirkabir_University_of_Technology "Amirkabir University of Technology"), [Iran University of Science and Technology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iran_University_of_Science_and_Technology "Iran University of Science and Technology") and [K. N. Toosi University of Technology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/K._N._Toosi_University_of_Technology "K. N. Toosi University of Technology") also located in Tehran is nationally well known for taking in the top undergraduate Engineering and Science students; and internationally recognized for training competent undergraduate students. It has probably the highest percentage of graduates who seek higher education abroad. Tehran is also home to Iran's largest military academy, and several religious schools and seminaries. ## Culture \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tehran&action=edit§ion=34 "Edit section: Culture")\] Main article: [Culture of Tehran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Culture_of_Tehran "Culture of Tehran") The [culture of Tehran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Culture_of_Tehran "Culture of Tehran") concerns the arts, music, museums, festivals, many [Persian entertainments](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Persian_Culture "Persian Culture") and sports activities in Tehran, the capital city of Iran. [Iranian festivals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iranian_Festivals "Iranian Festivals") are held in Tehran along with regional and western festivals. [Nowruz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nowruz "Nowruz"), [Chaharshanbe Suri](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chaharshanbe_Suri "Chaharshanbe Suri"), [Sizdah Be-dar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sizdah_Be-dar "Sizdah Be-dar"), [Yaldā Night](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yald%C4%81_Night "Yaldā Night"), [Valentine's Day](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Valentine%27s_Day "Valentine's Day") and [Halloween](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Halloween "Halloween") have been popular festivals in recent decades.[\[125\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-Tehran_Culture-126) ### Architecture \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tehran&action=edit§ion=35 "Edit section: Architecture")\] See also: [Architecture of Tehran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Architecture_of_Tehran "Architecture of Tehran") The oldest surviving architectural monuments of Tehran are from the [Qajar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qajar_dynasty "Qajar dynasty") and [Pahlavi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pahlavi_dynasty "Pahlavi dynasty") eras. In Greater Tehran, monuments dating back to the [Seljuk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seljuk_Empire "Seljuk Empire") era remain as well; notably the [Toqrol Tower](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tughrul_Tower "Tughrul Tower") in Ray. [Rashkan Castle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rashkan_Castle "Rashkan Castle"), dating back to the ancient [Parthian Empire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parthian_Empire "Parthian Empire"), of which some artifacts are housed at the [National Museum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Museum_of_Iran "National Museum of Iran");[\[126\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-127) and the [Bahram fire temple](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bahram_fire_temple "Bahram fire temple"), which remains since the [Sassanian Empire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sasanian_Empire "Sasanian Empire"). Tehran only had a small population until the late 18th century but began to take a more considerable role in Iranian society after it was chosen as the capital city. Despite the regular occurrence of earthquakes during the Qajar period and after, some historic buildings remain from that era.[\[127\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-128) Tehran is Iran's [primate city](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Primate_city "Primate city"), and is considered to have the most modernized infrastructure in the country. However, the [gentrification](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gentrification "Gentrification") of old neighbourhoods and the demolition of buildings of cultural significance have caused concerns.[\[128\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-129) - [![Hasanabad Square](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/02_hasan_abad_Sq..jpg/960px-02_hasan_abad_Sq..jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:02_hasan_abad_Sq..jpg "Hasanabad Square") [Hasanabad Square](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hasanabad,_Tehran "Hasanabad, Tehran") - [![A view of the building of the City Theater of Tehran](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Tehran_City_Theater_1.jpg/960px-Tehran_City_Theater_1.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Tehran_City_Theater_1.jpg "A view of the building of the City Theater of Tehran") A view of the building of the [City Theater of Tehran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/City_Theater_of_Tehran "City Theater of Tehran") - [![Police House, the National Garden](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Iranian_Foreign_Affaire_Ministry.jpg/250px-Iranian_Foreign_Affaire_Ministry.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Iranian_Foreign_Affaire_Ministry.jpg "Police House, the National Garden") Police House, the [National Garden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Garden,_Tehran "National Garden, Tehran") Previously a low-rise city due to seismic activity in the region, modern high-rise developments in Tehran have been built in recent decades in order to service its growing population. There have been no major quakes in Tehran since 1830.[\[129\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-130) [Tehran International Tower](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran_International_Tower "Tehran International Tower") is the tallest skyscraper in Iran. It is 54-stories tall and located in the northern district of [Yusef Abad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yusef_Abad "Yusef Abad"). The [Azadi Tower](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Azadi_Tower "Azadi Tower"), a memorial built under the reign of the [Pahlavi dynasty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pahlavi_dynasty "Pahlavi dynasty"), has long been the most famous symbol of Tehran. Originally constructed in commemoration of the [2,500th year of the foundation of the Imperial State of Iran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2,500-year_celebration_of_the_Persian_Empire "2,500-year celebration of the Persian Empire"), it combines elements of the architecture of the [Achaemenid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Achaemenid_architecture "Achaemenid architecture") and [Sassanid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sassanid_architecture "Sassanid architecture") eras with post-classical [Iranian architecture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iranian_architecture "Iranian architecture"). The [Milad Tower](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milad_Tower "Milad Tower"), which is the [sixth tallest tower](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_towers "List of towers")[\[130\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-NBN_Nasl_Bartar_Novin-131) and the [24th-tallest freestanding structure](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_tallest_buildings_and_structures#Tallest_structures,_freestanding_structures,_and_buildings "List of tallest buildings and structures") in the world,[\[131\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-132) is the city's other famous landmark tower. [Leila Araghian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leila_Araghian "Leila Araghian")'s [Tabiat Bridge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tabiat_Bridge "Tabiat Bridge"), the largest pedestrian overpass in Tehran, was completed in 2014 and is also considered a landmark.[\[12\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-archdaily-12) ### Fashion and clothing \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tehran&action=edit§ion=36 "Edit section: Fashion and clothing")\] See also: [Fashion in Iran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fashion_in_Iran "Fashion in Iran") and [Women's rights in Iran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Women%27s_rights_in_Iran "Women's rights in Iran") The city has produced many notable Iranian design houses and clothing companies. Fashion events are also held in some areas of the city.[\[132\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-133) Many famous Iranian models were born in Tehran, including [Nazanin Afshin-Jam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nazanin_Afshin-Jam "Nazanin Afshin-Jam"), [Cameron Alborzian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cameron_Alborzian "Cameron Alborzian"), [Sahar Biniaz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sahar_Biniaz "Sahar Biniaz"), Elnaaz Norouzi, [Shermine Shahrivar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shermine_Shahrivar "Shermine Shahrivar") and [Sadaf Taherian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sadaf_Taherian "Sadaf Taherian"). Women of Tehran widely used over-the-knee and leather boots after 2000s.[\[133\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-134) ### Theater \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tehran&action=edit§ion=37 "Edit section: Theater")\] [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/RudakiHall.jpg/250px-RudakiHall.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:RudakiHall.jpg) The [Vahdat Hall](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vahdat_Hall "Vahdat Hall"), Tehran Under the reign of the [Qajars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qajar_dynasty "Qajar dynasty"), Tehran was home to the royal theatre of [Tekye Dowlat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tekyeh_Dowlat "Tekyeh Dowlat"), located to the southeast of the [Golestan Palace](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Golestan_Palace "Golestan Palace"), in which traditional and religious performances were observed. It was eventually demolished and replaced with a bank building in 1947, following the reforms during the reign of [Reza Shah](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reza_Shah "Reza Shah"). Before the 1979 Revolution, the Iranian national stage had become the most famous performing scene for known international artists and troupes in the Middle East,[\[134\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-135) with the Vahdat Hall, formerly known as Rudaki Hall, constructed to function as the national stage for opera and ballet. The hall was inaugurated in October 1967 and named after prominent Persian poet [Rudaki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rudaki "Rudaki"). It is home to the [Tehran Symphony Orchestra](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran_Symphony_Orchestra "Tehran Symphony Orchestra"), the Tehran Opera Orchestra, and the [Iranian National Ballet Company](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iranian_National_Ballet_Company "Iranian National Ballet Company"). The [City Theater of Tehran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/City_Theater_of_Tehran "City Theater of Tehran"), one of Iran's biggest theatre complexes, which contains several performance halls, was opened in 1972. It was built at the initiative and presidency of empress [Farah Pahlavi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Farah_Pahlavi "Farah Pahlavi"), and was designed by architect Ali Sardar Afkhami, constructed within five years. One of the gathering centers of [cabarets](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cabaret "Cabaret") in old Tehran was [Laleh-Zar Street](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laleh-Zar_Street "Laleh-Zar Street"). Famous Persian cabarets were active in the city until 1979. They also introduced many domestic artists. In common language, cabaret was sometimes called "home of dance" or "dancing place".[\[135\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-136) The annual events of [Fajr Theater Festival](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fajr_International_Theater_Festival "Fajr International Theater Festival") and [Tehran Puppet Theater Festival](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran_International_Puppet_Theatre_Festival "Tehran International Puppet Theatre Festival") take place in Tehran. ### Cinema \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tehran&action=edit§ion=38 "Edit section: Cinema")\] The first movie theater in Tehran was established by [Mirza Ebrahim Khan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mirza_Ebrahim_Khan_Sahhafbashi "Mirza Ebrahim Khan Sahhafbashi") in 1904.[\[136\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-137) Until the early 1930s, there were 15 theaters in Tehran province and 11 in other provinces.[\[137\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-138) In present-day Tehran, most of the movie theatres are located downtown. The complexes of [Kourosh Cinema](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kourosh_Complex&action=edit&redlink=1 "Kourosh Complex (page does not exist)"), [Mellat Gallery and Cineplex](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mellat_Park "Mellat Park"), [Azadi Cinema](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Azadi_Cinema_Complex "Azadi Cinema Complex"), and [Cinema Farhang](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cinema_Farhang "Cinema Farhang") are among the most popular cinema complexes in Tehran. Several film festivals are held in Tehran, including [Fajr Film Festival](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fajr_International_Film_Festival "Fajr International Film Festival"), [Children and Youth Film Festival](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Film_Festival_for_Children_and_Youth "International Film Festival for Children and Youth"), House of Cinema Festival, Mobile Film and Photo Festival, Nahal Festival, [Roshd Film Festival](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roshd_International_Film_Festival "Roshd International Film Festival"), Tehran Animation Festival, Tehran Short Film Festival, and Urban Film Festival. ### Music and dance \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tehran&action=edit§ion=39 "Edit section: Music and dance")\] There are a variety of concert halls in Tehran. An organization like the Roudaki Culture and Art Foundation has five different venues where more than 500 concerts take place this year. [Vahdat Hall](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vahdat_Hall "Vahdat Hall"), [Roudaki Hall](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roudaki_Hall "Roudaki Hall"), Ferdowsi Hall, Hafez Hall and Azadi Theater are the top five venues in Tehran, where classical, pop, traditional, rock or solo concerts take place.[\[138\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-139) [Erotic dancers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Erotic_dance "Erotic dance") were active and trained in Tehran until the 1979 revolution. But after this date, due to the policies of the new government, these activities were completely banned.[\[125\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-Tehran_Culture-126) ### Sports \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tehran&action=edit§ion=40 "Edit section: Sports")\] See also: [Sport in Iran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sport_in_Iran "Sport in Iran") Football and volleyball are the city's most popular sports, while wrestling, basketball, and futsal are also major parts of the city's sporting culture. Ice hockey and rugby are also popular in Tehran. [12 ski resorts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_ski_areas_and_resorts_in_Iran "List of ski areas and resorts in Iran") operate in Iran, the most famous being [Tochal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tochal_Complex "Tochal Complex"), [Dizin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dizin "Dizin"), and [Shemshak](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shemshak_(ski_resort) "Shemshak (ski resort)"), all within one to three hours from the city of Tehran. [Tochal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tochal "Tochal")'s resort is the world's fifth-highest ski resort at over 3,730 meters (12,240 feet) above sea level at its highest point. It is also the world's nearest ski resort to a capital city. The resort was opened in 1976, shortly before the 1979 Revolution. It is equipped with an 8-kilometre-long (5 mi) gondola lift that covers a huge vertical distance.[\[139\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-140) There are two parallel chair ski lifts in Tochal that reach 3,900 meters (12,800 feet) high near Tochal's peak (at 4,000 m/13,000 ft), rising higher than the gondola's seventh station, which is higher than any of the European ski resorts. From the Tochal peak, there are views of the [Alborz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alborz "Alborz") range, including the 5,610-metre-high (18,406 ft) [Mount Damavand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mount_Damavand "Mount Damavand"), a dormant volcano. Tehran is the site of the [national stadium of Azadi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Azadi_Stadium "Azadi Stadium"), the [biggest stadium by capacity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_stadiums_by_capacity "List of stadiums by capacity") in West Asia, where many of the top matches of Iran's Premier League are held. The stadium is a part of the [Azadi Sport Complex](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Azadi_Sport_Complex "Azadi Sport Complex"), which was originally built to host the [7th Asian Games](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1974_Asian_Games "1974 Asian Games") in September 1974. This was the first time the Asian Games were hosted in West Asia. Tehran played host to 3,010 athletes from 25 countries/NOCs, which was at the time the highest number of participants since the inception of the Games.[\[140\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-141) That followed hosting the [6th AFC Asian Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1976_AFC_Asian_Cup "1976 AFC Asian Cup") in June 1976, and then the first [West Asian Games](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/West_Asian_Games "West Asian Games") in November 1997. The success of the games led to the creation of the [West Asian Games Federation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/West_Asian_Games "West Asian Games") (WAGF), and the intention of hosting the games every two years.[\[141\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-142) The city had also hosted the final of the [1968 AFC Asian Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1968_AFC_Asian_Cup "1968 AFC Asian Cup"). Several [FIVB Volleyball World League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FIVB_Volleyball_World_League "FIVB Volleyball World League") courses have also been hosted in Tehran. - [![Tehran derby in Azadi Stadium. The match is considered one of the world's most intense derbies.](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Esteghlal_Edges_Past_Persepolis_3-2_to_Claim_Tehran_Derby-33.jpg/541px-Esteghlal_Edges_Past_Persepolis_3-2_to_Claim_Tehran_Derby-33.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Esteghlal_Edges_Past_Persepolis_3-2_to_Claim_Tehran_Derby-33.jpg "Tehran derby in Azadi Stadium. The match is considered one of the world's most intense derbies.") [Tehran derby](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran_derby "Tehran derby") in [Azadi Stadium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Azadi_Stadium "Azadi Stadium"). The match is considered one of the world's most intense derbies. - [![Iran's ice hockey league in Tehran](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Iran_men%27s_ice_hockey_league_in_Tehran.jpg/960px-Iran_men%27s_ice_hockey_league_in_Tehran.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Iran_men%27s_ice_hockey_league_in_Tehran.jpg "Iran's ice hockey league in Tehran") [Iran's ice hockey league](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ice_hockey_in_Iran "Ice hockey in Iran") in Tehran - [![Dizin, Iran's largest ski resort, is located near Tehran.](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Dizin%2C_Iran.jpeg/540px-Dizin%2C_Iran.jpeg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Dizin,_Iran.jpeg "Dizin, Iran's largest ski resort, is located near Tehran.") [Dizin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dizin "Dizin"), Iran's largest ski resort, is located near Tehran. ### Food \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tehran&action=edit§ion=41 "Edit section: Food")\] See also: [Iranian cuisine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iranian_cuisine "Iranian cuisine") There are many restaurants and cafes in Tehran, both modern and classic, serving both Iranian and cosmopolitan cuisine. Pizzerias, [sandwich bars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sandwich_bar "Sandwich bar"), and kebab shops make up the majority of food shops in Tehran.[\[142\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-143) ### Graffiti \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tehran&action=edit§ion=42 "Edit section: Graffiti")\] Main article: [Graffiti in Tehran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graffiti_in_Tehran "Graffiti in Tehran") Many styles of graffiti are seen in Tehran. Some are political and revolutionary slogans painted by governmental organizations,[\[143\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-graff-144) and some are works of art by ordinary citizens, representing their views on both social and political issues. However, unsanctioned street art is forbidden in Iran,[\[143\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-graff-144) and such works are usually short-lived. During the [2009 Iranian presidential election protests](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_Iranian_presidential_election_protests "2009 Iranian presidential election protests"), many graffiti works were created by people supporting the [Green Movement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iranian_Green_Movement "Iranian Green Movement"). They were removed from the walls by the paramilitary [Basij](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Basij "Basij") forces.[\[144\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-145) In recent years, Tehran Municipality has been using graffiti in order to beautify the city. Several graffiti festivals have also taken place in Tehran, including the one organized by the [Tehran University of Art](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran_University_of_Art "Tehran University of Art") in October 2014.[\[145\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran#cite_note-146) ## Twin towns – sister cities \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tehran&action=edit§ion=43 "Edit section: Twin towns – sister cities")\] See also: [List of twin towns and sister cities in Iran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_twin_towns_and_sister_cities_in_Iran "List of twin towns and sister cities in Iran") | | | | --- | --- | | [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/60px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg) | This section **needs additional citations for [verification](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")**. NBA Finals - Game 5

OKC leads series 3-2

![Pacers](https://a.espncdn.com/combiner/i?img=/i/teamlogos/nba/500-dark/scoreboard/ind.png&cquality=80&h=256&w=256)

[**Indiana Pacers**](https://www.espn.com/nba/team/_/name/ind/indiana-pacers)

50-32, 20-20 away

109

Final

|  | 1 | 2 | 3 | 4 | T |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| IND | 22 | 23 | 34 | 30 | 109 |
| OKC | 32 | 27 | 28 | 33 | 120 |

![Thunder](https://a.espncdn.com/combiner/i?img=/i/teamlogos/nba/500-dark/scoreboard/okc.png&cquality=80&h=256&w=256)

[**Oklahoma City Thunder**](https://www.espn.com/nba/team/_/name/okc/oklahoma-city-thunder)

68-14, 35-6 home

120Winner Icon Oklahoma City Thunder

ByAP

Jun 16, 2025, 07:02 pm

FacebookFacebook MessengerTwitterEmail

OKLAHOMA CITY -- — Game 5 was starting to look like Game 1 all over again. Oklahoma City, at home, takes a huge lead. Indiana comes roaring back in the fourth quarter.

Indiana won that one.

This time, the Thunder crafted a different ending — and a 3-2 lead in the NBA Finals was their reward.

[Jalen Williams](http://www.espn.com/nba/player/_/id/4593803/jalen-williams) scored a career playoff-high 40 points, MVP [Shai Gilgeous-Alexander](http://www.espn.com/nba/player/_/id/4278073/shai-gilgeous-alexander) added 31 and the Thunder moved one win from a title by beating the Pacers 120-109 on Monday night.

“We're learning,” said Williams, whose previous playoff best was 34.

It was the 10th — and by far, the biggest — time the Thunder stars combined for more than 70 points in a game. Williams was 14 of 24 from the field, and Gilgeous-Alexander added 10 assists.

“It wasn't a perfect game at all and there's a lot of room for growth,” Thunder coach Mark Daigneault said. “But our improvement from Game 4 to Game 5 was critical.”

[Pascal Siakam](http://www.espn.com/nba/player/_/id/3149673/pascal-siakam) had 28 points for Indiana, which will host Game 6 on Thursday night. TJ McConnell added 18 for the Pacers, who whittled an 18-point deficit down to two in the fourth — then watched the Thunder pull away again, and for good.

“It kind of went away from us,” Siakam said. “But the fight was there.”

It was, but now everything favors the Thunder.

Teams that win Game 5 of an NBA Finals that was tied at 2-2 have gone on to win the series 23 times in 31 previous opportunities, or 74%. And teams with a 3-2 lead in the finals have won 40 times in 49 previous opportunities, or 82%.

But Game 5 was not easy. Far from it.

Down by 18 late in the second quarter, the Pacers — the comeback kings of these playoffs, with as many wins in this postseason from 15 points down or more (five) than the rest of the league has combined, including in Game 1 of this series — did what they do, chipping away. And they did it with [Tyrese Haliburton](http://www.espn.com/nba/player/_/id/4396993/tyrese-haliburton) reduced to basically playing decoy on offense because of a leg issue that he aggravated in the first quarter.

“He's not 100%,” Pacers coach Rick Carlisle said. “It's pretty clear.”

Led by McConnell, who scored 13 points in just under seven minutes of the third, the Pacers got within five late in that quarter.

Then, Siakam went to work — a pair of free throws with 9:19 left got Indiana within four, then a 3-pointer about a minute later made it 95-93. In the play-by-play era of the NBA, starting with the 1997 playoffs, teams with leads of 15 points or more in the finals were 80-9.

Make that 81-9 now, and the Thunder are one win away from giving Oklahoma City its first NBA title.

“That was honestly the same exact game as Game 1,” Williams said. “Learning through these finals, that's what makes a team good.”

One more win, and his team will be certified as great.

​
(m. 1979)​ | **Patricia Mary** " **Kim**" **Woodburn** ([née](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Birth_name#Maiden_and_married_names "Birth name") **McKenzie**; 25 March 1942 – 16 June 2025) was an English television personality, writer, and expert cleaner. Known as the "Queen of Clean", she came to prominence by co-presenting the [Channel 4](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Channel_4 "Channel 4") series _[How Clean Is Your House?](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/How_Clean_Is_Your_House%3F "How Clean Is Your House?")_ (2003–2009) and its Canadian version _Kim's Rude Awakenings_ (2007–2009). Woodburn went on to appear on various reality television shows, including _[I'm a Celebrity...Get Me Out of Here!](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/I%27m_a_Celebrity...Get_Me_Out_of_Here! "I'm a Celebrity...Get Me Out of Here!")_ (2009) and _[Celebrity Big Brother](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Celebrity_Big_Brother_(British_TV_series) "Celebrity Big Brother (British TV series)")_ (2017). ## Early life \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kim_Woodburn&action=edit§ion=1 "Edit section: Early life")\] Patricia Mary McKenzie was born in [Eastney](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eastney "Eastney"), [Hampshire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hampshire "Hampshire") on 25 March 1942 to Mary Patricia ( _née_ Shaw) and Ronald McKenzie.[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Woodburn#cite_note-Unbeaten-1) Woodburn says that she was physically abused by her parents throughout her childhood, and sexually abused by her father.[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Woodburn#cite_note-Unbeaten-1) She left home at the age of 16 and moved to [Liverpool](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liverpool "Liverpool") where she worked as a live-in cleaner for a family.[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Woodburn#cite_note-Liverpool-2) Besides being a professional cleaner, Woodburn also held other jobs such as [social worker](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_worker "Social worker"), [beautician](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beautician "Beautician") and [model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model_(person) "Model (person)").[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Woodburn#cite_note-3) In February 1966, when she was 23 years old, Woodburn prematurely gave birth to a stillborn son and buried him in a park.[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Woodburn#cite_note-Unbeaten-1) This revelation, which she made in her 2006 autobiography, _Unbeaten_, led to a police inquiry, but no action was taken.[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Woodburn#cite_note-Liverpool-2) After the death of her baby, she changed her name from Patricia to Kim, after the American actress and painter [Kim Novak](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Novak "Kim Novak").[\[4\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Woodburn#cite_note-BBC-4) ## Career \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kim_Woodburn&action=edit§ion=2 "Edit section: Career")\] ### _How Clean Is Your House?_ \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kim_Woodburn&action=edit§ion=3 "Edit section: How Clean Is Your House?")\] In 2002, [Channel 4](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Channel_4 "Channel 4") contacted a cleaning company looking for "a really good cleaner with quite a funny temperament for a new series."[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Woodburn#cite_note-Belfast-5) The company recommended Woodburn, who was working as a live-in cleaner for a family in [Kent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kent "Kent").[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Woodburn#cite_note-Belfast-5) After a screen test, programme makers paired her with [Aggie MacKenzie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aggie_MacKenzie "Aggie MacKenzie") and filming began three weeks later.[\[6\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Woodburn#cite_note-6)[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Woodburn#cite_note-7) _[How Clean Is Your House?](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/How_Clean_Is_Your_House%3F "How Clean Is Your House?")_ aired from 2003 to 2009, with the duo producing books, board games and DVDs due to the popularity of the series.[\[8\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Woodburn#cite_note-Metro-8) Woodburn appeared on _[The Oprah Winfrey Show](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Oprah_Winfrey_Show "The Oprah Winfrey Show")_ in the US, where _How Clean Is Your House?_ aired on [BBC America](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BBC_America "BBC America").[\[9\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Woodburn#cite_note-9) From 2007 to 2009, Woodburn starred in a Canadian version, titled _Kim's Rude Awakenings_, alongside Mike Chalut.[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Woodburn#cite_note-BBC1-10) In August 2009, Woodburn announced to _[Now](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Now_(UK_magazine) "Now (UK magazine)")_ magazine that she would not be making any further series of _How Clean Is Your House?_ and Channel 4 announced soon afterwards that the series had been cancelled.[\[11\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Woodburn#cite_note-Now-11)[\[12\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Woodburn#cite_note-12) ### Television appearances \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kim_Woodburn&action=edit§ion=4 "Edit section: Television appearances")\] In November 2009, Woodburn was announced as a contestant for the [ninth series](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/I%27m_a_Celebrity...Get_Me_Out_of_Here!_(British_series_9) "I'm a Celebrity...Get Me Out of Here! (British series 9)") of _[I'm a Celebrity...Get Me Out of Here!](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/I%27m_a_Celebrity...Get_Me_Out_of_Here! "I'm a Celebrity...Get Me Out of Here!")_. She finished as runner-up to [Gino D'Acampo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gino_D%27Acampo "Gino D'Acampo").[\[13\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Woodburn#cite_note-13) In March 2010, she appeared on _[Celebrity Come Dine with Me](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Come_Dine_with_Me "Come Dine with Me")_ on Channel 4 alongside [Claire Sweeney](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Claire_Sweeney "Claire Sweeney"), [Darren Day](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Darren_Day "Darren Day") and [Tom O'Connor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tom_O%27Connor_(comedian) "Tom O'Connor (comedian)").[\[14\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Woodburn#cite_note-14) In 2011, Woodburn became a regular panellist on the _[Big Brother](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_Brother_2011_(UK) "Big Brother 2011 (UK)")_ spin-off series, _[Big Brother's Bit on the Side](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_Brother%27s_Bit_on_the_Side "Big Brother's Bit on the Side")_. In November 2011, she entered the house to set a shopping task which she also judged, while berating the housemates for their hygiene.[\[15\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Woodburn#cite_note-15) In February 2013, Woodburn teamed up with chef [Rosemary Shrager](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rosemary_Shrager "Rosemary Shrager"), and the pair appeared on the fifth series of _[Let's Dance for Comic Relief](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Let%27s_Dance_for_Comic_Relief "Let's Dance for Comic Relief")_ as contestants. They danced to " [Diamonds Are a Girl's Best Friend](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diamonds_Are_a_Girl%27s_Best_Friend "Diamonds Are a Girl's Best Friend")" by [Marilyn Monroe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marilyn_Monroe "Marilyn Monroe"). They were eliminated by the panel of judges.[\[16\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Woodburn#cite_note-16) In 2014, Woodburn appeared as a contestant on an episode of _[The Chase](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Chase_(UK_game_show) "The Chase (UK game show)")_ Celebrity Specials.[\[17\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Woodburn#cite_note-17) In March 2016, Woodburn took part in the second series of _Famous, Rich and Homeless_ for [BBC One](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BBC_One "BBC One"). Her controversial comments on the lives of rough sleepers and some of them that she met led to a dispute between her, the public and the other volunteers on the show.[\[18\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Woodburn#cite_note-18) In April 2016, Woodburn and her husband, Pete, appeared on Channel 4's _[A Place in the Sun: Winter Sun](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A_Place_in_the_Sun_(British_TV_series) "A Place in the Sun (British TV series)")_ in order to find a holiday home in Costa del Sol, which was to be their home during the winter months. Their budget was £320,000 and they were shown five two-three bedroom penthouses.[\[19\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Woodburn#cite_note-19) They put two offers forward of £285,000 and then £295,000 on an apartment but both were turned down by the Norwegian owner.[\[20\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Woodburn#cite_note-20) In January 2017, Woodburn entered the _[Celebrity Big Brother](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Celebrity_Big_Brother_(British_TV_series) "Celebrity Big Brother (British TV series)")_ house to participate as a housemate in its [nineteenth series](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Celebrity_Big_Brother_(British_series_19) "Celebrity Big Brother (British series 19)"), entering on Day 11. During her time in the house, Woodburn was involved in conflicts with several of her fellow housemates, one incident of which required security to enter the house.[\[21\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Woodburn#cite_note-21) She gained notoriety for her outbursts, several of which featured Woodburn referring to her housemates as "ganghanded" and "chicken-livered".[\[22\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Woodburn#cite_note-22) She finished in third place on Day 32.[\[23\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Woodburn#cite_note-23) In August 2018, Woodburn made a controversial appearance on [ITV](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ITV_(TV_network) "ITV (TV network)")'s _[Loose Women](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Loose_Women "Loose Women")_. She was asked if she would make amends with [Coleen Nolan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coleen_Nolan "Coleen Nolan") (who she fell out with after they both appeared on _Celebrity Big Brother_), but left after a reception by the panel that was widely described as "bullying". The incident resulted in almost 8,000 people complaining to [Ofcom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ofcom "Ofcom").[\[24\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Woodburn#cite_note-24) In 2021, Woodburn featured in a Christmas advert for Grainger Market Delivery, an online shopping company.[\[25\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Woodburn#cite_note-25) In 2022, Woodburn made various guest appearances on [GB News](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GB_News "GB News") and was a contestant on the [E4](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E4_(TV_channel) "E4 (TV channel)") cooking competition _[Celeb Cooking School](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Celeb_Cooking_School "Celeb Cooking School")_, where she was eliminated first.[\[26\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Woodburn#cite_note-26) ### Other ventures \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kim_Woodburn&action=edit§ion=5 "Edit section: Other ventures")\] In 2006, Woodburn wrote an autobiography, _Unbeaten_, which detailed her early life.[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Woodburn#cite_note-Unbeaten-1) She went on to appear in various pantomimes in theatres all over the UK. Her first pantomime performance was in the _Cinderella_ as an Ugly Sister, alongside television co-star Aggie MacKenzie, at the [Theatre Royal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theatre_Royal,_Brighton "Theatre Royal, Brighton") in [Brighton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brighton "Brighton"). It ran from 7 December 2007 to 6 January 2008.[\[27\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Woodburn#cite_note-27) From 15 December 2010 to 3 January 2011, she made her second appearance in pantomime in _Cinderella_ at the [Woodville Halls Theatre](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Woodville_Halls_Theatre "Woodville Halls Theatre") in [Gravesend](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gravesend "Gravesend"), where played the Fairy Godmother. [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Kim_Woodburn_branded_pink_cleaning_merchandise_at_Poundland.jpg/330px-Kim_Woodburn_branded_pink_cleaning_merchandise_at_Poundland.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Kim_Woodburn_branded_pink_cleaning_merchandise_at_Poundland.jpg) Woodburn's cleaning products at [Poundland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poundland "Poundland") From 11 to 26 December 2012, Woodburn played the Wicked Stepmother in _Cinderella_ at the [Grimsby Auditorium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grimsby_Auditorium "Grimsby Auditorium").[\[28\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Woodburn#cite_note-28) She performed in pantomime for the fourth time at the [Southport Theatre](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southport_Theatre "Southport Theatre") in _Jack and the Beanstalk_ as Fairy Starlight. The season ran from 13 December 2013 to 31 December 2013. From 2014 to 2015, she played Fairy Liquid in _Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs_ at [The Brindley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Brindley "The Brindley") in [Runcorn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Runcorn "Runcorn"), followed by a 2018 appearance at the [Epstein Theatre](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epstein_Theatre "Epstein Theatre") in [Liverpool](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liverpool "Liverpool") as the Wicked Queen in _Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs_.[\[29\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Woodburn#cite_note-29) In 2022, Woodburn released a range of cleaning products at [Poundland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poundland "Poundland").[\[30\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Woodburn#cite_note-30) In February 2025, Woodburn was interviewed by drag queen Belinda Scandal for a one-off "In Conversation With: Kim Woodburn" show at [The Lowry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Lowry "The Lowry"), in which she spoke about her life and career.[\[31\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Woodburn#cite_note-31) ## Personal life and death \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kim_Woodburn&action=edit§ion=6 "Edit section: Personal life and death")\] Woodburn's first marriage to Kenneth Davies ended in divorce in 1975.[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Woodburn#cite_note-Unbeaten-1) She married Peter Woodburn in 1979 and they lived together in [Nantwich](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nantwich "Nantwich"), [Cheshire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cheshire "Cheshire").[\[32\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Woodburn#cite_note-32)[\[33\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Woodburn#cite_note-33) They had no children.[\[34\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Woodburn#cite_note-34) Woodburn's tight braided bun hair style was described as her "trademark" by [BBC One](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BBC_One "BBC One").[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Woodburn#cite_note-BBC1-10) Woodburn died on 16 June 2025 at the age of 83, following a short illness.[\[35\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Woodburn#cite_note-35) Her death was announced the following day by her management, who described her as an "incredibly kind, caring, charismatic and strong person", adding that her husband was "heartbroken at the loss of his soulmate".[\[36\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Woodburn#cite_note-36) ## ![Najmul Hossain Shanto and Mushfiqur Rahim centuries deflated Sri Lanka, Sri Lanka vs Bangladesh, 1st Test, Galle, first day, June 17, 2025](https://img1.hscicdn.com/image/upload/f_auto,t_ds_wide_w_1280,q_70/lsci/db/PICTURES/CMS/402200/402249.6.jpg)

Najmul Hossain Shanto and Mushfiqur Rahim's centuries deflated Sri Lanka  •  Associated Press

_**Bangladesh** 292 for 3 (Shanto 136\*, Mushfiqur 105\*, Tharindu 2-124) vs **Sri Lanka**_

The first hour or so of play on the opening day of the Galle Test belonged to [Sri Lanka](https://www.espncricinfo.com/team/sri-lanka-8). But after that, it was all [Bangladesh](https://www.espncricinfo.com/team/bangladesh-25), as [Najmul Hossain Shanto](https://www.espncricinfo.com/cricketers/najmul-hossain-shanto-629058) and [Mushfiqur Rahim](https://www.espncricinfo.com/cricketers/mushfiqur-rahim-56029) struck centuries during an unbroken stand of 247, to seize control of day one.

By stumps, Shanto was unbeaten on 136 and had Mushfiqur right behind him on 105 not out. Seamer [Milan Rathnayake](https://www.espncricinfo.com/cricketers/milan-rathnayake-1070229) was the most economical of the Sri Lanka bowlers, his 12 overs going for just 19 runs, but the bulk of the overs were bowled by the spin pair of [Prabath Jayasuriya](https://www.espncricinfo.com/cricketers/prabath-jayasuriya-422871) and debutant [Tharindu Rathnayake](https://www.espncricinfo.com/cricketers/tharindu-rathnayake-950405). The wickets were split between Asitha Fernando and debutant Tharindu, but once Shanto and Mushfiqur were set, Sri Lanka rarely caused them trouble.

Winning the toss and opting to bat is usually the obvious call in Galle, but this time in particular, with conditions more favourable than usual for batters, Shanto was rightfully chuffed when the toss fell his way. That smile though, had become closer to a grimace when he stood at the non-striker's end watching a third Bangladeshi batter fall with not even 50 on the board.

When Mushfiqur walked out to join him, Shanto himself had faced just three deliveries; it took him only until his sixth though to show that he would not be cowed by the situation, skipping down the track and smoking one back over Tharindu's head. That set the tone, if not outright aggression and displayed resolute confidence.

Tharindu had at that point been building up a head of steam. Mominul Haque had gone after him, but the ambidextrous spinner had the last laugh. And prior to that, he had removed opener Shadman Islam. Shanto though, made it a mission to put Tharindu off his rhythm; he would end the morning session having struck at better than run-a-ball against the spinner, and would continue to target him as a release valve of sorts throughout the day. Of Shanto's 15 boundaries (14 fours and a six), ten came off Tharindu.

Tharindu eventually settled in and brought down his economy rate, but Shanto and Mushfiqur continued steadily on, the run rate always hovering around 3-3.5 an over. The session counters reflected as much - 90, 92 and 110. The last session might have been less, after Sri Lanka began utilising defensive lines for the first hour, but they got tired in the final hour and it allowed Bangladesh to tick along at nearly four an over during that period.

Considering the batter-friendly nature of the pitch, an argument could be made for Bangladesh perhaps having been able to go harder at the Sri Lankan bowlers, but even with the pitch taking less turn on day one than what it has in the past, the conventional wisdom in Galle has been to bat first and long, and Bangladesh are set up to do just that.

Sri Lanka for most of the morning, would not have imagined proceedings ending up like this. The day had begun with a felicitation and a guard of honour for the retiring Angelo Mathews, and then just 4.3 overs into the day's play, Asitha got one to seam away and catch Anamul Haque's edge.

Tharindu then added to the celebratory mood, grabbing two wickets in consecutive deliveries (across two overs), a dream start to his Test career. But then things took a turn with the experience of Shanto and Mushfiqur coming into play.

Sri Lanka too were guilty of perhaps over-bowling the debutant when it was clear he was being targeted, while they could also have possibly refrained from pairing him with Milan, who was creating pressure at one end only for it to be alleviated at the other. For instance, it took until an hour after the lunch break for Jayasuriya to be reintroduced, and by that time, both batters had neared fifties.

That said, both Shanto and Mushfiqur batted with clear purpose and it meant that when Sri Lanka erred, they were waiting and ready to capitalise.

    BBC Sport football news reporter



    Chelsea won their opening Club World Cup match against Los Angeles FC in front of a mostly empty Mercedes-Benz Stadium in Atlanta.



    Pedro Neto's near-post shot after being sent clear in the first half was followed by a close-range tap-in from Enzo Fernandez, after a fine cross from debutant striker Liam Delap.



    However, [the major talking point was an official attendance figure of just 22,137 fans](https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/articles/c8rpxjgr8mjo) inside the 71,000-seater arena.



    Those in the ground witnessed a laboured performance from the Blues, but ultimately finishing quality sealed victory for the Premier League side, with Delap exciting on his debut after his £30m move from Ipswich this month.



    Midfielder Dario Essugo also made his debut, with Chelsea having now won eight of their past nine matches, including the Conference League final.



    Underdogs LAFC, featuring World Cup-winning French duo Olivier Giroud and Hugo Lloris, caused problems but could not take chances which fell to Denis Bouanga and substitute David Martinez.
