![Enzo Fernandez and Liam Delap ](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/ace/standard/800/cpsprodpb/431a/live/d4148bb0-4af3-11f0-a61b-3f34d059c107.jpg)Image source, Getty Images

Image caption,

Enzo Fernandez scored his ninth goal of the season from Liam Delap's cross

[Nizaar Kinsella](https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/topics/c999r12k905t)

BBC Sport football news reporter in Atlanta

**Liam Delap made his debut as Chelsea won their Club World Cup opener against Los Angeles FC in front of thousands of empty seats at Mercedes-Benz Stadium in Atlanta.**

Pedro Neto's near-post shot after being sent clear in the first half was followed by a close-range tap-in from Enzo Fernandez, assisted by Delap's fine cross from the right.

However, the major talking point [was an official attendance of just 22,137 fans](https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/articles/c8rpxjgr8mjo) inside the 71,000-seater arena.

Those in the ground witnessed a laboured performance by Chelsea, but their finishing quality sealed victory with striker Delap impressing as a 64th-minute substitute following his [£30m move from Ipswich](https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/articles/c0k3dkd0gvno) this month.

Underdogs LAFC, featuring World Cup-winning French duo Olivier Giroud and Hugo Lloris, caused problems but could not take chances which fell to Denis Bouanga and substitute David Martinez.

Midfielder Dario Essugo also made his debut for Chelsea, who have now won eight of their past nine matches, including the [Conference League final](https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/live/crk2zx2e1xet).

## Delap impresses on 30-minute debut

Chelsea have a very exciting new attacker if Delap's debut is anything to go by.

The England Under-21s forward, who withdrew from Lee Carsley's international squad to play in the Club World Cup, picked up the ball 30 yards from goal and drove at LAFC captain Aaron Long, almost setting up Fernandez in the process.

Just moments later his chipped cross was tapped home by the midfielder, while he almost provided another assist after dribbling 25 yards in his final action of the game.

## Why was the crowd so small?

There are concerns about the attendance at the match in Atlanta, just one year before the 2026 World Cup.

A large number of locals seemed oblivious to a major international club match at their stadium this week, with a Power Rangers convention and UFC event vying for their attention.

But high ticket prices, minimal local marketing efforts and the game kicking off at 3pm local time on a weekday were cited as other factors behind the poor turnout.

This is a city boasting the highest attendances in Major League Soccer (MLS), with Atlanta United attracting an average 44,037 fans.

More than 70,000 supporters watched Chelsea face Newcastle in a friendly at this stadium two years ago. BBC Sport has contacted Fifa for comment.

## What's next for these teams?

Chelsea take on Brazilian side Flamengo in Philadelphia on Friday (19:00 BST), while LAFC face ES Tunis in Nashville (23:00). The culmination of Group D is the following Tuesday, when Chelsea play Tunis and LAFC meet Flamengo.

Click here for more information.") From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia Rare neurodegenerative disease This article is about the neurodegenerative disease. For other uses, see [ALS (disambiguation)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS_(disambiguation) "ALS (disambiguation)"). "Motor neuron disease" and "Motor neurone disease" redirect here. For a group of muscle-wasting disorders, see [Motor neuron diseases](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motor_neuron_diseases "Motor neuron diseases"). Medical condition | Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis | | --- | | Other names | - Motor neurone disease (MND)
- [Lou Gehrig](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lou_Gehrig "Lou Gehrig")'s disease
- [Charcot's disease](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jean-Martin_Charcot "Jean-Martin Charcot")[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Orphanet2009-1) | | [![Diagram of a human nervous system highlighting the brain, spinal cord, motor neurons, and muscles of the body affected by ALS](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/ALS_Affected_neurons_and_muscles.png/250px-ALS_Affected_neurons_and_muscles.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:ALS_Affected_neurons_and_muscles.png) | | Parts of the [nervous system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nervous_system "Nervous system") affected by ALS, causing progressive symptoms in [skeletal muscles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Skeletal_muscles "Skeletal muscles") throughout the body[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Masrori-2020-2) | | [Specialty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medical_specialty "Medical specialty") | [Neurology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neurology "Neurology") | | [Symptoms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signs_and_symptoms "Signs and symptoms") | **Early**: [Stiff muscles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spasticity "Spasticity"), [muscle twitches](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fasciculation "Fasciculation"), gradual increasing weakness[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-NINDS2020-3)
**Later**: Difficulty in [speaking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dysarthria "Dysarthria"), [swallowing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dysphagia "Dysphagia"), and [breathing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shortness_of_breath "Shortness of breath"); [respiratory failure](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Respiratory_failure "Respiratory failure");[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-NINDS2020-3) 10–15% experience [frontotemporal dementia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frontotemporal_dementia "Frontotemporal dementia")[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Masrori-2020-2) | | [Complications](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complication_(medicine) "Complication (medicine)") | [Falling (accident)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Falling_(accident) "Falling (accident)"); [Respiratory failure](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Respiratory_failure "Respiratory failure"); [Pneumonia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pneumonia "Pneumonia"); [Malnutrition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malnutrition "Malnutrition") | | Usual onset | 45–75 years[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Masrori-2020-2) | | Causes | Unknown (90% to 95%), genetic (5% to 10%) | | [Risk factors](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Risk_factor "Risk factor") | Genetic risk factors; age; [male sex](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Male "Male"); heavy metals; organic chemicals; smoking; electric shock; physical exercise; head injury[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Masrori-2020-2) | | [Diagnostic method](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medical_diagnosis "Medical diagnosis") | Clinical diagnosis of exclusion based on progressive symptoms of upper and lower motor neuron degeneration in which no other explanation can be found. Supportive evidence from [electromyography](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electromyography "Electromyography"), [genetic testing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genetic_testing "Genetic testing"), and [neuroimaging](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neuroimaging "Neuroimaging") | | [Differential diagnosis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Differential_diagnosis "Differential diagnosis") | [Multifocal motor neuropathy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multifocal_motor_neuropathy "Multifocal motor neuropathy"), [Kennedy's disease](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kennedy%27s_disease "Kennedy's disease"), [Hereditary spastic paraplegia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hereditary_spastic_paraplegia "Hereditary spastic paraplegia"), [Nerve compression syndrome](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nerve_compression_syndrome "Nerve compression syndrome"), [Diabetic neuropathy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diabetic_neuropathy "Diabetic neuropathy"), [Post-polio syndrome](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Post-polio_syndrome "Post-polio syndrome"), [Myasthenia gravis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Myasthenia_gravis "Myasthenia gravis"), [Multiple sclerosis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multiple_sclerosis "Multiple sclerosis")[\[4\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-4) | | Treatment | [Walker (mobility)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walker_(mobility) "Walker (mobility)"); - Prevalence: 4.4/100,000 living individuals[\[6\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Goutman_480%E2%80%93493-6)
- Lifetime risk: 1 in 400 individuals[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-7) | **Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis** ( **ALS**), also known as **motor neuron disease** ( **MND**) or—in the United States— **[Lou Gehrig](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lou_Gehrig "Lou Gehrig")'s disease** ( **LGD**), is a rare, [terminal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terminal_illness "Terminal illness") [neurodegenerative disorder](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neurodegenerative_disease "Neurodegenerative disease") that results in the progressive loss of both upper and lower [motor neurons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motor_neuron "Motor neuron") that normally control [voluntary muscle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Skeletal_muscle "Skeletal muscle") contraction.[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-NINDS2020-3) ALS is the most common form of the [motor neuron diseases](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motor_neuron_diseases "Motor neuron diseases").[\[8\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-8) ALS often presents in its early stages with gradual muscle [stiffness](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spasticity "Spasticity"), [twitches](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fasciculation "Fasciculation"), [weakness](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muscle_weakness "Muscle weakness"), and [wasting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muscle_atrophy "Muscle atrophy").[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-NINDS2020-3) Motor neuron loss typically continues until the abilities to eat, speak, move, and, lastly, breathe are all lost.[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-NINDS2020-3) While only 15% of people with ALS also fully develop [frontotemporal dementia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frontotemporal_dementia "Frontotemporal dementia"), an estimated 50% face at least some minor difficulties with [thinking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_disorder "Cognitive disorder") and [behavior](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavior "Behavior").[\[9\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Lancet2017-9) Depending on which of the aforementioned symptoms develops first, ALS is classified as _limb-onset_ (begins with weakness in the arms or legs) or _bulbar-onset_ (begins with difficulty in [speaking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dysarthria "Dysarthria") or [swallowing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dysphagia "Dysphagia")).[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Nature2017-10) Most cases of ALS (about 90–95%) have [no known cause](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Idiopathic "Idiopathic"), and are known as _sporadic ALS_.[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-NINDS2020-3)[\[11\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-11) However, both [genetic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genetics "Genetics") and [environmental factors](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Environmental_factors "Environmental factors") are believed to be involved.[\[12\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Wingo2011-12) The remaining 5–10% of cases have a genetic cause, often linked to a [family history of the disease](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Family_history_(medicine) "Family history (medicine)"), and these are known as _familial ALS_ (hereditary).[\[6\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Goutman_480%E2%80%93493-6)[\[13\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-13) About half of these genetic cases are due to disease-causing variants in one of four specific [genes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gene "Gene").[\[14\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Goutman-2022-14) The [diagnosis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diagnosis "Diagnosis") is based on a person's [signs and symptoms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signs_and_symptoms "Signs and symptoms"), with testing conducted to rule out other potential causes.[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-NINDS2020-3) There is no known cure for ALS.[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-NINDS2020-3) The goal of treatment is to slow the disease progression, and improve symptoms.[\[9\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Lancet2017-9) FDA-approved treatments that slow the progression of ALS include [riluzole](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Riluzole "Riluzole") and [edaravone](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edaravone "Edaravone").[\[15\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-alsa1-15) [Non-invasive ventilation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-invasive_ventilation "Non-invasive ventilation") may result in both improved quality and length of life.[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Support2016-5) [Mechanical ventilation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mechanical_ventilation "Mechanical ventilation") can prolong survival but does not stop disease progression.[\[16\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Care2017-16) A [feeding tube](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feeding_tube "Feeding tube") may help maintain weight and nutrition.[\[17\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Conn2015-17) Death is usually caused by respiratory failure.[\[18\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Lancet2011-18) The disease can affect people of any age, but usually starts around the age of 60.[\[18\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Lancet2011-18) The average survival from onset to death is two to four years, though this can vary, and about 10% of those affected survive longer than ten years.[\[19\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Pupillo-2014-19) Descriptions of the disease date back to at least 1824 by [Charles Bell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Bell "Charles Bell").[\[20\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Rowland2001-20) In 1869, the connection between the symptoms and the underlying neurological problems was first described by French neurologist [Jean-Martin Charcot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jean-Martin_Charcot "Jean-Martin Charcot"), who in 1874 began using the term _amyotrophic lateral sclerosis_.[\[20\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Rowland2001-20) ## Classification \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=ALS&action=edit§ion=1 "Edit section: Classification")\] ALS is a [motor neuron disease](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motor_neuron_diseases "Motor neuron diseases"), which is a group of [neurological disorders](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neurological_disorder "Neurological disorder") that selectively affect [motor neurons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motor_neuron "Motor neuron"), the cells that control [voluntary muscles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Skeletal_muscle "Skeletal muscle") of the body.[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-NINDS2020-3) Other motor neuron diseases include [primary lateral sclerosis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Primary_lateral_sclerosis "Primary lateral sclerosis") (PLS), [progressive muscular atrophy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Progressive_muscular_atrophy "Progressive muscular atrophy") (PMA), [progressive bulbar palsy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Progressive_bulbar_palsy "Progressive bulbar palsy"), [pseudobulbar palsy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pseudobulbar_palsy "Pseudobulbar palsy"), and [monomelic amyotrophy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monomelic_amyotrophy "Monomelic amyotrophy") (MMA).[\[21\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-21) As a disease, ALS itself can be classified in a few different ways: by which part of the motor neurons are affected; by the parts of the body first affected; whether it is genetic; and by the age at which it started. Each individual diagnosed with the condition will sit at a unique place at the intersection of these complex and overlapping subtypes, which presents a challenge to diagnosis, understanding, and prognosis.[\[22\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-22) ### Subtypes of motor neuron disease \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=ALS&action=edit§ion=2 "Edit section: Subtypes of motor neuron disease")\] [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Illustration_of_the_motor_neuron_tract_descending_from_primary_motor_cortex%2C_via_spinal_cord%2C_to_skeletal_muscle.jpg/250px-Illustration_of_the_motor_neuron_tract_descending_from_primary_motor_cortex%2C_via_spinal_cord%2C_to_skeletal_muscle.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Illustration_of_the_motor_neuron_tract_descending_from_primary_motor_cortex,_via_spinal_cord,_to_skeletal_muscle.jpg) Classic ALS involves neurons in the brain and spinal cord ( [upper motor neurons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Upper_motor_neuron "Upper motor neuron"), highlighted red), as well as the [lower motor neurons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lower_motor_neuron "Lower motor neuron"), which go from the spinal cord to the muscles, highlighted teal.[\[23\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Cold_Spring_Harbor_2017-23) ALS can be classified by the types of motor neurons that are affected.[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Masrori-2020-2) To successfully control any voluntary muscle in the body, a signal must be sent from the [motor cortex](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motor_cortex "Motor cortex") in the brain down the [upper motor neuron](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Upper_motor_neuron "Upper motor neuron") as it travels down the spinal cord. There, it connects via a [synapse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synapse "Synapse") to the [lower motor neuron](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lower_motor_neuron "Lower motor neuron") which connects to the muscle itself. Damage to either the upper or lower motor neuron, as it makes its way from the brain to muscle, causes different types of symptoms.[\[23\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Cold_Spring_Harbor_2017-23) Damage to the upper motor neuron typically causes [spasticity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spasticity "Spasticity") including stiffness and increased [tendon reflexes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tendon_reflex "Tendon reflex") or [clonus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clonus "Clonus"), while damage to the lower motor neuron typically causes [weakness](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muscle_weakness "Muscle weakness"), [muscle atrophy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muscular_atrophy#Pathophysiology "Muscular atrophy"), and [fasciculations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fasciculation "Fasciculation").[\[24\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-arora-2023-24) Classical, or classic ALS, involves degeneration to both the [upper motor neurons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Upper_motor_neuron "Upper motor neuron") in the brain and the [lower motor neurons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lower_motor_neuron "Lower motor neuron") in the spinal cord.[\[6\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Goutman_480%E2%80%93493-6)[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Masrori-2020-2) [Primary lateral sclerosis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Primary_lateral_sclerosis "Primary lateral sclerosis") (PLS) involves degeneration of only the upper motor neurons, and [progressive muscular atrophy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Progressive_muscular_atrophy "Progressive muscular atrophy") (PMA) involves only the lower motor neurons. There is debate over whether PLS and PMA are separate diseases or simply variants of ALS.[\[9\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Lancet2017-9) | Main ALS subtypes | [Upper motor neuron](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Upper_motor_neuron "Upper motor neuron") degeneration | [Lower motor neuron](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lower_motor_neuron "Lower motor neuron") degeneration | | --- | --- | --- | | Classical ALS | Yes | Yes | | Primary lateral sclerosis (PLS) | Yes | No | | Progressive muscular atrophy (PMA) | No | Yes | Classical ALS accounts for about 70% of all cases of ALS and can be subdivided into where symptoms first appear as these are usually focused to one region of the body at initial presentation before later spread. _Limb-onset_ ALS (also known as spinal-onset) and _bulbar-onset_ ALS.[\[9\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Lancet2017-9) Limb-onset ALS begins with weakness in the hands, arms, feet, and/or legs[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Nature2017-10) and accounts for about two-thirds of all classical ALS cases.[\[9\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Lancet2017-9) Bulbar-onset ALS begins with weakness in the muscles of speech, chewing, and swallowing[\[23\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Cold_Spring_Harbor_2017-23) and accounts for about 25% of classical ALS cases.[\[6\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Goutman_480%E2%80%93493-6) A rarer type of classical ALS affecting around 3% of patients is respiratory-onset,[\[9\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Lancet2017-9) in which the initial symptoms are difficulty breathing ( [dyspnea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dyspnea "Dyspnea")) upon exertion, at rest, or while lying flat ( [orthopnea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orthopnea "Orthopnea")).[\[25\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-25) [Primary lateral sclerosis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Primary_lateral_sclerosis "Primary lateral sclerosis") (PLS) is a subtype of the overall ALS category which accounts for about 5% of all cases and only affects the upper motor neurons in the arms, legs, and bulbar region.[\[26\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Nature2014-26) However, more than 75% of people with apparent PLS go on to later develop lower motor neuron signs within four years of symptom onset, meaning that a definitive diagnosis of PLS cannot be made until several years have passed.[\[27\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Classification2016-27) PLS has a better prognosis than classical ALS, as it progresses slower, results in less functional decline, does not affect the ability to breathe, and causes less severe weight loss than classical ALS.[\[26\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Nature2014-26) [Progressive muscular atrophy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Progressive_muscular_atrophy "Progressive muscular atrophy") (PMA) is another subtype that accounts for about 5% of the overall ALS category and affects lower motor neurons in the arms, legs, and bulbar region.[\[26\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Nature2014-26) While PMA is associated with longer survival on average than classical ALS, it is still progressive over time, eventually leading to respiratory failure and death.[\[9\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Lancet2017-9) As with PLS developing into classical ALS, PMA can also develop into classical ALS over time if the lower motor neuron involvement progresses to include upper motor neurons, in which case the diagnosis might be changed to classic ALS.[\[27\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Classification2016-27) ### Rare isolated variants of ALS \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=ALS&action=edit§ion=3 "Edit section: Rare isolated variants of ALS")\] Isolated variants of ALS have symptoms that are limited to a single region for at least a year; they progress more slowly than classical ALS and are associated with longer survival.[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Masrori-2020-2) These regional variants of ALS can only be considered as a diagnosis should the initial symptoms fail to spread to other spinal cord regions for an extended period of time (at least 12 months).[\[28\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-28) [Flail arm syndrome](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brachial_amyotrophic_diplegia "Brachial amyotrophic diplegia") is characterized by lower motor neuron damage affecting the arm muscles, typically starting with the upper arms symmetrically and progressing downwards to the hands.[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Masrori-2020-2) Flail leg syndrome is characterized by lower motor neuron damage leading to asymmetrical weakness and wasting in the legs starting around the feet.[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Masrori-2020-2) Isolated bulbar palsy is characterized by upper or lower motor neuron damage in the bulbar region (in the absence of limb symptoms for at least 20 months),[\[29\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-29) leading to gradual onset of difficulty with speech ( [dysarthria](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dysarthria "Dysarthria")) and swallowing ( [dysphagia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dysphagia "Dysphagia")). [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/ALS_subtypes_UMN_LMN_distribution.png/250px-ALS_subtypes_UMN_LMN_distribution.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:ALS_subtypes_UMN_LMN_distribution.png) Illustration showing the range of upper and lower motor neuron involvement in the two most common types of ALS (top row) and three of the most common rare subtypes of ALS (bottom row) ### Age of onset \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=ALS&action=edit§ion=4 "Edit section: Age of onset")\] ALS can also be classified based on the age of onset. People with familial ALS have an age of onset about 5 years younger than those with apparently sporadic ALS.[\[30\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-30) About 10% of all cases of ALS begin before age 45 ("young-onset" ALS), and about 1% of all cases begin before age 25 ("juvenile" ALS).[\[23\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Cold_Spring_Harbor_2017-23) People who develop young-onset ALS are more likely to be male, less likely to have bulbar onset of symptoms, and more likely to have a slower progression of the disease.[\[27\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Classification2016-27) Juvenile ALS is more likely to be genetic in origin than adult-onset ALS; the most common genes associated with juvenile ALS are _[FUS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FUS_(gene) "FUS (gene)")_, _[ALS2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS2 "ALS2")_, and _[SETX](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SETX "SETX")_.[\[31\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-31) Although most people with juvenile ALS live longer than those with adult-onset ALS, some of them have specific mutations in _[FUS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FUS_(gene) "FUS (gene)")_ and _[SOD1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SOD1 "SOD1")_ that are associated with a poor prognosis.[\[32\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-32) Late onset (after age 65) is generally associated with a more rapid functional decline and shorter survival.[\[33\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Clinical_Features_of_ALS-33) ## Signs and symptoms \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=ALS&action=edit§ion=5 "Edit section: Signs and symptoms")\] The disorder causes muscle weakness, [atrophy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atrophy "Atrophy"), and [muscle spasms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spasticity "Spasticity") throughout the body due to the degeneration of the upper motor and lower motor neurons. [Sensory nerves](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sensory_neuron "Sensory neuron") and the [autonomic nervous system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomic_nervous_system "Autonomic nervous system") are generally unaffected, meaning the majority of people with ALS maintain [hearing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hearing "Hearing"), [sight](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visual_perception "Visual perception"), [touch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Somatosensory_system "Somatosensory system"), [smell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olfaction "Olfaction"), and [taste](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taste "Taste").[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-NINDS2020-3) ### Initial symptoms \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=ALS&action=edit§ion=6 "Edit section: Initial symptoms")\] The start of ALS may be so subtle that the symptoms are overlooked.[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-NINDS2020-3) The earliest symptoms of ALS are muscle weakness or muscle atrophy, typically on one side of the body. Other presenting symptoms include trouble swallowing or breathing, cramping, or stiffness of affected muscles; muscle weakness affecting an arm or a leg; or slurred and nasal speech. The parts of the body affected by early symptoms of ALS depend on which motor neurons in the body are damaged first.[\[34\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-34) In limb-onset ALS, the first symptoms are in the arms or the legs. If the legs are affected first, people may experience awkwardness, tripping, or stumbling when walking or running; this is often marked by walking with a " [dropped foot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foot_drop "Foot drop")" that drags gently on the ground. If the arms are affected first, they may experience difficulty with tasks requiring manual dexterity, such as buttoning a shirt, writing, or turning a key in a lock.[\[35\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-35) In bulbar-onset ALS, the first symptoms are difficulty speaking or swallowing. Speech may become slurred, nasal in character, or quieter. There may be difficulty with swallowing and loss of tongue mobility. A smaller proportion of people experience "respiratory-onset" ALS, where the [intercostal muscles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intercostal_muscle "Intercostal muscle") that support breathing are affected first.[\[18\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Lancet2011-18) Over time, people experience increasing difficulty moving, swallowing ( [dysphagia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dysphagia "Dysphagia")), and speaking or forming words ( [dysarthria](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dysarthria "Dysarthria")). Symptoms of upper motor neuron involvement include tight and stiff muscles ( [spasticity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spasticity "Spasticity")) and exaggerated reflexes ( [hyperreflexia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyperreflexia "Hyperreflexia")), including an overactive gag reflex.[\[23\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Cold_Spring_Harbor_2017-23) While the disease does not cause pain directly, pain is a symptom experienced by most people with ALS caused by reduced mobility.[\[36\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Pain2017-36) Symptoms of lower motor neuron degeneration include muscle weakness and atrophy, muscle cramps, and fleeting twitches of muscles that can be seen under the skin ( [fasciculations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fasciculation "Fasciculation")).[\[24\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-arora-2023-24) ### Progression \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=ALS&action=edit§ion=7 "Edit section: Progression")\] Although the initial site of symptoms and subsequent rate of disability progression vary from person to person, the initially affected body region is usually the most affected over time, and symptoms usually spread to a neighbouring body region. For example, symptoms starting in one arm usually spread next to either the opposite arm or to the leg on the same side.[\[23\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Cold_Spring_Harbor_2017-23) Bulbar-onset patients most typically get their next symptoms in their arms rather than legs, arm-onset patients typically spread to the legs before the bulbar region, and leg-onset patients typically spread to the arms rather than the bulbar region.[\[37\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-37) Over time, regardless of where symptoms began, most people eventually lose the ability to walk or use their hands and arms independently. Less consistently, they may lose the ability to speak and to swallow food. It is the eventual development of weakness of the respiratory muscles, with the loss of ability to cough and to breathe without support, that is ultimately life-shortening in ALS.[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Support2016-5) The rate of progression can be measured using the [ALS Functional Rating Scale - Revised](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS_Functional_Rating_Scale_-_Revised "ALS Functional Rating Scale - Revised") (ALSFRS-R), a 12-item instrument survey administered as a clinical interview or self-reported questionnaire that produces a score between 48 (normal function) and 0 (severe disability).[\[38\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-38) The ALSFRS-R is the most frequently used outcome measure in clinical trials[\[39\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-39) and is used by doctors to track disease progression.[\[40\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-40) Though the degree of variability is high and a small percentage of people have a much slower progression, on average people with ALS lose about 1 ALSFRS-R point per month.[\[41\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-41) Brief periods of stabilization ("plateaus") and even small reversals in ALSFRS-R score are not uncommon, due to the fact the tool is subjective, can be affected by medication, and different forms of compensation for changes in function.[\[42\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Bedlack-2016-42) However, it is rare (<1%) for these improvements to be large (i.e. greater than 4 ALSFRS-R points) or sustained (i.e. greater than 12 months).[\[42\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Bedlack-2016-42) A survey-based study among clinicians showed that they rated a 20% change in the slope of the ALSFRS-R as being clinically meaningful, which is the most common threshold used to determine whether a new treatment is working in clinical trials.[\[43\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-43) ### Late-stage disease management \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=ALS&action=edit§ion=8 "Edit section: Late-stage disease management")\] Difficulties with chewing and swallowing make eating very difficult ( [dysphagia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dysphagia "Dysphagia")) and increase the risk of choking or of [aspirating](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pulmonary_aspiration "Pulmonary aspiration") food into the lungs.[\[44\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Yunusova-2019-44) In later stages of the disorder, [aspiration pneumonia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aspiration_pneumonia "Aspiration pneumonia") can develop, and maintaining a healthy weight can become a significant problem that may require the insertion of a feeding tube.[\[44\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Yunusova-2019-44) As the diaphragm and [intercostal muscles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intercostal_muscle "Intercostal muscle") of the [rib cage](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rib_cage "Rib cage") that support breathing weaken, measures of [lung function](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spirometry "Spirometry") such as [vital capacity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vital_capacity "Vital capacity") and inspiratory pressure diminish. In respiratory-onset ALS, this may occur before significant limb weakness is apparent. Individuals affected by the disorder may ultimately lose the ability to initiate and control all voluntary movement,[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Support2016-5) known as [locked-in syndrome](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Locked-in_syndrome "Locked-in syndrome"). Bladder and bowel function are usually spared, meaning [urinary](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Urinary_incontinence "Urinary incontinence") and [fecal incontinence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fecal_incontinence "Fecal incontinence") are uncommon, although trouble getting to a toilet can lead to difficulties. The [extraocular muscles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extraocular_muscles "Extraocular muscles") responsible for eye movement are usually spared,[\[45\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-45) meaning the use of [eye tracking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eye_tracking "Eye tracking") technology to support [augmentative communication](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Augmentative_and_alternative_communication "Augmentative and alternative communication") is often feasible, albeit slow, and needs may change over time.[\[46\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-46) Despite these challenges, many people in an advanced state of disease report satisfactory wellbeing and quality of life.[\[47\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-47) ### Prognosis, staging, and survival \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=ALS&action=edit§ion=9 "Edit section: Prognosis, staging, and survival")\] Although respiratory support using [non-invasive ventilation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-invasive_ventilation "Non-invasive ventilation") can ease problems with breathing and prolong survival,[\[48\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-48) it does not affect the progression rate of ALS. Most people with ALS die between two and four years after the diagnosis.[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Support2016-5) Around 50% of people with ALS die within 30 months of their symptoms beginning, about 20% live between five and ten years,[\[18\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Lancet2011-18) and about 10% survive for 10 years or longer.[\[19\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Pupillo-2014-19) The most common cause of death among people with ALS is [respiratory failure](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Respiratory_failure "Respiratory failure"), often accelerated by [pneumonia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pneumonia "Pneumonia").[\[18\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Lancet2011-18) Most ALS patients die at home after a period of worsening difficulty breathing, a decline in their nutritional status, or a rapid worsening of symptoms.[\[49\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Bede-2011-49) Sudden death or acute respiratory distress are uncommon.[\[50\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-50) Access to [palliative care](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palliative_care "Palliative care") is recommended from an early stage to explore options, ensure psychosocial support for the patient and caregivers, and to discuss [advance healthcare directives](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Advance_healthcare_directive "Advance healthcare directive").[\[49\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Bede-2011-49) As with [cancer staging](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cancer_staging "Cancer staging"), ALS has staging systems numbered between 1 and 4 that are used for research purposes in clinical trials.[\[6\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Goutman_480%E2%80%93493-6) Two very similar staging systems emerged around a similar time, the King's staging system and Milano-Torino (MiToS) functional staging.[\[51\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-51) | | Stage 1 | Stage 2 | Stage 3 | Stage 4 | | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | | Stage description | Symptom onset, involvement of the first region | 2A: Diagnosis
2B: Involvement of the second region | Involvement of the third region | 4A: Need for a feeding tube
4B: Need for non-invasive ventilation | | Median time to stage | 13.5 months | 17.7 months | 23.3 months | 4A: 17.7 months
4B: 30.3 months | Kings ALS staging system and prognosis at each stage | | Stage 0 | Stage 1 | Stage 2 | Stage 3 | Stage 4 | Stage 5 | | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | | Stage description | No loss of a functional domain | Loss of 1 domain | Loss of 2 domains | Loss of 3 domains | Loss of 4 domains | Death | | Probability of death at each stage | 7% | 26% | 33% | 33% | 86% | | MiToS ALS staging system and prognosis at each stage Providing individual patients with a precise prognosis is not currently possible, though research is underway to provide statistical models on the basis of prognostic factors including age at onset, progression rate, site of onset, and presence of [frontotemporal dementia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frontotemporal_dementia "Frontotemporal dementia").[\[6\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Goutman_480%E2%80%93493-6) Those with a bulbar onset have a worse prognosis than limb-onset ALS; a population-based study found that bulbar-onset ALS patients had a median survival of 2.0 years and a 10-year survival rate of 3%, while limb-onset ALS patients had a median survival of 2.6 years and a 10-year survival rate of 13%.[\[52\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-JNNP_July_2011-52) Those with respiratory-onset ALS had a shorter median survival of 1.4 years and 0% survival at 10 years.[\[52\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-JNNP_July_2011-52) While [astrophysicist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astrophysics "Astrophysics") [Stephen Hawking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stephen_Hawking "Stephen Hawking") lived for 55 more years following his diagnosis, his was an unusual case.[\[53\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-53) ### Cognitive, emotional, and behavioral symptoms \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=ALS&action=edit§ion=10 "Edit section: Cognitive, emotional, and behavioral symptoms")\] [Cognitive impairment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_disorder "Cognitive disorder") or behavioral dysfunction is present in 30–50% of individuals with ALS,[\[54\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Martin2017-54) and can appear more frequently in later stages of the disease.[\[55\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Crockford-2018-55) [Language dysfunction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Language_disorder "Language disorder"), [executive dysfunction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Executive_dysfunction "Executive dysfunction"), and troubles with [social cognition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_cognition "Social cognition") and [verbal memory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Verbal_memory "Verbal memory") are the most commonly reported cognitive symptoms in ALS.[\[55\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Crockford-2018-55) Cognitive impairment is found more frequently in patients with C9orf72 gene repeat expansions, bulbar onset, bulbar symptoms, [family history](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Family_history_(medicine) "Family history (medicine)") of ALS, and/or a predominantly upper motor neuron phenotype.[\[56\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-56) [Emotional lability](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pseudobulbar_affect "Pseudobulbar affect") is a symptom in which patients cry, smile, yawn, or laugh, either in the absence of emotional stimuli, or when they are feeling the opposite emotion to that being expressed;[\[57\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-57) it is experienced by about half of ALS patients and is more common in those with bulbar-onset ALS.[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Support2016-5) While relatively benign relative to other symptoms, it can cause increased stigma and social isolation as people around the patient struggle to react appropriately to what can be frequent and inappropriate outbursts in public.[\[58\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-58) In addition to mild changes in cognition that may only emerge during neuropsychological testing, around 10–15% of individuals have signs of [frontotemporal dementia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frontotemporal_dementia "Frontotemporal dementia") (FTD).[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Support2016-5) [Repeating phrases or gestures](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perseveration "Perseveration"), apathy, and [loss of inhibition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disinhibition "Disinhibition") are the most frequently reported behavioral features of ALS.[\[59\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-59) ALS and FTD are now considered to be part of a common disease spectrum (ALS–FTD) because of genetic, clinical, and pathological similarities.[\[60\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-60) Genetically, repeat expansions in the C9orf72 gene account for about 40% of genetic ALS and 25% of genetic FTD.[\[61\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Neuroscience2014-61) Cognitive and behavioral issues are associated with a poorer prognosis as they may reduce adherence to medical advice, and deficits in empathy and social cognition which may increase caregiver burden.[\[62\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-62) ## Cause \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=ALS&action=edit§ion=11 "Edit section: Cause")\] It is not known what causes sporadic ALS, hence it is described as an [idiopathic disease](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Idiopathic_disease "Idiopathic disease").[\[18\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Lancet2011-18) Though its exact cause is unknown, genetic and environmental factors are thought to be of roughly equal importance.[\[12\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Wingo2011-12) The genetic factors are better understood than the environmental factors; no specific environmental factor has been definitively shown to cause ALS. A multi-step [liability threshold model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liability_threshold_model "Liability threshold model") for ALS proposes that cellular damage accumulates over time due to genetic factors present at birth and exposure to environmental risks throughout life.[\[63\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Conspiracy-63) ALS can strike at any age, but its likelihood increases with age.[\[64\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Mayo_Clinic-64) Most people who develop ALS are between the ages of 40 and 70, with an average age of 55 at the time of diagnosis.[\[65\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-auto-65) ALS is 20% more common in men than women,[\[65\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-auto-65) but this difference in sex distribution is no longer present in patients with onset after age 70.[\[64\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Mayo_Clinic-64) ### Genetics and genetic testing \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=ALS&action=edit§ion=12 "Edit section: Genetics and genetic testing")\] Main article: [Genetics of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genetics_of_amyotrophic_lateral_sclerosis "Genetics of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis") While they appear identical clinically and pathologically,[\[66\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-66) ALS can be classified as being either familial or sporadic, depending on whether there is a known family history of the disease and/or whether an ALS-associated genetic mutation has been identified via genetic testing.[\[67\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-67) Familial ALS is thought to account for 10–15% of cases overall and can include [monogenic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monogenic_(genetics) "Monogenic (genetics)"), [oligogenic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oligogenic_inheritance "Oligogenic inheritance"), and [polygenic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polygenic_inheritance "Polygenic inheritance") modes of inheritance.[\[14\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Goutman-2022-14) There is considerable variation among clinicians on how to approach genetic testing in ALS, and only about half discuss the possibility of genetic inheritance with their patients, particularly if there is no discernible family history of the disease.[\[68\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-68) In the past, genetic counseling and testing was only offered to those with obviously familial ALS.[\[14\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Goutman-2022-14) But it is increasingly recognized that cases of sporadic ALS may also be due to disease-causing [de novo mutations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/De_novo_mutation "De novo mutation") in _[SOD1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SOD1 "SOD1")_, or _[C9orf72](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/C9orf72 "C9orf72")_,[\[69\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-69) an incomplete family history, or incomplete [penetrance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Penetrance "Penetrance"), meaning that a patient's ancestors carried the gene but did not express the disease in their lifetimes.[\[14\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Goutman-2022-14) The lack of positive family history may be caused by lack of historical records, having a smaller family, older generations dying earlier of causes other than ALS, genetic [non-paternity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-paternity_event "Non-paternity event"), and uncertainty over whether certain neuropsychiatric conditions (e.g. [frontotemporal dementia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frontotemporal_dementia "Frontotemporal dementia"), other forms of [dementia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dementia "Dementia"), suicide, psychosis, [schizophrenia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schizophrenia "Schizophrenia")) should be considered significant when determining a family history.[\[14\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Goutman-2022-14) There have been calls in the research community to routinely counsel and test all diagnosed ALS patients for familial ALS,[\[70\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-70) particularly as there is now a licensed gene therapy ( [tofersen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tofersen "Tofersen")) specifically targeted to carriers of SOD-1 ALS. A shortage of genetic counselors and limited clinical capacity to see such at-risk individuals makes this challenging in practice, as does the unequal access to genetic testing around the world.[\[71\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-71) More than 40 genes have been associated with ALS, of which four account for nearly half of familial cases, and around 5% of sporadic cases:[\[14\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Goutman-2022-14) _[C9orf72](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/C9orf72 "C9orf72")_ (40% of familial cases, 7% sporadic), _[SOD1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SOD1 "SOD1")_ (12% of familial cases, 1–2% sporadic), _[FUS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FUS_(gene) "FUS (gene)")_ (4% of familial cases, 1% sporadic), and _[TARDBP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TARDBP "TARDBP")_ (4% of familial cases, 1% sporadic), with the remaining genes mostly accounting for fewer than 1% of either familial or sporadic cases.[\[14\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Goutman-2022-14) ALS genes identified to date explain the cause of about 70% of familial ALS and about 15% of sporadic ALS.[\[14\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Goutman-2022-14) Overall, first-degree relatives of an individual with ALS have a ~1% risk of developing ALS themselves.[\[14\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Goutman-2022-14) ### Environmental and other factors \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=ALS&action=edit§ion=13 "Edit section: Environmental and other factors")\] The multi-step hypothesis suggests the disease is caused by some interaction between an individual's genetic risk factors and their cumulative lifetime of exposures to environmental factors, termed their [exposome](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exposome "Exposome").[\[14\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Goutman-2022-14) The most consistent lifetime exposures associated with developing ALS (other than genetic mutations) include heavy metals (e.g. [lead](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lead "Lead") and [mercury](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercury_(element) "Mercury (element)")), chemicals (e.g. [pesticides](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pesticide "Pesticide") and [solvents](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solvent "Solvent")), [electric shock](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electrical_injury "Electrical injury"), [physical injury](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Injury "Injury") (including [head injury](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Head_injury "Head injury")), and [smoking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smoking "Smoking") (in men more than women).[\[72\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Wang_2017-72) Overall these effects are small, with each exposure in isolation only increasing the likelihood of a very rare condition by a small amount. For instance, an individual's lifetime risk of developing ALS might go from "1 in 400" without exposure to between "1 in 300" and "1 in 200" if they were exposed to heavy metals.[\[72\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Wang_2017-72) Some industries are heavily dependent upon the use or exposure to these environmental factors, increasing employees' susceptibility. Agricultural tasks can be intertwined with as many as 5 such risk factors[\[73\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-FPH-2023-73) excluding workers' smoking preferences. A range of other factors have weaker evidence supporting them and include participation in [professional sports](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Professional_sports "Professional sports"), having a lower [body mass index](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Body_mass_index "Body mass index"), lower [educational attainment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Educational_attainment "Educational attainment"), manual occupations, military service, exposure to [Beta-N-methylamino-L-alanin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beta-Methylamino-L-alanine "Beta-Methylamino-L-alanine") (BMAA), and viral infections.[\[72\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Wang_2017-72) Although some personality traits, such as [openness](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Openness_to_experience "Openness to experience"),[\[74\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Grossman2006-74) [agreeableness](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agreeableness "Agreeableness")[\[75\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-PK2018-75) and [conscientiousness](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conscientiousness "Conscientiousness")[\[75\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-PK2018-75) appear remarkably common among patients with ALS, it remains open whether personality can increase susceptibility to ALS directly.[\[76\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-76) Instead, genetic factors giving rise to personality might simultaneously predispose people to develop ALS,[\[74\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Grossman2006-74) or the above personality traits might underlie lifestyle choices which are in turn risk factors for ALS.[\[75\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-PK2018-75) ## Pathophysiology \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=ALS&action=edit§ion=14 "Edit section: Pathophysiology")\] ### Neuropathology \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=ALS&action=edit§ion=15 "Edit section: Neuropathology")\] Upon examination at autopsy, features of the disease that can be [seen with the naked eye](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gross_pathology "Gross pathology") include skeletal [muscle atrophy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muscle_atrophy "Muscle atrophy"), motor cortex atrophy, [sclerosis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sclerosis_(medicine) "Sclerosis (medicine)") of the [corticospinal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corticospinal_tract "Corticospinal tract") and [corticobulbar tracts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corticobulbar_tract "Corticobulbar tract"), thinning of the [hypoglossal nerves](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypoglossal_nerve "Hypoglossal nerve") (which control the tongue), and thinning of the [anterior roots](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anterior_roots "Anterior roots") of the spinal cord.[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Nature2017-10) The defining feature of ALS is the death of both upper motor neurons (located in the [motor cortex](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motor_cortex "Motor cortex") of the brain) and lower motor neurons (located in the brainstem and spinal cord).[\[77\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-77) In ALS with frontotemporal dementia, neurons throughout the frontal and temporal lobes of the brain die as well.[\[78\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-NEJM_2017-78) The pathological hallmark of ALS is the presence of [inclusion bodies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inclusion_bodies "Inclusion bodies") (abnormal aggregations of protein) known as Bunina bodies in the cytoplasm of motor neurons. In about 97% of people with ALS, the main component of the inclusion bodies is [TDP-43](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TDP-43 "TDP-43") protein;[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Nature2017-10) however, in those with _SOD1_ or _FUS_ mutations, the main component of the inclusion bodies[\[79\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-79)[\[80\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-80) is SOD1 protein or FUS protein, respectively.[\[23\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Cold_Spring_Harbor_2017-23) [Prion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prion "Prion")-like propagation of misfolded proteins from cell to cell may explain why ALS starts in one area and spreads to others.[\[23\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Cold_Spring_Harbor_2017-23) The [glymphatic system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glymphatic_system "Glymphatic system") may also be involved in the [pathogenesis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pathogenesis "Pathogenesis") of ALS.[\[81\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-81) ### Biochemistry \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=ALS&action=edit§ion=16 "Edit section: Biochemistry")\] [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/ALS_Disease_Pathology_and_Proposed_Disease_Mechanisms.jpg/960px-ALS_Disease_Pathology_and_Proposed_Disease_Mechanisms.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:ALS_Disease_Pathology_and_Proposed_Disease_Mechanisms.jpg) This figure shows ten proposed disease mechanisms for ALS and the genes associated with them.[\[82\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-82) It is still not fully understood why neurons die in ALS, but this [neurodegeneration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neurodegeneration "Neurodegeneration") is thought to involve many different cellular and molecular processes.[\[9\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Lancet2017-9) The genes known to be involved in ALS can be grouped into three general categories based on their normal function: protein degradation, the [cytoskeleton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cytoskeleton "Cytoskeleton"), and RNA processing.[\[83\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-83) Mutant SOD1 protein forms intracellular aggregations that inhibit protein degradation. Cytoplasmic aggregations of [wild-type](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wild-type "Wild-type") (normal) SOD1 protein are common in sporadic ALS.[\[78\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-NEJM_2017-78) It is thought that misfolded mutant SOD1 can cause misfolding and aggregation of wild-type SOD1 in neighboring neurons in a prion-like manner.[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Nature2017-10) Other protein degradation genes that can cause ALS when mutated include _[VCP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Valosin-containing_protein "Valosin-containing protein")_, _[OPTN](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optineurin "Optineurin")_, _[TBK1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TBK1_(gene) "TBK1 (gene)")_, and _[SQSTM1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SQSTM1 "SQSTM1")_. Three genes implicated in ALS that are important for maintaining the cytoskeleton[\[78\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-NEJM_2017-78) and for axonal transport[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Nature2017-10) include _[DCTN1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DCTN1 "DCTN1")_, _[PFN1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PFN1 "PFN1")_, and _[TUBA4A](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TUBA4A "TUBA4A")_.[\[78\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-NEJM_2017-78) Several ALS genes encode RNA-binding proteins. The first to be discovered was TDP-43 protein,[\[78\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-NEJM_2017-78) a nuclear protein that aggregates in the cytoplasm of motor neurons in almost all cases of ALS; however, mutations in _TARDBP_, the gene that codes for TDP-43, are a rare cause of ALS.[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Nature2017-10) _FUS_ codes for FUS, another RNA-binding protein with a similar function to TDP-43, which can cause ALS when mutated.[\[61\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Neuroscience2014-61) It is thought that mutations in _TARDBP_ and _FUS_ increase the binding affinity of the low-complexity domain, causing their respective proteins to aggregate in the cytoplasm.[\[84\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-84) Once these mutant RNA-binding proteins are misfolded and aggregated, they may be able to misfold normal proteins both within and between cells in a prion-like manner.[\[78\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-NEJM_2017-78) This also leads to decreased levels of RNA-binding protein in the nucleus, which may mean that their target RNA transcripts do not undergo normal processing.[\[85\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-85) Other RNA metabolism genes associated with ALS include _[ANG](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Angiogenin "Angiogenin")_, _[SETX](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SETX "SETX")_, and _[MATR3](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MATR3 "MATR3")_.[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Nature2017-10) _C9orf72_ is the most commonly mutated gene in ALS and causes motor neuron death through a number of mechanisms.[\[78\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-NEJM_2017-78) The pathogenic mutation is a hexanucleotide repeat expansion (a series of six nucleotides repeated over and over);[\[86\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-86) people with up to 30 repeats are considered normal, while people with hundreds or thousands of repeats can have familial ALS, frontotemporal dementia, or sometimes sporadic ALS.[\[87\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-87) The three mechanisms of disease associated with these _C9orf72_ repeats are deposition of RNA transcripts in the nucleus, translation of the RNA into toxic dipeptide repeat proteins in the cytoplasm, and decreased levels of the normal C9orf72 protein.[\[78\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-NEJM_2017-78) Mitochondrial bioenergetic dysfunction leading to dysfunctional motor neuron axonal homeostasis (reduced axonal length and fast axonal transport of mitochondrial cargo) has been shown to occur in _C9orf72_-ALS using human [induced pluripotent stem cell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Induced_pluripotent_stem_cells "Induced pluripotent stem cells") (iPSC) technologies coupled with [CRISPR/Cas9](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CRISPR/Cas9-mediated_genome_editing "CRISPR/Cas9-mediated genome editing") gene-editing, and human post-mortem spinal cord tissue examination.[\[88\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-88) [Excitotoxicity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Excitotoxicity "Excitotoxicity"), or nerve cell death caused by high levels of intracellular calcium due to excessive stimulation by the excitatory [neurotransmitter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neurotransmitter "Neurotransmitter") [glutamate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glutamate "Glutamate"), is a mechanism thought to be common to all forms of ALS. Motor neurons are more sensitive to excitotoxicity than other types of neurons because they have a lower calcium-buffering capacity and a type of glutamate receptor (the [AMPA receptor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AMPA_receptor "AMPA receptor")) that is more permeable to calcium. In ALS, there are decreased levels of excitatory amino acid transporter 2 ( [EAAT2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/EAAT2 "EAAT2")), which is the main transporter that removes glutamate from the synapse; this leads to increased synaptic glutamate levels and excitotoxicity. [Riluzole](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Riluzole "Riluzole"), a drug that modestly prolongs survival in ALS, inhibits glutamate release from pre-synaptic neurons; however, it is unclear if this mechanism is responsible for its therapeutic effect.[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Nature2017-10) ## Diagnosis \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=ALS&action=edit§ion=17 "Edit section: Diagnosis")\] [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/ALS_cross.jpg/600px-ALS_cross.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:ALS_cross.jpg) An [MRI of the brain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MRI_of_the_brain "MRI of the brain") (axial [FLAIR](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fluid-attenuated_inversion_recovery "Fluid-attenuated inversion recovery")) looking at a person as if from above that shows increased [_T2_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spin-spin_relaxation "Spin-spin relaxation") signal as a small white region within the [posterior part of the internal capsule](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internal_capsule#Posterior_limb "Internal capsule") around the center of the image, consistent with the diagnosis of ALS No single test can provide a definite diagnosis of ALS.[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-NINDS2020-3) Instead, the diagnosis of ALS is primarily made based on a physician's clinical assessment after ruling out other diseases.[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-NINDS2020-3) Physicians often obtain the person's full [medical history](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medical_history "Medical history") and conduct neurologic examinations at regular intervals to assess whether signs and symptoms such as muscle weakness, [muscle atrophy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muscle_atrophy "Muscle atrophy"), [hyperreflexia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyperreflexia "Hyperreflexia"), [Babinski's sign](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plantar_reflex "Plantar reflex"), and spasticity are worsening.[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-NINDS2020-3) Many biomarkers are being studied for the condition, but as of 2023 are not in general medical use.[\[89\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-89) [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/ALS_Coronal.jpg/250px-ALS_Coronal.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:ALS_Coronal.jpg) An [MRI of the brain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MRI_of_the_brain "MRI of the brain") looking at a person from side-on that shows [increased T2 signal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/T2-weighted "T2-weighted") as a white region in the posterior part of the [internal capsule](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internal_capsule "Internal capsule") that can be tracked to the [motor cortex](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motor_cortex "Motor cortex"), consistent with the diagnosis of ALS ### Differential diagnosis \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=ALS&action=edit§ion=18 "Edit section: Differential diagnosis")\] Because symptoms of ALS can be similar to those of a wide variety of other, more treatable diseases or disorders, appropriate tests must be conducted to exclude the possibility of other conditions. One of these tests is [electromyography](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electromyography "Electromyography") (EMG), a special recording technique that detects electrical activity in muscles. Certain EMG findings can support the diagnosis of ALS. Another common test measures [nerve conduction velocity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nerve_conduction_velocity "Nerve conduction velocity") (NCV).[\[90\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-90) Specific abnormalities in the NCV results may suggest, for example, that the person has a form of [peripheral neuropathy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peripheral_neuropathy "Peripheral neuropathy") (damage to peripheral nerves) or [myopathy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Myopathy "Myopathy") (muscle disease) rather than ALS. While a [magnetic resonance imaging](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magnetic_resonance_imaging "Magnetic resonance imaging") (MRI) is often normal in people with early-stage ALS, it can reveal evidence of other problems that may be causing the symptoms, such as a spinal cord tumor, [multiple sclerosis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multiple_sclerosis "Multiple sclerosis"), a [herniated disc](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Herniated_disc "Herniated disc") in the neck, [syringomyelia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Syringomyelia "Syringomyelia"), or cervical [spondylosis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spondylosis "Spondylosis").[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-NINDS2020-3) Based on the person's symptoms and findings from the examination and from these tests, the physician may order tests on blood and [urine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Urine "Urine") samples to eliminate the possibility of other diseases, as well as routine laboratory tests. In some cases, for example, if a physician suspects the person may have a myopathy rather than ALS, a muscle biopsy may be performed.[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-NINDS2020-3) A number of infectious diseases can sometimes cause ALS-like symptoms,[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-NINDS2020-3) including human immunodeficiency virus ( [HIV](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HIV "HIV")), [human T-lymphotropic virus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_T-lymphotropic_virus "Human T-lymphotropic virus") (HTLV), [Lyme disease](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyme_disease "Lyme disease"), and [syphilis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Syphilis "Syphilis").[\[9\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Lancet2017-9) Neurological disorders such as multiple sclerosis, [post-polio syndrome](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Post-polio_syndrome "Post-polio syndrome"), [multifocal motor neuropathy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multifocal_motor_neuropathy "Multifocal motor neuropathy"), [CIDP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chronic_inflammatory_demyelinating_polyneuropathy "Chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy"), [spinal muscular atrophy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spinal_muscular_atrophy "Spinal muscular atrophy"), and [spinal and bulbar muscular atrophy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spinal_and_bulbar_muscular_atrophy "Spinal and bulbar muscular atrophy") can also mimic certain aspects of the disease and should be considered.[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-NINDS2020-3) ALS must be differentiated from the "ALS mimic syndromes", which are unrelated disorders that may have a similar presentation and clinical features to ALS or its variants.[\[91\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-91) Because the prognosis of ALS and closely related subtypes of motor neuron disease are generally poor, neurologists may carry out investigations to evaluate and exclude other diagnostic possibilities. Disorders of the [neuromuscular junction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neuromuscular_junction "Neuromuscular junction"), such as [myasthenia gravis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Myasthenia_gravis "Myasthenia gravis") (MG) and [Lambert–Eaton myasthenic syndrome](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lambert%E2%80%93Eaton_myasthenic_syndrome "Lambert–Eaton myasthenic syndrome"), may also mimic ALS, although this rarely presents diagnostic difficulty over time.[\[92\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-92)[\[93\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-93) [Benign fasciculation syndrome](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benign_fasciculation_syndrome "Benign fasciculation syndrome") and [cramp fasciculation syndrome](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cramp_fasciculation_syndrome "Cramp fasciculation syndrome") may also, occasionally, mimic some of the early symptoms of ALS. Nonetheless, the absence of other neurological features that develop inexorably with ALS means that, over time, the distinction will not present any difficulty to the experienced neurologist; where doubt remains, EMG may be helpful.[\[94\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-94) ## Management \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=ALS&action=edit§ion=19 "Edit section: Management")\] There is no cure for ALS.[\[9\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Lancet2017-9) Management focuses on treating symptoms and providing supportive care, to improve quality of life and prolong survival.[\[9\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Lancet2017-9) This care is best provided by multidisciplinary teams of healthcare professionals; attending a multidisciplinary ALS clinic is associated with longer survival, fewer hospitalizations, and improved quality of life.[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Support2016-5) [Non-invasive ventilation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-invasive_ventilation "Non-invasive ventilation") (NIV) is the main treatment for respiratory failure in ALS.[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Nature2017-10) In people with normal bulbar function, it prolongs survival by about seven months and improves the quality of life. One study found that NIV is ineffective for people with poor bulbar function[\[95\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Cochrane_NIV-95) while another suggested that it may provide a modest survival benefit.[\[9\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Lancet2017-9) Many people with ALS have difficulty tolerating NIV.[\[96\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Sleep_Disorders_and_Respiratory_Function-96) Invasive ventilation is an option for people with advanced ALS when NIV is not enough to manage their symptoms.[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Support2016-5) While invasive ventilation prolongs survival, disease progression, and functional decline continue.[\[16\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Care2017-16) It may decrease the quality of life of people with ALS or their caregivers.[\[17\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Conn2015-17)[\[16\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Care2017-16) Invasive ventilation is more commonly used in Japan than in North America or Europe.[\[97\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-ALS_Ethics-97) [![Person with ALS and their assistive technologies](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Per_Villand.jpg/250px-Per_Villand.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Per_Villand.jpg) A person with late-stage ALS with a range of assistive technologies to support movement (power wheelchair), breathing (invasive ventilation), and communication (eye tracker and computer) Physical therapy can promote functional independence[\[98\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Lewis_&_Rushanan-98)[\[99\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-asha-99) through aerobic, range of motion, and stretching exercises.[\[100\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-British_Medical_Bulletin-100) Occupational therapy can assist with activities of daily living through adaptive equipment.[\[101\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-ajop-101) Speech therapy can assist people with ALS who have difficulty speaking.[\[99\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-asha-99) Preventing weight loss and malnutrition in people with ALS improves both survival and quality of life.[\[9\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Lancet2017-9) Initially, difficulty swallowing (dysphagia) can be managed by dietary changes and swallowing techniques. A [feeding tube](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feeding_tube "Feeding tube") should be considered if someone with ALS loses 5% or more of their body weight or if they cannot safely swallow food and water.[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Nature2017-10) The feeding tube is usually inserted by [percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Percutaneous_endoscopic_gastrostomy "Percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy") (PEG). There is weak evidence that PEG tubes improve survival.[\[102\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-:0-102) PEG insertion is usually performed with the intent of improving quality of life.[\[17\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Conn2015-17) [Palliative care](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palliative_care "Palliative care") should begin shortly after someone is diagnosed with ALS.[\[103\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-EFNS_2012-103) Discussion of end-of-life issues gives people with ALS time to reflect on their preferences for [end-of-life care](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/End-of-life_care "End-of-life care") and can help avoid unwanted interventions or procedures. Hospice care can improve symptom management at the end of life and increase the likelihood of a peaceful death.[\[17\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Conn2015-17) In the final days of life, opioids can be used to treat pain and dyspnea, while benzodiazepines can be used to treat anxiety.[\[16\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Care2017-16) ### Medications \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=ALS&action=edit§ion=20 "Edit section: Medications")\] #### Disease-slowing treatments \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=ALS&action=edit§ion=21 "Edit section: Disease-slowing treatments")\] [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Riluzole2DACS.svg/600px-Riluzole2DACS.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Riluzole2DACS.svg) Chemical structure of [riluzole](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Riluzole "Riluzole"), a medication that prolongs survival by 2–3 months[\[104\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-CD001447-104) [Riluzole](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Riluzole "Riluzole") has been found to modestly prolong survival by about 2–3 months.[\[105\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-105)[\[104\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-CD001447-104) It may have a greater survival benefit for those with [bulbar-onset ALS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bulbar-onset_ALS "Bulbar-onset ALS").[\[104\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-CD001447-104) It may work by decreasing release of the excitatory [neurotransmitter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neurotransmitter "Neurotransmitter") [glutamate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glutamate_(neurotransmitter) "Glutamate (neurotransmitter)") from pre-synaptic neurons.[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Nature2017-10) The most common side effects are nausea and a lack of energy ( [asthenia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asthenia "Asthenia")).[\[104\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-CD001447-104) People with ALS should begin treatment with riluzole as soon as possible following their diagnosis.[\[103\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-EFNS_2012-103) Riluzole is available as a tablet, liquid, or dissolvable oral film.[\[15\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-alsa1-15) [Edaravone](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edaravone "Edaravone") has been shown to modestly slow the decline in function in a small group of people with early-stage ALS.[\[106\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-106)[\[107\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Therapeutic_Advances_in_Neurological_Disorders-107) It may work by protecting motor neurons from [oxidative stress](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oxidative_stress "Oxidative stress").[\[108\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-108) The most common side effects are bruising and gait disturbance.[\[107\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Therapeutic_Advances_in_Neurological_Disorders-107) Edaravone is available as an intravenous
