infusion or as an oral suspension.[\[109\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-109) [AMX0035](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sodium_phenylbutyrate/ursodoxicoltaurine "Sodium phenylbutyrate/ursodoxicoltaurine") (Relyvrio) is a combination of [sodium phenylbutyrate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sodium_phenylbutyrate "Sodium phenylbutyrate") and [taurursodiol](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tauroursodeoxycholic_acid "Tauroursodeoxycholic acid"), which was initially shown to prolong the survival of patients by an average of six months.[\[110\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-110) Relyvrio was withdrawn by the manufacturer in April 2024[\[111\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-111) following the completion of the Phase 3 PHOENIX trial[\[112\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-112) which did not show substantial benefit to ALS patients. [Tofersen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tofersen "Tofersen") (Qalsody) is an [antisense oligonucleotide](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antisense_oligonucleotide "Antisense oligonucleotide") that was approved for medical use in the United States in April 2023, for the treatment of SOD1-associated ALS.[\[113\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-FDA_Qalsody-113) In a study of 108 patients with SOD1-associated ALS there was a non-significant trend towards a slowing of progression, as well as a significant reduction in neurofilament light chain,[\[114\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-114) a putative ALS biomarker thought to indicate neuronal damage.[\[115\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-115) A follow-up study and open-label extension suggested that earlier treatment initiation had a beneficial effect on slowing disease progression. Tofersen is available as an intrathecal injection into the [lumbar cistern](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lumbar_cistern "Lumbar cistern") at the base of the spine.[\[113\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-FDA_Qalsody-113) A 2025 phase II study published found that tetramethylpyrazine nitrone is safe for patients with ALS, but it did not show a significant advantage over placebo in the primary efficacy measure.[\[116\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-116) Researchers noted that the drug may help slow the decline in grip strength, however further clinical trials are necessary to confirm its potential benefits.[\[117\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-117) #### Symptomatic treatments \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=ALS&action=edit§ion=22 "Edit section: Symptomatic treatments")\] Other medications may be used to help reduce fatigue, ease muscle cramps, control spasticity, and reduce excess saliva and [phlegm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phlegm "Phlegm").[\[100\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-British_Medical_Bulletin-100) [Gabapentin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gabapentin "Gabapentin"), [pregabalin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pregabalin "Pregabalin"), and [tricyclic antidepressants](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tricyclic_antidepressants "Tricyclic antidepressants") (e.g., [amitriptyline](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amitriptyline "Amitriptyline")) can be used for neuropathic pain, while nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs ( [NSAIDs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NSAIDs "NSAIDs")), [acetaminophen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acetaminophen "Acetaminophen"), and [opioids](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opioid "Opioid") can be used for nociceptive pain.[\[36\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Pain2017-36) Depression can be treated with [selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Selective_serotonin_reuptake_inhibitor "Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor") (SSRIs) or tricyclic antidepressants,[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Nature2017-10) while [benzodiazepines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benzodiazepines "Benzodiazepines") can be used for anxiety.[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Support2016-5) There are no medications to treat cognitive impairment/frontotemporal dementia (FTD); however, SSRIs and antipsychotics can help treat some of the symptoms of FTD.[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Nature2017-10) [Baclofen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baclofen "Baclofen") and [tizanidine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tizanidine "Tizanidine") are the most commonly used oral drugs for treating spasticity; an [intrathecal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intrathecal "Intrathecal") baclofen pump can be used for severe spasticity.[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Nature2017-10) [Atropine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atropine "Atropine"), [scopolamine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scopolamine "Scopolamine"), amitriptyline, or [glycopyrrolate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glycopyrrolate "Glycopyrrolate") may be prescribed when people with ALS begin having trouble swallowing their saliva ( [sialorrhea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sialorrhea "Sialorrhea")).[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Nature2017-10) A 2017 review concluded that [mexiletine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mexiletine "Mexiletine") is safe and effective for treating cramps in ALS based on a randomized controlled trial from 2016.[\[107\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Therapeutic_Advances_in_Neurological_Disorders-107) ### Breathing support \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=ALS&action=edit§ion=23 "Edit section: Breathing support")\] #### Non-invasive ventilation \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=ALS&action=edit§ion=24 "Edit section: Non-invasive ventilation")\] [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/BIPAP.JPG/960px-BIPAP.JPG)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:BIPAP.JPG) [Non-invasive ventilation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-invasive_ventilation "Non-invasive ventilation") supports breathing with a face or nasal mask connected to a ventilator. [Non-invasive ventilation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-invasive_ventilation "Non-invasive ventilation") (NIV) is the primary treatment for respiratory failure in ALS[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Nature2017-10) and was the first treatment shown to improve both survival and quality of life.[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Support2016-5) NIV uses a face or nasal mask connected to a ventilator that provides intermittent positive pressure to support breathing. Continuous positive pressure is not recommended for people with ALS because it makes breathing more difficult.[\[16\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Care2017-16) Initially, NIV is used only at night[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Support2016-5) because the first sign of respiratory failure is decreased gas exchange ( [hypoventilation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypoventilation "Hypoventilation")) during sleep; symptoms associated with this nocturnal hypoventilation include interrupted sleep, anxiety, morning headaches, and daytime fatigue.[\[96\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Sleep_Disorders_and_Respiratory_Function-96) As the disease progresses, people with ALS develop shortness of breath when lying down, during physical activity or talking, and eventually at rest.[\[118\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-NeuroRehabilitation_2015-118) Other symptoms include poor concentration, poor memory, confusion, respiratory tract infections, and a weak cough. Respiratory failure is the most common cause of death in ALS.[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Support2016-5) It is important to monitor the respiratory function of people with ALS every three months because beginning NIV soon after the start of respiratory symptoms is associated with increased survival. This involves asking the person with ALS if they have any respiratory symptoms and measuring their respiratory function.[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Support2016-5) The most commonly used measurement is upright [forced vital capacity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forced_vital_capacity "Forced vital capacity") (FVC), but it is a poor detector of early respiratory failure and is not a good choice for those with bulbar symptoms, as they have difficulty maintaining a tight seal around the mouthpiece. Measuring FVC while the person is lying on their back (supine FVC) is a more accurate measure of diaphragm weakness than upright FVC.[\[96\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Sleep_Disorders_and_Respiratory_Function-96) Sniff nasal inspiratory pressure (SNIP) is a rapid, convenient test of diaphragm strength that is not affected by bulbar muscle weakness.[\[16\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Care2017-16) If someone with ALS has signs and symptoms of respiratory failure, they should undergo daytime [blood gas analysis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blood_gas_analysis "Blood gas analysis")[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Support2016-5) to look for [hypoxemia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypoxemia "Hypoxemia") (low oxygen in the blood) and [hypercapnia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypercapnia "Hypercapnia") (too much carbon dioxide in the blood).[\[16\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Care2017-16) If their daytime blood gas analysis is normal, they should then have nocturnal [pulse oximetry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pulse_oximetry "Pulse oximetry") to look for hypoxemia during sleep.[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Support2016-5) Non-invasive ventilation prolongs survival longer than riluzole.[\[119\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-119) A 2006 randomized controlled trial found that NIV prolongs survival by about 48 days and improves the quality of life; however, it also found that some people with ALS benefit more from this intervention than others. For those with normal or only moderately impaired bulbar function, NIV prolongs survival by about seven months and significantly improves the quality of life. For those with poor bulbar function, NIV neither prolongs survival nor improves the quality of life, though it does improve some sleep-related symptoms.[\[95\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Cochrane_NIV-95) Despite the clear benefits of NIV, about 25–30% of all people with ALS are unable to tolerate it, especially those with cognitive impairment or bulbar dysfunction.[\[96\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Sleep_Disorders_and_Respiratory_Function-96) Results from a large 2015 cohort study suggest that NIV may prolong survival in those with bulbar weakness, so NIV should be offered to all people with ALS, even if it is likely that they will have difficulty tolerating it.[\[9\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Lancet2017-9) #### Invasive ventilation \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=ALS&action=edit§ion=25 "Edit section: Invasive ventilation")\] Invasive ventilation bypasses the nose and mouth (the upper airways) by making a cut in the trachea ( [tracheostomy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tracheostomy "Tracheostomy")) and inserting a [tube](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tracheal_tube "Tracheal tube") connected to a ventilator.[\[16\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Care2017-16) It is an option for people with advanced ALS whose respiratory symptoms are poorly managed despite continuous NIV use.[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Support2016-5) While invasive ventilation prolongs survival, especially for those younger than 60, it does not treat the underlying neurodegenerative process. The person with ALS will continue to lose motor function, making communication increasingly difficult and sometimes leading to [locked-in syndrome](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Locked-in_syndrome "Locked-in syndrome"), in which they are completely paralyzed except for their eye muscles.[\[16\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Care2017-16) About half of the people with ALS who choose to undergo invasive ventilation report a decrease in their quality of life[\[17\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Conn2015-17) but most still consider it to be satisfactory. However, invasive ventilation imposes a heavy burden on caregivers and may decrease their quality of life.[\[16\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Care2017-16) Attitudes toward invasive ventilation vary from country to country; about 30% of people with ALS in Japan choose invasive ventilation, versus less than 5% in North America and Europe.[\[97\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-ALS_Ethics-97) ### Therapy \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=ALS&action=edit§ion=26 "Edit section: Therapy")\] [![A man with ALS communicates with his wife by pointing to letters and words with a head mounted laser pointer.](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Using_a_head_mounted_laser_to_point_to_a_communication_board.jpg/600px-Using_a_head_mounted_laser_to_point_to_a_communication_board.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Using_a_head_mounted_laser_to_point_to_a_communication_board.jpg) A man with ALS communicates by pointing to letters and words using a head-mounted laser pointer. [Physical therapy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Physical_therapy "Physical therapy") plays a large role in rehabilitation for individuals with ALS. Specifically, physical, occupational, and speech therapists can set goals and promote benefits for individuals with ALS by delaying loss of strength, maintaining endurance, limiting pain, improving speech and swallowing, preventing complications, and promoting functional independence.[\[98\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Lewis_&_Rushanan-98)[\[99\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-asha-99) Occupational therapy and special equipment such as [assistive technology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assistive_technology "Assistive technology") can also enhance people's independence and safety throughout the course of ALS.[\[101\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-ajop-101) Gentle, low-impact [aerobic exercise](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aerobic_exercise "Aerobic exercise") such as performing activities of daily living, walking, swimming, and [stationary bicycling](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stationary_bicycle "Stationary bicycle") can strengthen unaffected muscles, improve cardiovascular health, and help people fight fatigue and depression. Range of motion and stretching exercises can help prevent painful [spasticity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spasticity "Spasticity") and shortening (contracture) of muscles.[\[120\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-120) Physical and occupational therapists can recommend exercises that provide these benefits without overworking muscles because muscle exhaustion can lead to a worsening of symptoms associated with ALS, rather than providing help to people with ALS.[\[100\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-British_Medical_Bulletin-100) They can suggest devices such as ramps, braces, walkers, bathroom equipment (shower chairs, toilet risers, etc.), and wheelchairs that help people remain mobile. Occupational therapists can provide or recommend equipment and adaptations to enable ALS people to retain as much safety and independence in activities of daily living as possible.[\[101\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-ajop-101) Since respiratory insufficiency is the primary cause of mortality, physical therapists can help improve respiratory outcomes in people with ALS by implementing pulmonary physical therapy. This includes inspiratory muscle training, lung volume recruitment training, and manual assisted cough therapy aimed at increasing respiratory muscle strength as well as increasing survival rates.[\[121\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-121) People with ALS who have difficulty speaking or swallowing may benefit from working with a [speech-language pathologist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Speech-language_pathology "Speech-language pathology").[\[99\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-asha-99) These health professionals can teach people adaptive strategies such as techniques to help them speak louder and more clearly. As ALS progresses, speech-language pathologists can recommend the use of [augmentative and alternative communication](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Augmentative_and_alternative_communication "Augmentative and alternative communication") such as voice amplifiers, speech-generating devices (or voice output communication devices), or low-tech communication techniques such as head-mounted laser pointers, [alphabet boards](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Letter_board#Communication_Board "Letter board") or yes/no signals.[\[99\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-asha-99) ### Nutrition \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=ALS&action=edit§ion=27 "Edit section: Nutrition")\] [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Percutaneous_endoscopic_gastrostomy-tube.jpg/250px-Percutaneous_endoscopic_gastrostomy-tube.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Percutaneous_endoscopic_gastrostomy-tube.jpg) A [gastrostomy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gastrostomy "Gastrostomy") tube is placed through the wall of the abdomen into the stomach. Preventing [weight loss](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weight_loss "Weight loss") and [malnutrition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malnutrition "Malnutrition") in people with ALS improves both survival and quality of life.[\[9\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Lancet2017-9) Weight loss in ALS is often caused by muscle wasting and increased resting energy expenditure. Weight loss may also be secondary to reduced food intake since [dysphagia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dysphagia "Dysphagia") develops in about 85% of people with ALS at some point throughout their disease course.[\[16\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Care2017-16) Therefore, regular periodic assessment of the weight and swallowing ability in people with ALS is very important.[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Support2016-5) Dysphagia is often initially managed via dietary changes and modified swallowing techniques.[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Nature2017-10) People with ALS are often instructed to avoid dry or chewy foods in their diet and instead have meals that are soft, moist, and easy to swallow.[\[118\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-NeuroRehabilitation_2015-118) Switching to thick liquids (like fruit nectar or smoothies) or adding thickeners (to thin fluids like water and coffee) may also help people facing difficulty swallowing liquids. There is tentative evidence that high-calorie diets may prevent further weight loss and improve survival,[\[107\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Therapeutic_Advances_in_Neurological_Disorders-107) but more research is still needed. A [feeding tube](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feeding_tube "Feeding tube") should be considered if someone with ALS loses 5% or more of their body weight or if they cannot safely swallow food and water.[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Nature2017-10) This can take the form of a [gastrostomy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gastrostomy "Gastrostomy") tube, in which a tube is placed through the wall of the abdomen into the stomach, or (less commonly) a [nasogastric tube](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nasogastric_tube "Nasogastric tube"), in which a tube is placed through the nose and down the esophagus into the stomach.[\[16\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Care2017-16) A gastrostomy tube is more appropriate for long-term use[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Support2016-5) than a nasogastric tube, which is uncomfortable and can cause esophageal ulcers.[\[16\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Care2017-16) The feeding tube is usually inserted by a [percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Percutaneous_endoscopic_gastrostomy "Percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy") procedure (PEG). While there is weak evidence that PEG tubes improve survival in people with ALS, no [randomized controlled trials](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Randomized_controlled_trial "Randomized controlled trial") (RCTs) have yet been conducted to indicate whether enteral tube feeding has benefits compared to continuation of feeding by mouth.[\[102\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-:0-102) Nevertheless, PEG tubes are still offered with the intent of improving the person's quality of life[\[17\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Conn2015-17) by sustaining nutrition, hydration status, and medication intake.[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Support2016-5) ### End-of-life care \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=ALS&action=edit§ion=28 "Edit section: End-of-life care")\] [Palliative care](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palliative_care "Palliative care"), which relieves symptoms and improves the quality of life without treating the underlying disease, should begin shortly after someone is diagnosed with ALS.[\[103\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-EFNS_2012-103) Early discussion of end-of-life issues gives people with ALS time to reflect on their preferences for [end-of-life care](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/End-of-life_care "End-of-life care") and can help avoid unwanted interventions or procedures.[\[17\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Conn2015-17) Once they have been fully informed about all aspects of various life-prolonging measures, they can fill out [advance directives](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Advance_directive "Advance directive") indicating their attitude toward noninvasive ventilation, invasive ventilation, and feeding tubes.[\[107\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Therapeutic_Advances_in_Neurological_Disorders-107) Late in the disease course, difficulty speaking due to muscle weakness ( [dysarthria](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dysarthria "Dysarthria")) and cognitive dysfunction may impair their ability to communicate their wishes regarding care.[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Nature2017-10) Continued failure to solicit the preferences of the person with ALS may lead to unplanned and potentially unwanted emergency interventions, such as invasive ventilation. If people with ALS or their family members are reluctant to discuss end-of-life issues, it may be useful to use the introduction of gastrostomy or noninvasive ventilation as an opportunity to bring up the subject.[\[17\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Conn2015-17) [Hospice care](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hospice_care "Hospice care"), or palliative care at the end of life, is especially important in ALS because it helps to optimize the management of symptoms and increases the likelihood of a peaceful death.[\[17\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Conn2015-17) It is unclear exactly when the end-of-life phase begins in ALS, but it is associated with significant difficulty moving, communicating, and, in some cases, thinking.[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Nature2017-10) Although many people with ALS fear choking to death (suffocating),[\[17\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Conn2015-17) they can be reassured that this occurs rarely, less than 1% of the time.[\[122\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-122) Most patients die at home,[\[17\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Conn2015-17) and in the final days of life, opioids can be used to treat pain and [dyspnea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dyspnea "Dyspnea"), while [benzodiazepines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benzodiazepine "Benzodiazepine") can be used to treat anxiety.[\[16\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Care2017-16) ## Epidemiology \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=ALS&action=edit§ion=29 "Edit section: Epidemiology")\] ALS is the most common [motor neuron disease](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motor_neuron_diseases "Motor neuron diseases") in adults and the third most common [neurodegenerative disease](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neurodegenerative_disease "Neurodegenerative disease")[\[61\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Neuroscience2014-61) after [Alzheimer's disease](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alzheimer%27s_disease "Alzheimer's disease") and [Parkinson's disease](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parkinson%27s_disease "Parkinson's disease").[\[123\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-123) Worldwide the number of people who develop ALS yearly is estimated to be 1.9 people per 100,000 per year, while the number of people who have ALS at any given time is estimated to be about 4.5 people per 100,000.[\[124\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-124) In Europe, the number of new cases a year is about 2.6 people per 100,000, while the number affected is 7–9 people per 100,000.[\[125\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-125) The lifetime risk of developing ALS is 1:350 for European men and 1:400 for European women. Men have a higher risk mainly because spinal-onset ALS is more common in men than women.[\[63\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Conspiracy-63) The number of those with ALS in the United States in 2015 was 5.2 people per 100,000, and was higher in whites, males, and people over 60 years old.[\[126\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-MMWR_2015-126) The number of new cases is about 0.8 people per 100,000 per year in East Asia and about 0.7 people per 100,000 per year in South Asia. About 80% of ALS epidemiology studies have been conducted in Europe and the United States, mostly in people of northern European descent.[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Nature2017-10) There is not enough information to determine the rates of ALS in much of the world, including Africa, parts of Asia, India, Russia, and South America.[\[63\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Conspiracy-63) There are several geographic clusters in the Western Pacific where the prevalence of ALS was reported to be 50–100 times higher than in the rest of the world, including [Guam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guam "Guam"), the [Kii Peninsula](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kii_Peninsula "Kii Peninsula") of Japan, and [Western New Guinea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_New_Guinea "Western New Guinea"). The incidence in these areas has decreased since the 1960s;[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Orphanet2009-1) the cause remains unknown.[\[63\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Conspiracy-63) [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Prevalence_of_ALS_in_the_United_States_by_age_group%2C_2012-2015.jpg/500px-Prevalence_of_ALS_in_the_United_States_by_age_group%2C_2012-2015.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Prevalence_of_ALS_in_the_United_States_by_age_group,_2012-2015.jpg) Estimated prevalence of ALS in the United States by age group, 2012–2015[\[126\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-MMWR_2015-126) People of all races and ethnic backgrounds may be affected by ALS,[\[126\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-MMWR_2015-126) but it is more common in whites than in Africans, Asians, or Hispanics.[\[127\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Projected2016-127) In the United States in 2015, the prevalence of ALS in whites was 5.4 people per 100,000, while the prevalence in blacks was 2.3 people per 100,000. The Midwest had the highest prevalence of the four US Census regions with 5.5 people per 100,000, followed by the Northeast (5.1), the South (4.7), and the West (4.4). The Midwest and Northeast likely had a higher prevalence of ALS because they have a higher proportion of whites than the South and West.[\[126\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-MMWR_2015-126) Ethnically mixed populations may be at a lower risk of developing ALS; a study in Cuba found that people of mixed ancestry were less likely to die from ALS than whites or blacks.[\[128\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Current_Issues_in_ALS_Epidemiology-128) There are also differences in the genetics of ALS between different ethnic groups; the most common ALS gene in Europe is _C9orf72_, followed by _SOD1_, _TARDBP_, and _FUS_, while the most common ALS gene in Asia is _SOD1_, followed by _FUS_, _C9orf72_, and _TARDBP_.[\[129\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-129) ALS can affect people at any age,[\[54\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Martin2017-54) but the peak incidence is between 50 and 75 years[\[9\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Lancet2017-9) and decreases dramatically after 80 years.[\[18\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Lancet2011-18) The reason for the decreased incidence in the elderly is unclear. One thought is that people who survive into their 80s may not be genetically susceptible to developing ALS; alternatively, ALS in the elderly might go undiagnosed because of [comorbidities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comorbidities "Comorbidities") (other diseases they have), difficulty seeing a neurologist, or dying quickly from an aggressive form of ALS.[\[128\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Current_Issues_in_ALS_Epidemiology-128) In the United States in 2015, the lowest prevalence was in the 18–39 age group, while the highest prevalence was in the 70–79 age group.[\[126\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-MMWR_2015-126) Sporadic ALS usually starts around the ages of 58 to 63 years, while genetic ALS starts earlier, usually around 47 to 52 years.[\[18\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Lancet2011-18) The number of ALS cases worldwide is projected to increase from 222,801 in 2015 to 376,674 in 2040, an increase of 69%. This will largely be due to the aging of the world's population, especially in developing countries.[\[127\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Projected2016-127) ## History \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=ALS&action=edit§ion=30 "Edit section: History")\] [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Jean-Martin_Charcot.jpg/380px-Jean-Martin_Charcot.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Jean-Martin_Charcot.jpg) The French neurologist [Jean-Martin Charcot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jean-Martin_Charcot "Jean-Martin Charcot") coined the term _amyotrophic lateral sclerosis_ in 1874.[\[20\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Rowland2001-20)[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/1923_Lou_Gehrig.png/500px-1923_Lou_Gehrig.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:1923_Lou_Gehrig.png) American baseball player [Lou Gehrig](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lou_Gehrig "Lou Gehrig"). In some countries, especially the United States, ALS is called "Lou Gehrig's disease".[\[130\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-What's_in_a_name?-130) Descriptions of the disease date back to at least 1824 by [Charles Bell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Bell "Charles Bell").[\[20\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Rowland2001-20) In 1850, [François-Amilcar Aran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fran%C3%A7ois-Amilcar_Aran "François-Amilcar Aran") was the first to describe a disorder he named "progressive muscular atrophy", a form of ALS in which only the lower motor neurons are affected.[\[131\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-131) In 1869, the connection between the symptoms and the underlying neurological problems was first described by [Jean-Martin Charcot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jean-Martin_Charcot "Jean-Martin Charcot"), who initially introduced the term _amyotrophic lateral sclerosis_ in his 1874 paper.[\[20\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Rowland2001-20) Flail arm syndrome, a regional variant of ALS, was first described by [Alfred Vulpian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alfred_Vulpian "Alfred Vulpian") in 1886. Flail leg syndrome, another regional variant of ALS, was first described by [Pierre Marie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pierre_Marie "Pierre Marie") and his student Patrikios in 1918.[\[132\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-132) ### Diagnostic criteria \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=ALS&action=edit§ion=31 "Edit section: Diagnostic criteria")\] In the 1950s, [electrodiagnostic testing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electrodiagnostic_testing "Electrodiagnostic testing") (EMG) and [nerve conduction velocity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nerve_conduction_velocity "Nerve conduction velocity") (NCV) testing began to be used to evaluate clinically suspected ALS. In 1969 [Edward H. Lambert](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electromyography#History "Electromyography") published the first EMG/NCS diagnostic criteria for ALS, consisting of four findings he considered to strongly support the diagnosis.[\[133\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-133) Since then several diagnostic criteria have been developed, which are mostly in use for research purposes for inclusion/exclusion criteria, and to stratify patients for analysis in trials. Research diagnostic criteria for ALS include the "El Escorial" in 1994,[\[134\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-134) revised in 1998.[\[135\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-135) In 2006, the "Awaji" criteria proposed using EMG and NCV tests to help diagnose ALS earlier,[\[136\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-136) and most recently the "Gold Coast" criteria in 2019.[\[137\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-137) ### Name \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=ALS&action=edit§ion=32 "Edit section: Name")\] See also: [Motor neuron diseases](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motor_neuron_diseases "Motor neuron diseases") _Amyotrophic_ comes from [Greek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greek_language "Greek language"): _a-_ means "no", _myo-_ (from _mûs_) refers to "muscle", and _trophḗ_ means "nourishment". Therefore, _[amyotrophy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amyotrophy "Amyotrophy")_ means "muscle malnourishment"[\[138\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-What_is_ALS?-138) or the wasting of muscle tissue.[\[139\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-139) _Lateral_ identifies the locations in the spinal cord of the affected motor neurons. _[Sclerosis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sclerosis_(medicine) "Sclerosis (medicine)")_ means "scarring" or "hardening" and refers to the death of the motor neurons in the spinal cord.[\[138\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-What_is_ALS?-138) ALS is sometimes referred to as _Charcot's disease_ (not to be confused with [Charcot–Marie–Tooth disease](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charcot%E2%80%93Marie%E2%80%93Tooth_disease "Charcot–Marie–Tooth disease") or [Charcot joint disease](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charcot_joint_disease "Charcot joint disease")), because [Jean-Martin Charcot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jean-Martin_Charcot "Jean-Martin Charcot") was the first to connect the clinical symptoms with the pathology seen at autopsy.[\[140\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-140) The British neurologist [Russell Brain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russell_Brain "Russell Brain") coined the term _motor neuron disease_ in 1933 to reflect his belief that ALS, progressive bulbar palsy, and progressive muscular atrophy were all different forms of the same disease.[\[141\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-141) In some countries, especially the United States, ALS is called _Lou Gehrig's disease_[\[130\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-What's_in_a_name?-130) after the American [baseball](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baseball "Baseball") player [Lou Gehrig](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lou_Gehrig "Lou Gehrig"), who was diagnosed with ALS in 1939.[\[142\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-142) In the United States and continental Europe, the term _ALS_ (as well as _Lou Gehrig's disease_ in the US) refers to all forms of the disease, including "classical" ALS, [progressive bulbar palsy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Progressive_bulbar_palsy "Progressive bulbar palsy"), [progressive muscular atrophy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Progressive_muscular_atrophy "Progressive muscular atrophy"), and [primary lateral sclerosis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Primary_lateral_sclerosis "Primary lateral sclerosis").[\[143\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-UMN_Assessment-143)[\[33\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-Clinical_Features_of_ALS-33) In the United Kingdom and Australia, the term _motor neuron disease_ refers to all forms of the disease while _ALS_ only refers to "classical" ALS, meaning the form with both upper and lower motor neuron involvement.[\[143\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-UMN_Assessment-143) ## Society and culture \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=ALS&action=edit§ion=33 "Edit section: Society and culture")\] [Play video](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:ALS_Ice_Bucket_Challenge.ogv "Play video") Duration: 23 seconds.0:23A student demonstrating the ice bucket challenge See also: [List of people with motor neuron disease](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_people_with_motor_neuron_disease "List of people with motor neuron disease") In addition to the baseball player [Lou Gehrig](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lou_Gehrig "Lou Gehrig") and the theoretical physicist [Stephen Hawking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stephen_Hawking "Stephen Hawking") (who notably lived longer than any other known person with the condition), several other notable individuals have or have had ALS.[\[65\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-auto-65) Several books have been written and films have been made about patients of the disease as well. American sociology professor and ALS patient [Morrie Schwartz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morrie_Schwartz "Morrie Schwartz") was the subject of the memoir _[Tuesdays with Morrie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tuesdays_with_Morrie "Tuesdays with Morrie")_ and the [film of the same name](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tuesdays_with_Morrie_(film) "Tuesdays with Morrie (film)"), and Stephen Hawking was the subject of the critically acclaimed biopic _[The Theory of Everything](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Theory_of_Everything_(2014_film) "The Theory of Everything (2014 film)")_. In August 2014, the " [Ice Bucket Challenge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ice_Bucket_Challenge "Ice Bucket Challenge")" to raise money for ALS research went [viral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Viral_phenomenon "Viral phenomenon") online.[\[144\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-144) Participants filmed themselves filling a bucket full of ice water and pouring it onto themselves; they then nominated other individuals to do the same. Many participants donated to ALS research at the [ALS Association](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS_Association "ALS Association"), the [ALS Therapy Development Institute](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS_Therapy_Development_Institute "ALS Therapy Development Institute"), [ALS Society of Canada](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS_Society_of_Canada "ALS Society of Canada"), or [Motor neuron Disease Association](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motor_Neurone_Disease_Association "Motor Neurone Disease Association") in the UK.[\[145\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_note-145) ## References \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=ALS&action=edit§ion=34 "Edit section: References")\] 001. ^ [Jump up to: _**a**_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_ref-Orphanet2009_1-0) [_**b**_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS#cite_ref-Orphanet2009_1-1)Wijesekera LC, Leigh PN (February 2009). ## Player News

[See All](https://www.nba.com/stats/fantasynews/?Team=pacers)

06/16/2025, 7:30 PM

Dealing with lower leg issue

Haliburton provided four points (0-6 FG, 0-4 3Pt, 4-4 FT), seven rebounds and six assists across 34 minutes during Monday's 120-109 loss to the Thunder in Game 5 of the NBA Finals. He also appears to be dealing with a right lower leg issue, though he expects to play in Game 6 on Thursday, Tony East of WTHR Channel 13 Indianapolis reports.

06/16/2025, 4:20 PM

Briefly exits Monday

Haliburton briefly exited to the locker room in the first quarter of Monday's Game 5 of the NBA Finals due to right lower leg tightness, Tony East of WTHR Channel 13 Indianapolis reports. However, he returned with 8:27 remaining in the second quarter.

06/12/2025, 7:03 AM

Shines in Game 3 win

Haliburton racked up 22 points (9-17 FG, 4-8 3Pt), nine rebounds, 11 assists, one block and two steals over 36 minutes during Wednesday's 116-107 win over the Thunder in Game 3 of the NBA Finals.

06/10/2025, 8:24 AM

Will play in Game 3

Haliburton is dealing with a lower leg issue but said he will play in Game 3 of the NBA Finals against the Thunder on Wednesday, Jamal Collier of ESPN.com reports.

06/05/2025, 6:43 PM

Stuns OKC in Game 1

Haliburton supplied 14 points (6-13 FG, 2-7 3Pt), 10 rebounds, six assists and one block across 39 minutes during Thursday's 111-110 victory over the Thunder in Game 1 of the NBA Finals.

[**Storyline**](https://www.imdb.com/title/tt10548174/#storyline)

[Edit](https://contribute.imdb.com/updates?edit=tt10548174/storyline&ref_=tt_stry)

It's been almost three decades since the rage virus escaped a biological weapons laboratory, and now, still in a ruthlessly enforced quarantine, some have found ways to exist amidst the infected. One such group of survivors lives on a small island connected to the mainland by a single, heavily-defended causeway. When one of the group leaves the island on a mission into the dark heart of the mainland, he discovers secrets, wonders, and horrors that have mutated not only the infected but other survivors as well.

The trailer features a distinctive recording of the poem 'Boots' by [Rudyard Kipling](https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0456017/?ref_=dyk_trv), read by the actor [Taylor Holmes](https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0392067/?ref_=dyk_trv) in 1915. The poem's repetitive rhythm imagines the march of British soldiers during the Boer War, and this recording of the poem is used by the US military to simulate the psychological distress of being held captive.

The flats in 2015 | | [![Map](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/250x200@2x.png?lang=en&domain=en.wikipedia.org&title=Gordon_Wilson_Flats&groups=_76ff176e3f3a8d3b450f57601a27ddd50454cc05)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Wilson_Flats#/map/0 "Show in full screen")
[Show in full screen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Wilson_Flats#/map/0 "Show in full screen")[Wikimedia](https://foundation.wikimedia.org/wiki/Maps_Terms_of_Use) \| © [OpenStreetMap](https://www.openstreetmap.org/copyright) | | General information | | Address | 320 The Terrace | | Town or city | Wellington | | Country | New Zealand | | [Coordinates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system "Geographic coordinate system") | ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/WMA_button2b.png/34px-WMA_button2b.png)[41°17′28″S174°46′13″E﻿ / ﻿41.29109°S 174.77040°E﻿ / -41.29109; 174.77040](https://geohack.toolforge.org/geohack.php?pagename=Gordon_Wilson_Flats¶ms=41.29109_S_174.7704_E_type:landmark_region:NZ) | | Named for | [Gordon Wilson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Wilson_(architect) "Gordon Wilson (architect)") | | Completed | 1959 | | Closed | 2012 | | Owner | [Victoria University of Wellington](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Victoria_University_of_Wellington "Victoria University of Wellington") | **Gordon Wilson Flats** is a residential building in central Wellington, completed in 1959. The building was owned by Housing New Zealand and housed 131 people. It is currently owned by [Victoria University of Wellington](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Victoria_University_of_Wellington "Victoria University of Wellington"), and is unoccupied pending a decision on its future.[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Wilson_Flats#cite_note-Building_may_be_demolished-1) On 17 June 2025, the New Zealand government said it would remove the flats' heritage protected status. [https://www.beehive.govt.nz/release/gordon-wilson-flats’-heritage-protection-goneburger](https://www.beehive.govt.nz/release/gordon-wilson-flats%E2%80%99-heritage-protection-goneburger) The Terrace Flats was renamed in honour of government architect [Gordon Wilson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Wilson_(architect) "Gordon Wilson (architect)") who died in its final year of construction.[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Wilson_Flats#cite_note-Te_Ara_-_Wilson-2)[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Wilson_Flats#cite_note-wareham_cameron_+_co-3) ## Use as social housing: 1959–2013 \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Gordon_Wilson_Flats&action=edit§ion=1 "Edit section: Use as social housing: 1959–2013")\] | | | | --- | --- | | [![[icon]](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/20px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg) | This section **needs expansion**. You can help by [adding to it](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Gordon_Wilson_Flats&action=edit§ion=). _(May 2016)_ | The foundation stone for the building was laid on 6 August 1957,[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Wilson_Flats#cite_note-wareham_cameron_+_co-3) with completion in 1959. The complex housed around 130 people.[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Wilson_Flats#cite_note-Building_may_be_demolished-1) ### Earthquake assessment \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Gordon_Wilson_Flats&action=edit§ion=2 "Edit section: Earthquake assessment")\] An engineering firm first reported concerns about the building in April 2010. A later assessment determined that a large person falling on a balcony could cause masonry façades to fall off the building. Housing New Zealand was more concerned about strong wind or an earthquake event, however, and decided to relocate tenants to avoid any problems.[\[4\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Wilson_Flats#cite_note-Large_person_collapse-4) "The building is corroding, so it's a progressive deterioration," HNZ assets development general manager Sean Bignell said.[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Wilson_Flats#cite_note-5) ## Vacancy, sale and mooted demolition \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Gordon_Wilson_Flats&action=edit§ion=3 "Edit section: Vacancy, sale and mooted demolition")\] [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Gordon_Wilson_Flats_warning_sign.jpg/250px-Gordon_Wilson_Flats_warning_sign.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Gordon_Wilson_Flats_warning_sign.jpg) The danger sign outside the Gordon Wilson Flats on the Terrace Tenants had to leave the flats in May 2012, after [Housing New Zealand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Housing_New_Zealand "Housing New Zealand") had serious doubts about the building's structural integrity and safety.[\[4\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Wilson_Flats#cite_note-Large_person_collapse-4) Tenants were only given seven days notice to leave, a move which was criticised by some MPs, who pointed out the lack of other options for ex-tenants, especially at such short notice.[\[6\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Wilson_Flats#cite_note-6) Some tenants said they found the process very stressful, particularly given many of the residents had health problems or were refugees who didn't speak English well.[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Wilson_Flats#cite_note-7) At the time Housing New Zealand moved tenants out of the building, the organisation said it was determining what to do with the building, and said no decisions had yet been made about its future. Their regional tenancy manager said at the time: "Wellington has a high demand for housing. Our preference is to upgrade the building".[\[4\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Wilson_Flats#cite_note-Large_person_collapse-4) In January 2014, Wellington MP [Grant Robertson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grant_Robertson "Grant Robertson") sought assurances that it would remain as social housing, and said he was worried it would be sold off rather than redeveloped. Housing advocates also pointed out that there was a shortage of social housing in Wellington, especially given the temporary closure of a number of housing complexes for earthquake strengthening.[\[8\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Wilson_Flats#cite_note-8) ### Sale to Victoria University \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Gordon_Wilson_Flats&action=edit§ion=4 "Edit section: Sale to Victoria University")\] In February 2014, Radio New Zealand reported that Housing New Zealand was in negotiations to sell the flats to Victoria University of Wellington. Neither party to the negotiations would comment. Wellington MP Grant Robertson said he was worried social housing was being driven out of the central city.[\[9\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Wilson_Flats#cite_note-9) In September 2014, it was announced that Victoria University of Wellington would purchase the building. The university bought the building because of its proximity to its Kelburn campus, and the potential for it to provide a link between the Terrace and Wai-te-ata Road. The Vice-Chancellor of Victoria University, [Grant Guilford](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grant_Guilford "Grant Guilford"), said that the university was in the process of making a decision about whether to demolish the building in consultation with the community.[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Wilson_Flats#cite_note-Building_may_be_demolished-1) He commented that: > If the consensus of the community was that the building shouldn't be there, it would certainly suit our views.[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Wilson_Flats#cite_note-Building_may_be_demolished-1) It was subsequently revealed that the purchase price was over $6 million.[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Wilson_Flats#cite_note-10) In July 2015, Urban Perspectives Limited, on behalf of Victoria University, lodged an application with [Wellington City Council](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wellington_City_Council "Wellington City Council") to rezone the area from "Inner Residential Area" to "Institutional Precinct", remove the Flats from the City District Plan’s heritage list, and amend the Institutional Precinct provisions of the District Plan.[\[11\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Wilson_Flats#cite_note-11) Evidence presented to the Wellington City Council panel by architectural historian noted the architectural significance of the flats: > The Gordon Wilson Flats have exceptional architectural significance. Not only are they associated with F. Gordon Wilson, one of the most prominent, powerful and influential architects in New Zealand from the 1930s through to the 1950s but they are the last of a line of highly important high rise social housing projects built by the state. They were initiated by the first Labour Government of 1935 and they reflect and have a direct connection with international modernism.[\[12\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Wilson_Flats#cite_note-12) In April 2016, a Wellington City Council panel approved the rezoning of the flats, allowing Victoria University to demolish the building and build anything – possibly student accommodation. The media reported that the prospect of noisy student accommodation worried neighbours.[\[13\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Wilson_Flats#cite_note-13)[\[14\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Wilson_Flats#cite_note-14) In July 2016, the Architectural Centre lodged an appeal in the [Environment Court](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Environment_Court_of_New_Zealand "Environment Court of New Zealand") against the Wellington City Council's decision to remove the Gordon Wilson flats' heritage status under Wellington's District Plan.[\[15\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Wilson_Flats#cite_note-15) The appeal was successful with the court determining that the heritage listing should stand in August 2017.[\[16\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Wilson_Flats#cite_note-16) In July 2020, the University revealed plans to rezone the site for institutional use, and to demolish the flats in favour of a development including an 'outdoor entrance plaza and new teaching and research facilities'.[\[17\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Wilson_Flats#cite_note-17) The new design was to be called [Te Huanui](https://www.wgtn.ac.nz/huanui), which the university called "a great opportunity for positive inner-city development."[\[18\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Wilson_Flats#cite_note-18) In February 2021, the flats were listed by [Heritage New Zealand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heritage_New_Zealand "Heritage New Zealand") as a category 1 historic place, meaning any plans to develop the site would need Environment Court approval.[\[19\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Wilson_Flats#cite_note-19) Plans for Te Huanui have been "put on hold" since that time.[\[20\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Wilson_Flats#cite_note-20) In March 2024, the Wellington City Council voted to remove the heritage designation from the Gordon Wilson flats in an update of the district plan.[\[21\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Wilson_Flats#cite_note-21) As a result of law changes leading to the National Policy Statement on Urban Development,[\[22\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Wilson_Flats#cite_note-22) the council's decisions in updated district plans cannot be appealed to the Environment Court. The updated district plan only requires approval from the [Housing Minister](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minister_of_Housing_(New_Zealand) "Minister of Housing (New Zealand)"), [Chris Bishop](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chris_Bishop "Chris Bishop").[\[23\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Wilson_Flats#cite_note-23) ## References \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Gordon_Wilson_Flats&action=edit§ion=5 "Edit section: References")\] 01. ^ [Jump up to: _**a**_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Wilson_Flats#cite_ref-Building_may_be_demolished_1-0) [_**b**_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Wilson_Flats#cite_ref-Building_may_be_demolished_1-1) [_**c**_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Wilson_Flats#cite_ref-Building_may_be_demolished_1-2) [_**d**_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Wilson_Flats#cite_ref-Building_may_be_demolished_1-3)Fensom, Alex (13 September 2014).
